fields.description: Have lunch by the river at our head office in a beautiful Oxfordshire deer park, or take long walks along the river.
fields.title: In the glorious Cotswolds

fields.description: Go out with the team to try the endless supply of real ales, or try the abumdance of street food and sit in the vibrant parks.
fields.title: Vibrant centre of Bristol

fields.description: Visit the sights with our team in America’s original capital. Rich in history and culture, Philadelphia is a great place to be.
fields.title: Historic Philadelphia

fields.description: Torchbox co-founders, Tom and Olly, met whilst working at OneWorld.org. Tom, a techy, and Olly, a creative, quickly realised that their shared passion, of wanting to drive positive change, warranted a go at starting a digital agency. Cue Torchbox.
fields.title: When Tom Met Olly

fields.description: It's hard to imagine what life without Drupal was like. Since 2007, we've used Drupal to create beautiful, yet powerful websites for some of the world's best-known organisations, including the University of Oxford, Chatham House and Greenpeace.
fields.title: Drupal Service Launched

fields.description: Thanks to Tom and Olly's love of skiing, Torchbox's bi-annual company ski trips started in 2006. A much-loved calendar event, the trips provide our team with well-deserved time out.
fields.title: First Torchbox Ski Trip

fields.description: In 2014, Wagtail, our open source content management system was unveiled to the world. Powered by Django, Wagtail has quickly grown to become the world's new favourite CMS, powering websites such as Global Witness, Meningitis Now and the Royal Drawing School.
fields.title: Wagtail Launches

fields.description: 2015 was the year we hit 50 full-time employees. We're extremely proud of our team of designers, developers, software engineers, project managers and digital marketers. Together, we affect positive change.
fields.title: 50 Staff and Counting

fields.description: To accommodate our growing Bristol team, we recently moved into shiny, new offices in the city centre. Equipped with a creative shed, a cafe area and old school video games, it's safe to say that our Bristol team are loving their new home.
fields.title: New Bristol Office

fields.description: By 2001, the Torchbox team had outgrown the premises of Tom's kitchen. After landing a contract with a client based in Oxford, Tom and Olly made the decision to open Torchbox's first office nearby, in the idyllic grounds of Cornbury Park.
fields.title: Charlbury Office

fields.description: In 2013, we won the tender to design and build the Royal College of Art's (RCA) website. The technical requirements requested by RCA were not possible with any available open-source, content management system, so we built our own. Cue the birth of Wagtail.
fields.title: Royal College of Art

fields.description: Our award-winning design team know how to make things look good. They understand that the key to delivering lasting value is to create something that people enjoy and understand.
fields.title: Design

fields.description: We specialise in building powerful, flexible and scalable websites in both Drupal and Wagtail. Our team of expert developers thrive on developing solutions to meet complex requirements.
fields.title: Development

fields.description: From persona development and customer journey mapping through to wireframing, we put the needs of users first to create online experiences which drive results.
fields.title: User Experience

fields.description: Our software engineers have the skills and experience to tackle the most complex projects. Whatever system, feature, functionality or process you need, we can build it for you.
fields.title: Software Engineering

fields.description: Achieve business goals and grow digital audiences with the help of our social media team. From channel management through to content marketing and blogging, we’ve got it covered.
fields.title: Social Media

fields.description: We’re specialists in PPC management and Google Grants optimisation. Our granular approach and cutting edge technology keeps our clients one step ahead of the digital curve.
fields.title: Paid Search

fields.description: Our SEO projects ensure your website appeals to audiences and search engines in equal measure. We can help you reach new audiences, fundraisers, journalists and more.
fields.title: SEO

fields.description: Our qualified analytics consultants specialise in data storytelling, joining the dots between channels and devices to deliver greater online performance and increased sales.
fields.title: Google Analytics
Total UI freedom with Head-transplanted Drupal
Where am I in the Twig Loop?

Torchbox Shortlisted for Two Wirehive 100 Awards

fields.body: Work with our brilliant and talented team of designers, developers, project managers, and digital marketers. We’re a lovely bunch of sports enthusiasts, creatives, musicians, cyclists, readers, cooks and more.
fields.title: This lot

fields.body: We're very selective about who we work with. At the end of the day you'll go home knowing you've helped to make the world a better place.
fields.title: Ethical clients

fields.body: From large, complex website projects to campaign platforms and custom apps, we've always got lots of interesting creative and technical challenges to tackle.
fields.title: Cool projects

fields.body: Most years we put together a collaborative company Christmas card - and sometimes they go viral! Past initiatives have included talking mooses, iPad dances, on-demand snow machines, creative map plotting and interactive choirs.
fields.title: Viral Christmas cards

fields.body: Occasionally we all head off together for a few days of fun in the snow, complete with ski chalet, hot tub and lots of food and drink.
fields.title: Ski trips

fields.body: We want you to have everything you need to do your job well. All reasonable requests accepted – just ask!
fields.title: Decent kit

fields.body: Our offices come equipped with superior coffee, tea, fresh fruit and bread. We’ve got standing desks and comfortable sofas. Make sure you try out the juicer.
fields.title: Office perks

fields.body: With a cycle-to-work scheme, pension, health plan, and life cover, we’re interested in your wellbeing as well as your work.
fields.title: Beyond the office

fields.text: It’s been a wonderful experience. Working with Torchbox has helped sharpen our communication skills.
It’s been great working with Torchbox. Phil has a wealth of knowledge about this stuff. Knowledge that would be very difficult for someone like myself to get unless you are doing this everyday.

It’s been a pleasure working with Torchbox, who’ve been really proactive and helpful. We’ve appreciated the advice and expertise of our account manager and are delighted to have got to Grantspro status so quickly.

fields.body: If you don’t currently have a Google Ad Grant, you’re not alone. One in five (21%) of the charities who completed our survey didn’t have an Ad Grant either.
fields.title: Get started with Google Ad Grants

fields.body: Learn how to maximize how much you are spending, improve the performance of your ad campaigns and get meaningful results.
fields.title: Discover over 20 expert tips and tricks

fields.body: Learn how other charities use their $40,000 Grantspro account and find out the best practices for managing your account.
fields.title: Find out how to make the most of Grantspro

fields.author: Amy Olson
fields.quote: Make sure a skilled member of your in-house team is in charge of it.

fields.author: James Higgott
fields.quote: Keep on top of it - it is very easy to leave it running in the background but that leads to all sorts of problems.

fields.author: Dave O'Carroll
fields.quote: Give it the time it deserves

fields.search_description: Torchbox has won two WebAwards; one for the design of Museum of London’s website and another for Shakespeare Birthplace Trust’s website.
fields.title: Torchbox Wins Two WebAwards

fields.seo_title: How to Write a Proper Brief
fields.title: How to Write a Proper Brief

fields.OxfordAddress: Unit 9, Southill Business Park, Charlbury, OX7 3EW, UK

fields.call_to_action_text: Enter your email address to receive our free guide
fields.email_body:
Thanks for requesting a copy of Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant.

We hope you'll find the stats, stories and expert advice our team has put together helpful and inspiring.

If you have any feedback on the Guide, or would like to know more about Google Ad Grants, we'd love to hear from you.

Just email phil.mcminn@torchbox.com or give us a call on +44 (0) 1608 811 870.

Torchbox
https://torchbox.com/
fields.email_subject: Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant – a best practice guide from Torchbox
fields.intro: Whether you’re new to Ad Grants or an old pro, this 28-page guide will help you make the most of this fantastic marketing opportunity.
fields.thank_you_text: Thanks! We've sent you our free guide. Please check your email.

fields.body:
If you fulfil certain criteria, you can apply for Grantspro. If approved, it means that Google will give your charity $40,000 a month to spend. That’s a whopping $480,000 a year.

At Torchbox, we help organisations manage their Google Ad Grants. Sign up for an account audit by Torchbox and we’ll let you know if you are making the most of your Google Ad Grant.

Don’t have a Grant? We can help you apply.
fields.form_subtitle: Submit your details and we will be in touch
fields.form_title: Get your charity Google Ad Grants audit
fields.grants_managed_title: Google Ad Grants we have managed
fields.intro: As part of its nonprofit programme, Google gives eligible charities $10,000 a month to spend on AdWords, Google’s pay-per-click advertising system.
Meet our team

fields.biography:
Christopher joined Torchbox as a project manager, but now specializes in PPC, Google Analytics and SEO. He has a growing side interest in A/B testing. He is Google AdWords and Analytics certified and manages Google Ad Grants for our charity clients. He loves taking these accounts up to the Grantspro level ($40,000 a month of free advertising). 

In his spare time, Christopher drums in samba bands, plays the ukulele and enjoys cycling and wild swimming.
fields.intro: Christopher studied English at Hertford College, Oxford and developed an obsession with James Joyce.

fields.biography:
Olly is ultimately responsible for the design, digital strategy, user experience, and information architecture work at Torchbox. Along with Tom, Olly also fulfils the role of MD at Torchbox.

Olly has led our teams creating award-winning sites and campaigns for a roll-call of the most exciting organisations in the development, health and education sectors. Olly tries to ensure that Torchbox doesn't just meet expectations in our projects, but exceeds them. And, after fifteen years, Olly is just as excited about the Internet's potential as a force for social good as he was in the first dot com days.

Olly leads on our user experience team and is hands on in several UX projects, running workshops, defining IAs, co-creating wireframes, overseeing test programmes, as well as running a programme of ongoing development to ensure that our UX practices are continually evolving.

Olly is a married dad of three. He enjoys sports (cycling, skiing, tennis, cricket, squash), and dabbles with am-dram! He is currently rehearsing for a much anticipated role as the Sheriff of Nottingham, in the Northmoor Village pantomime. To the shame of his son and father-in-law, Olly is only a half-hearted Manchester United supporter.

Olly is Non-Executive Director of the charity Valid Nutrition.
fields.intro: Olly is a Founder Director and the Creative Director at Torchbox. His job is to help our clients achieve fantastic things online.

fields.biography:
Tom graduated from Balliol College, Oxford, in 1995, swapping the later philosophy of Wittgenstein for Netscape 2 and a 9600 baud modem. He ran a little agency called Naïve ("Why don't you just call yourselves 'Stupid'?") until he joined forces with Olly in 2000, starting Torchbox with the aim of building beautiful online software for people who make the world a better place.

As Technical Director, Tom is responsible for making sure the things we build are fast and reliable and easy to maintain. He manages the tech team and account directs many of our large technical projects. Along with Olly, Tom tries to make Torchbox a fun and inspiring place to work.

Tom lives with his family in the countryside. He reads novels and gets cross at tennis. He plays in three bands who will probably never make it. He composed the theme tune to Charlie and Lola.
fields.intro: Tom is a co-founder of Torchbox, and its Technical Director.

fields.biography:
He has been responsible for some of our standout creative work for clients including WWF, The King’s Fund, Canal & River Trust, and Chatham House.

Now based in our Bristol office, Ben has recently led our design work for The Roman Baths, the Royal Agricultural University, Global Witness, and Meningitis Now.

Outside of work he loves to brew and is perfecting his thrice-hopped pale ale. He’s also a savoury chap and loves a Bovril.

To find out more about Ben and what he gets up to at Torchbox, check out his Life as a Lead Designer at Torchbox.
fields.intro: Ben has been designing websites for Torchbox since 2004.

fields.biography:
As Torchbox's Drupal team manager, Johan's primarily responsible for making sure our talented team of developers are working effectively and enjoyably. In a previous life, Johan built websites and applications using C# before falling into step with Drupal 6. At Torchbox, he's been the technical lead on a number of high profile projects including Chatham House, Plan International, Carers Trust and CLIC Sargent and likes to consider himself a full stack developer at heart. He's even (just!) a Drupal 8 contributor.

When not wrangling with code, Johan's usually out and about with his baby daughter Clara, reading current affairs publications above his intellectual comfort zone, tending to his tropical fish and his not-so-tropical cat, and dreaming of scuba diving again in the tropics. Johan lives in the scenic Cotswold countryside, but quietly misses the vast, harsh winters and long summer days of Scandinavia.
fields.intro: Johan joined Torchbox in 2011.

fields.biography:
Helen studied English at Keble College, Oxford and took a postgraduate diploma in Cartography at Oxford Brookes.

Before joining Torchbox in 2004 she worked variously as a cartographer, a web developer and a programmer on an ESA project. Previously she was developer and project manager for many RationalMedia sites, but she now works as a front end developer on various Drupal and wagtail sites, including Oxford University and the Royal College of Art.

Outside work her main job is being a mum, but she also enjoys reading, singing in the Charlbury community choir, growing organic vegetables and attempting the Saturday Guardian crossword.
fields.intro: Helen studied English at university, but discovered her inner geek via a postgraduate course in Cartography.

fields.biography:
Justine has led the Front End development of several of our Drupal projects including Recycle Now and Chatham House.

Outside of work she loves to forage for anything edible in the countryside and is perfecting her cider-making skills. She also likes to change her hair colour to match her outfits. 

To find out more about Justine and what she gets up to at Torchbox, check out her Life as a Drupal Developer at Torchbox.
fields.intro: Justine has been meddling with Drupal's theming layer since 2009. She helps to coordinate Frontend United - the annual Drupal Frontend conference and she regularly volunteers at Drupal events.

fields.biography:
He has been a full time web developer since the mid-noughties, although launched his first commercial site in 2001.

Glenn enjoys traction kiting, BBQing, games and sport, including coaching a local youth football team.

Based in Bristol, Glenn is part of our new office's team.
fields.intro: Glenn hails from New Zealand, having lived in Australia and South Africa along the way, and has been living in the UK since 1994.

fields.biography:
A graduate of the American University of Bulgaria with a degree in Computer Science and Information Technology, Dan oversees the process of transforming ideas into reality and ensures their proper implementation. An avid bug hunter, optimizer and standards-lover, Dan likes to push his limits hard.

He has a long history of experiments with various technologies and a love-hate-turned-love relationship with Drupal. You can find him dabbling in Django and Wagtail projects, mapping and translations. 

Aside from computers, his passions include, but are not limited to: coffee, Lego, science fiction and knowledge sharing.
fields.intro: Dan is a noble <table>-fighter, knight of <div> and order from the picturesque country of Moldova.

fields.biography:
Nick graduated from Oxford University with a degree in Mathematics and Philosophy, and since then has managed to move an exotic 11 miles down the road to Witney.

He has a pilot's license, but his commercial flying career was doomed from the start when his interview invitation for BA's pilot training programme arrived on 11 September 2001. Instead he trained as a maths teacher and spent ten years working in Oxfordshire's comprehensive schools. Eventually teaching himself to code in order to make a pupil-tracking web application, Nick suddenly realised that he was enjoying this more than the day job, and so packed up his bags to head over to Torchbox.

He has previous lives as a moderately quick track cyclist, a moderately competitive photographer and a moderately decent trombone player. Now he is a moderately competent husband and father of two.

Anagrams of his name include Nicholas Smith, NicholaS smith and tmcaNisl hohSi.
fields.intro: Nick joined Torchbox in summer 2013 in a career-changing move from the secondary-school classroom

fields.biography: Tom has a BSc in biology, but he liked computers better so he got an MSc in them instead. He joined Torchbox as a Python Developer in 2014 after doing a bit of Java development. He likes free software, hard sci-fi and the countryside.
fields.intro: Tom is a developer from Oxford.

fields.biography:
Since joining Torchbox at its inception, Helen's work as a Senior Developer has marshalled important projects from concept and specifications through technical build and UAT to training and launch. Projects she's worked on recently include a monitoring, evaluation and project management tool for the Football Foundation, and a case management system from Pohwer, the advocacy service. 

Helen's skills lie in technical programming, database design, code optimisation, and working with clients to turn their requirements into technical specifications. She also has a keen interest in quality control. Outside work Helen has a strong interest in sustainable living and community building.
fields.intro: After gaining a DPhil in Astrophysics from St. John's College, Oxford, Helen spent several years as an academic researcher in theoretical and observational cosmology, gaining an international reputation.

fields.biography:
Born in San Francisco when his parents lived there for a while, Ru was bought back to the UK just quick enough not to remember any of the fantastic scenery or weather. He settled in the west country, via Hampshire and Reading, gaining a degree in Computer Science from the University of Bath along the way. He now lives in Bristol with his girlfriend, their daughter and their dog. Minnie the whippet can often be found creating her own brand of chaos in the Torchbox Bristol office.

When he's not doing things with computers, Ru likes riding bikes, taking pictures of things, taking things apart to see what's in them, drinking bourbon and combinations of these activities.
fields.intro: Ru likes making websites, always with open source software, and usually with Drupal.

fields.biography: Tom can also be found shutting down his Macbook and heading for the hills. Cycling, river swimming, drinking whiskey in the evenings and black coffee in the mornings.
fields.intro: Coming to Torchbox after almost a decade working on design, development and communications in the third-sector, Tom is an experienced digital all-rounder.

fields.biography: Specialises in designing and building large, bespoke web applications and providing users with intuitive interfaces to complex systems.
fields.intro: Senior Developer at Torchbox since 2001, a grey-haired member of the 'Torchbox Tenner Club'

fields.biography:
He began his career in academic publishing but 'went digital' when he moved to the University of Oxford and project managed the development and delivery of nearly 40 graduate and postgraduate online courses. Joining Oxfam GB in 2008, Ged cared for the Oxfam Education website and then spent 4 years managing Oxfam's digital campaigning in the UK. Before all that he studied English Literature as a graduate and Publishing as a postgraduate.

Ged's ideal day starts with a hearty breakfast and ends on the dancefloor; taking in a thick novel, a few hours of televised sport and an afternoon on the cricket pitch. Having DJ'd in and around Oxford for years, sunrise with friends has become his favourite thing to look forward to.
fields.intro: Ged joined Torchbox in January 2013 with a background in digital campaigning and project management.

fields.biography:
After graduating from the University of Bristol with a degree in English and Classics, Ellen started out in educational publishing, before moving into the arena of research dissemination. In her previous role she oversaw websites, print magazines and digital publications for a whole host of interesting European research projects. Since joining Torchbox, she has worked with CLIC Sargent, Nuffield Trust and WRAP, among others. 

In her spare time she is a passionate reader and consumer of TV series. She currently studies a part-time course in Theology, helps run a youth group and this year completed the Bristol Half Marathon for the first time.
fields.intro: Ellen joined Torchbox in 2014 with a background in publishing.

fields.biography:
As Client Services Director, Paul manages our Account Direction and Project Management teams, and helps ensure that we deliver a consistently high level of service.  

At KCL, Paul headed up a large R&D team designing and building complex custom web applications. As well as a deep understanding of the Higher Education sector, Paul brings extensive experience working as a consultant to, and collaborator with, many arts and cultural heritage organisations including Tate, the South Bank Centre and the Royal Opera House. He also ran his own digital agency for over ten years.  

When not working, Paul has been known to play the harp - but given that he is currently without a harp, this is a tricky pastime to maintain. Fortunately, he also likes to pretend he is Simon Hopkinson in the kitchen; and he is prone to become quite ill-tempered if unable to swim at least 12.5km a week.
fields.intro: Paul joined Torchbox in 2014 from a former life as a consultant and academic at King's College London's internationally renowned Department of Digital Humanities. That's where he met Wagtail.  Needless to say, it was love at first site.

fields.biography:
Rob joined Torchbox in December 2013. From a digital project management background, he effortlessly made the transition into the Digital Marketing Team, culminating in an individual able to deliver on-time and budget and reach out to engage new audiences.

Predominantly covering the social management for our Sports clients, he loves being creative and enjoys coming up with experimental ideas and putting them to the test.

Rob keeps abreast of the latest online marketing news and trends, but on a personal note: is a converted cat-lover, Tottenham Hotspur fan, and his favourite Pokémon is Scyther (the bug/flying type - terrible combo).
fields.intro: Rob is our social media crusader who loves overseeing engagement across our client communities.

fields.biography:
He is Google AdWords & Analytics certified and manages multiple Google Ad Grants, Google Analytics and Google Tag Manager accounts for our charity clients. Recent clients include Chatham House, Taylor & Francis, WRAP, Nuffield Trust and Global Witness. 

His favourite poet is Norman MacCaig, and his pen pal is the writer Graham Swift. In a previous life, he was a musician.
fields.intro: Phil joined Torchbox in October 2014. He works with clients to ensure they're getting the best out of their Google Ad Grants, SEO and Google Analytics accounts.

fields.biography: As well as looking after our invoicing, accounts and payroll and all that other essential stuff, Susan also makes sure we all have comfortable chairs and that the coffee, biscuits and fruit never run out. Susan is also a director of a logistics company with her husband. She loves walking and running, and is a former ultra long distance runner who once ran all the way from London to Brighton. She also enjoys sewing and gardening.
fields.intro: Susan is our Financial Manager and has been with Torchbox on and off since 2001.

fields.biography:
He has managed digital projects for The King's Fund, Greenpeace, ActionAid, International Committee of the Red Cross, WRAP, WWF, the RSA and more.

After four years as a Project Manager in our Oxfordshire HQ, Dave spent six months travelling and two years as Digital Manager at the UK's leading cycling and walking charity, Sustrans. 

He rejoined Torchbox in 2014 as Account Director. He loves to get close to our clients' objectives, developing strategies, and making sure that we're working together on projects that will have measurable impact.

Outside work he's a proud dad, keen cyclist, part-time runner, infrequent wild-swimmer, and beginner swing dancer.
fields.intro: Dave has been working for Torchbox since 2007.

fields.biography:
Swapping free crates of beer and a heightened sense of popularity, Jonny moved to Oxford on the promise of beautiful countryside, barbecues and ski slopes. So far so good. 

Joining a fledgling marketing team at the time, Jonny has worked across a range of disciplines - gaining experience in all areas of digital marketing.  He currently specialises in social media campaigns, strategy & advertising.  

Among his recent achievements, he lists helping to organise the first branded live Facebook Q&A in the UK, meeting Mr Motivator and getting David Hasselhoff to Tweet about Torchbox’s work.

Outside of work he’s a huge sport fan, social media junkie and has a habit of signing up to challenges that require death waivers.
fields.intro: Jonny joined Torchbox in April 2010 after previous experience in the digital marketing world of alcohol at Molson Coors.

fields.biography:
Matthew joined Torchbox straight out of uni in 2002 and immediately got involved in the development of Torchbox's original CMS, RationalMedia. Along the way he's gained extensive experience with the workings of content-managed websites, and most recently has headed the development of the open-source Wagtail CMS that powers many of Torchbox's latest sites.

He also has a keen interest in browser-side technologies, and has been exploring the possibilities of Javascript since before Google Maps and jQuery made it cool, creating rich data visualisations and mapping applications for the likes of WWF and ActionAid.

Outside of Torchbox, Matthew is actively involved in the demoscene - an international community of programmers and artists creating digital artworks - and regularly visits festivals across Europe presenting new code creations and live music performances. He is also currently on a long term mission to hike all of the UK's National Trails.
fields.intro: Matthew is the lead technical developer of the Wagtail CMS, and works on custom web application development, both server-side and front-end.

fields.biography:
After dropping out of high school at 17, Felicity joined the Wikimedia developer team in 2004, with a background in Unix but little experience of the real world.  She picked up her experience with scaling web sites 'on the fly', as Wikipedia grew from 7 servers to over 200 on a ridiculously small budget.

She joined Torchbox in 2012, where she's spent most of her time overhauling our hosting infrastructure, while fielding clients' technical questions, dealing with the typical unexpected problems that plague computers, and crawling under desks to fix the office wiring.

When not working, Felicity spends her time playing fiddle or sampling the latest beers at Charlbury's pubs (sometimes at the same time).
fields.intro: Felicity joined Torchbox in 2012 with a background in large-scale Unix web hosting.

fields.biography:
Following a degree in Philosophy and English Literature, Victoria was determined to work in the software industry and taught herself web design and animation in her free time.

Having gained the necessary skills – and reluctantly saying goodbye to scrolling marquee and animated gifs – she got her first big break as a web designer with the prestigious Singapore Press Holdings, before retraining as a web developer and moving to the UK to join Torchbox in 2004.

Initially working on RationalMedia CMS projects, Victoria switched to Drupal development in 2008, and has taken the lead developer role on projects for clients including The King's Fund, the University of Oxford (handing over to Dan Braghis when she went on maternity leave), and the Royal Agricultural University.

Victoria has contributed to various issues on Drupal.org, is the co-maintainer of Media Soundcloud, and in her free time – before becoming a mother – she enjoyed knitting, baking, and playing Go.
fields.intro: Victoria moved from Singapore to the UK in 2004 to join Torchbox, and has been working on Drupal projects since 2008.

fields.biography:
14 years of event management experience gave Paul the ability to see the big picture, and then zero in on the tiniest detail, providing the perfect foundation for the world of operations. 

Paul keeps a beady eye on all current and future resources, making sure we are able to deliver our client projects with utmost efficiency.

Outside of work, Paul likes to punish his body with things like squash and the occasional Tough Mudder event, as well as being Chief Entertainer to his two young daughters and trying to keep his garden in some sort of order.
fields.intro: After flexing his ops muscles at a previous digital agency, Paul joined Torchbox in March 2015.

fields.biography:
After graduating from Glasgow University with a BSc Hons in Software Engineering, Maya's intended year of travel turned into a more prolonged stint of working abroad, spending time working on the coral reefs of Western Australia and in the mountains of the French Alps. 5 years on it was time to return to the UK, joining another digital agency in Bristol as a Project Manager.

Maya's previous role saw her managing projects for various charities, non-for-profits and NGOs so the progression to Torchbox was obvious. Since joining Torchbox she has been working with Oxford University, The Future Leaders Trust as well as some exciting new projects!

In her spare time Maya pursues the activities of her time abroad, enjoying hill walking, diving (in the slightly colder waters of the UK!) and planning the next skiing adventure.
fields.intro: Maya joined Torchbox in early 2015.

fields.biography:
Since graduating in 2004 from University of Westminster, he has been building UI's for a range of designers and agencies looking to do something different on the internet and within native applications. Tying this into best practice development, adhering to standards and keeping an ear out for new techniques is what makes him happy when delivering projects.

During his career so far he has worked with some of the most passionate developers around the world at agencies such as AKQA and IRIS Digital, has evangelised best practice at Nokia in Berlin, and setup a beautiful co-op workspace in Wales.

Outside of work Toby enjoys annoying artisans with beginner questions, socialising, befriending cats, snow, Radio 4 and finding new electronic music.
fields.intro: Former contractor, Toby has found somewhere that implements the values he finds most important to him.

fields.biography:
He has worked on numerous Django and Wagtail projects, for clients including the Football Foundation, WRAP, the Royal College of Art, and many more.

In his spare time, Balazs enjoys cycling and swimming, and once made an attempt at skiing.
fields.intro: Balazs joined Torchbox's tech team in 2012 after studying economics in Budapest.

fields.biography:
During her career so far she has worked at several well respected Bristol-based web agencies, building on the web properties of clients both large and small. Most recently, she contributed to the principal website of EDF Energy.

Rose is a keen pianist and is currently working her way through selected pieces by one of her favourite contemporary composers, Einaudi.
fields.intro: Born and bred in Wales, Rose moved to Bristol to study at UWE. Since graduation, she has worked almost exclusively with Drupal to successfully deliver complex project briefs.

fields.biography:
He graduated at the University of Plymouth in 2003, then moved to Bristol, where he’s worked for several agencies including Mason Zimbler, Mubaloo and Flourish.

During his career, Adam has worked with a number of blue chip brands including Unilever, Microsoft and Samsung, as well as multiple charities, including NSPCC, Diabetes UK and RNIB.

Out of work, Adam enjoys going to music festivals, walking, swimming and brewing beer.
fields.intro: Adam joined Torchbox in May 2015, with 10 years’ digital agency experience.

fields.biography:
After studying French & German at the University of Leeds, Natalie stayed at the University in a marketing role, where she acquired a taste for digital and user experience. After moving to London, she joined the digital team at Cancer Research UK, where she was Product Owner for Race for Life and Shine Night Walk. 

Natalie swapped the brights lights of London for the rolling hills of Oxfordshire, and moved to Oxfam GB where she was part of the digital fundraising team. She worked with colleagues across fundraising and communications to drive income from digital channels.

In her spare time she can be found channeling her inner Mary Berry in the kitchen or jogging off the cakes and training for the Oxford Town & Gown 10k.
fields.intro: Natalie joined Torchbox in early 2016 with a background in digital fundraising.

fields.biography:
Alex is an avid contributor of open-source software, creator of free art and poetry, and a thinker of thoughts. He has been creating websites since 2008, at first through freelancing, and now with Torchbox in order to make a more positive impact on the world.

“A dream you dream alone is only a dream. A dream you dream together is reality.” ― John Lennon
fields.intro: Alex left Texas in 2016 to pioneer Torchbox in Philadelphia, USA.

fields.biography:
After earning a honours degree in Art History from the University of Plymouth, Robina indulged her passion for snowboarding working as an office manager for one of the UK’s top ski and snowboard magazines. Robina then put her university knowledge to good use and worked at leading auction house Christie’s, before moving to Oxfordshire and worked for several regional marketing agencies.

When she’s not in the office, she can be found teaching her bubbly five-year-old daughter how to speak Chinese, pounding the hilly trails around Charlbury in pursuit of a sub 50 minute 10K time and trying to convince her meat-loving husband to eat more veggies.
fields.intro: Robina joined Torchbox as an Administrative Assistant towards the end of 2015 with a background in administration, marketing and PR.

fields.biography:
Having studied Geological Sciences at Oxford Brookes University, Caroline decided not to return to her much loved Essex roots and white stilettos, but remained in West Oxfordshire to start a career in market research.

Five years later, and with Baby No. 1 on the way, she decided to swap her Account Manager position for becoming a stay-at-home mum, where she set up her own childminding business and solely cared for no less than forty children over the following eight years. More recently, with Child No.3 about to start full-time school, she spent a year studying web development, getting to grips with HTML, CSS and Python, ready to return to a world full of slightly older people once again.

Caroline is Google Adwords and Analytics certified and manages Google Ad Grants for our charity clients.

In any spare time she can find, she likes to set herself the odd challenge. In October 2015, she ran the Dublin Marathon and is now all set to take on a Half Iron Man in 2017. To relax, she enjoys playing the piano, smashing a tennis ball around a court, and acting all Princess-like with a little Pole Fitness.
fields.intro: Caroline joined Torchbox in early 2016, with a background in market research.

fields.biography:
A Computer Science graduate of Loughborough University, Joz has worked at several award-winning Drupal agencies in the UK. His experience includes high-traffic Drupal sites in the financial, education and healthcare sectors.

Joz has also helped develop the image compression algorithm for autostereoscopic 3D televisions (that's 3D content without the need for glasses).

Outside of work, Joz can usually be found playing on his Atari 2800 or enjoying a game of pool.
fields.intro: Joz joined Torchbox's Drupal development team in late 2015

fields.biography:
With a background primarily in marketing, Nathan also brings experience in design and account management to the team.

Managing social channels for sports clients – sport being his passion – Nathan delivers compelling and engaging content for their respective communities.

Away from the office, Nathan is an avid Bristol City fan, enjoys disco/funk music and any excuse to wear ridiculous outfits.
fields.intro: Nathan joined Torchbox's growing digital marketing team in late 2015.

fields.biography:
A self-confessed part-geek, Rich studied business and IT at university but quickly discovered he preferred IT, and building bits of the internet for the good guys in particular.

As a budding conservationist and part-time cat servant with a passion for learning, Rich is a founding-member of one embryonic local wildlife group and sits on the committee of another. When not helping make the world a better place at work, he can usually be found reading, searching for signs of elusive fauna in the Worcestershire countryside, walking over hills, and avoiding getting on his fiancée's horse.
fields.intro: Rich was born and raised in The Faithful City of Worcester, but likes Python and Django so much he joined Torchbox in Charlbury in 2015.

fields.biography:
A web developer since just after the dot-com bubble burst (so you can't pin that one on him), he's been using Drupal for longer than it's polite to ask. No monoglot, he's also very happy working with Python and Django, amongst others.

Hailing from Cardiff, Alex came to Torchbox's Bristol office the long way round, via Exeter and Brighton. He's a keen supporter of human rights causes, and likes to writes stories that, maybe, one day, he'll let other people read.
fields.intro: Alex enjoys working with people to help create what they need, not just what they ask for.

fields.biography:
Tom moved from freelance into a career in  higher education before joining Torchbox in 2015.

Away from the keyboard Tom gets out and about in Cornwall, walking, swimming, canoeing and cycling. He also enjoys tinkering with electronics and woodwork in his shed.
fields.intro: Originally an arts graduate, Tom has been a web developer since 2005, and has been involved with Drupal for much of that time.

fields.biography:
After four years away running his own design agency in the Lake District, Nick returned to Torchbox as a Senior Designer in 2016. Now based in our Bristol office, Nick's recent clients include the World Food Programme, the Royal College of Art, and Cranfield University.

Outside of work, Nick loves the outdoors – especially exploring the Lakes, Wales, and Cornwall to find the perfect spots to surf, hike and mountain bike.
fields.intro: Nick originally joined Torchbox in 2003 and lead the design of websites for clients including Greenpeace UK, Data.gov.uk, the University of Oxford, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, and Nuffield Trust (which won a BIMA award).

fields.biography:
After graduating from Rhodes University in South Africa with a degree in Fine Art, Ashley landed herself an internship in London and hasn’t looked back since.

Before joining Torchbox, Ashley worked for several award-winning digital agencies where she was responsible for managing all of their marketing efforts.

In search of a new challenge, Ashley swapped the bright lights of London for the friendly city of Bristol and is now in charge of building Torchbox’s profile and communicating the impact of our work.

When not at work, Ashley enjoys travelling, taking the dog for a walk, watching rugby, gardening and going out with friends.
fields.intro: Ashley joined Torchbox in April 2016 as our first dedicated Marketing Manager.

fields.biography:
No longer a practitioner, Anthony's still passionate as ever about UX and specifically user-centered design. 

Anthony founded his own digital agency in London in 2008, but eventually fled the bright city lights for the West Country in 2015 to work on International CRM strategy for a major FMCG brand. Finally finding his way to the Torchbox front door in 2016, he works across a broad range of Torchbox clients adding strategic thinking and senior client liaison to every project he's involved in.

Since circumnavigating more than half the globe on a 70ft monohull yacht Anthony now opts for a quieter and 'drier' life. His claim to fame is participating in the Rolex Sydney to Hobart race, although he's adamant he never wants to see the Bass Strait again.
fields.intro: Beginning his career in the record industry, Anthony started life as a designer, quickly turning to code in the early days of CSS.

fields.biography:
Graduating from Aston Business School in 2012 with a degree in Business & Management, Leanne started working for an international energy company. After completing their Graduate Scheme, living briefly in Sweden, Leanne returned to the UK to join their Renewable Energy Business, managing planning applications and public consultation for major wind farm projects across the UK & Europe.

Having joined Torchbox, Leanne now looks after Google Adwords accounts for our charity clients. She is Adwords and Analytics certified.

In her spare time, Leanne enjoys the great outdoors. She’s currently trying to overcome the hills of Oxfordshire on her bike, and in the summer, can frequently be found camping. She also enjoys teaching herself new things, and is currently trying to master Spanish.
fields.intro: Leanne joined Torchbox in June 2016, with a background in stakeholder and project management.

fields.descriptive_title: An exciting new player in open source content management
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "About Wagtail"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Wagtail is a powerful, well-featured content management system built on the popular and respected Django framework. Able to power sites of any size, it is particularly effective for medium to large sites with sophisticated content management requirements.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Wagtail is superfast compared to most CMSs. Built on Django, it is easy to extend and designed to be quick to implement, reducing cost and effort. The user experience and slick interface transforms content management from a chore to a pleasure.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/MQj2vI59sIo?t=1s"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Just weeks after its launch, Wagtail has a vibrant open source community growing behind it. You can\u00a0keep track of ongoing work in\u00a0our Github repo.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Sites launched on Wagtail include the\u00a0Royal College of Art, the UN Refugee Agency's\u00a0Refugee Project, the British Heart Foundation's\u00a0No Smoking Day\u00a0campaign,\u00a0the\u00a0University of South Wales, the King's Fund\u00a0Health and Social Care Election Tracker,\u00a0100 Shapes,\u00a0and many more.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Find out more\u00a0at\u00a0wagtail.io\u00a0and take a look at the video from our launch event above.

"}]
fields.summary: An exciting new player in open source content management.

fields.descriptive_title: A major research programme for Nuffield Trust and The Health Foundation
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The quality of health and social care has rarely had a higher profile and been more in need of independent scrutiny.\u00a0QualityWatch\u00a0is a major research programme from\u00a0Nuffield Trust\u00a0and\u00a0The Health Foundation, providing an authoritative independent resource, monitoring and commenting on how quality is changing over time, and highlighting how and where improvements can and should be made.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "QualityWatch homepage", "image": 1301, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What we did"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We created a responsive new site powered by Drupal 7, that helps them showcase data on nearly 150 healthcare indicators and provide in-depth analysis on a range of key topics. This site is truly an interesting piece 'of our time', reflecting on the state of the NHS in a period of austerity.\u00a0Crucial to the build was the ability to showcase complex data. Our indicators displayed data consistently and provided a high level of automation for updates.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "QualityWatch Indicators Page", "image": 1303, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The front-end is clean and easy to navigate, able to accommodate varying data formats juxtaposed with analysis. The back-end makes it relatively easy for research teams to bulk upload data without editorial burden.\u00a0Designed in the browser, the site demonstrates that content can look great and be made accessible no matter what device it's being viewed on.

"}]
fields.summary: A major research programme for Nuffield Trust and The Health Foundation

fields.descriptive_title: A major global redesign for WWF
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "UK Fundraising"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We completely redesigned WWF's online fundraising and animal adoption pages with the clear aim of generating more income. And it worked: membership, adoption and donation income doubled, and in 2010 the website came out on top in the Third Sector Excellence Awards.

Visit support.wwf.org.uk

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Global Redesign"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Since 2010 we've been working with WWF on a major global redesign, putting in place a coherent stylistic framework to govern the design of all WWF websites globally, while affording sufficient flexibility for country offices to retain their local flavour and promote local priorities.

Visit panda.org

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "WWF Footprint Calculator"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Originally produced for WWF UK in 2007, our Footprint Calculator was one of the first and remains the benchmark for accessibility and ease of use.

Visit WWF Footprint Calculator\u00a0

"}]
fields.summary: A major global redesign and UK fundraising transformation for our long-term partners WWF

fields.descriptive_title: A stunning redevelopment for the RCA
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were pretty chuffed to be appointed by the\u00a0Royal College of Art\u00a0(RCA)\u00a0to oversee their website redevelopment. They wanted to reflect the vibrant life of their pre-eminent school and the site needed to be valuable resource for internal staff and students, as well as a visually striking outward-facing platform to promote their inspiring work.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal College of Art homepage", "image": 1254, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Discovery"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After analysis and trials of existing platforms, in partnership with the RCA, we found that nothing out there was quite the right match for what we needed. So we took the rather exciting decision to develop our own open source content management system,\u00a0Wagtail. Innovative, creative and functional, Wagtail ended up being the perfect fit for the project.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Visual design was provided by\u00a0Neville Brody\u2019s\u00a0Research Studios\u00a0and we carried out UX design and front end development.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Torchbox have provided an excellent service to the Royal College of Art. Over the three years we've worked with them, they have provided UX services, built and developed a brand new application for our main website and CMS (launched as the open-source Wagtail), maintained our ongoing website development, trained staff, built a standalone site for our most prominent fundraising project, and are currently building a new application for our intranet.\"", "attribution": "Octavia Reeve, Senior Publishing Manager, Royal College of Art"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Content Strategy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Collaboration was key to content strategy.\u00a0Programme pages such as the\u00a0School of Architecture\u00a0showcase news and features alongside staff profiles and resources to encourage cross-programme fertilisation. Students can even use the Wagtail CMS to submit their own blog posts for moderation.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal College of Art School of Architecture page", "image": 1255, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The project culminated in a full series of wireframes for desktop, tablet and mobile.\u00a0We elected to use 'push state' to dynamically load pages within pages. News content opens in a lightbox that does not navigate the user away from the page and retains the context of the visit, using\u00a0pjax\u00a0to create\u00a0page urls.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Torchbox are helpful, efficient, approachable, have excellent project-management practices, and provide creative solutions to complex communication problems.\"", "attribution": "Octavia Reeve, Senior Publishing Manager, Royal College of Art"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Wagtail has since been released as a powerful, flexible, and highly performant CMS.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "http://vimeo.com/86719782"}]
fields.summary: A stunning redevelopment for the RCA

fields.descriptive_title: A site fit for the University of Oxford
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Seven years after our original redevelopment of\u00a0www.ox.ac.uk\u00a0in RationalMedia, the University of Oxford commissioned us to take another look at their site and\u00a0rebuild it in Drupal. They wanted a fresh and responsive design that could handle heavy traffic (over 40,000 unique visits a day) and, most importantly, a site to reflect their global standing as a centre of excellence.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

An ambitious task - but luckily, we love a challenge. We\u2019re long-term partners with Oxford and quite frankly we were thrilled to have a second opportunity to build their site from the ground up.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "University of Oxford homepage", "image": 1248, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Their website is used by everyone from top level staff to prospective students, and for a university like Oxford that means there are a lot of stakeholders. To give us focus, we took a principle-driven approach and honed our objectives down to a key set of eight. These digital principles acted as a touchstone for design and build. Read more about this in Olly\u2019s\u00a0blog post\u00a0on the subject.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Strategy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To check the pulse of what staff and students wanted, we spent time defining user needs and captured them using a tool developed by gov.uk, the\u00a0Needotron.\u00a0Then, once we\u2019d designed our first responsive prototypes, we carried out user testing to make sure we\u2019d hit the mark by delivering on the key needs for each audience type.\u00a0

Oxford is a world-leading research institution, and though dynamic news can take precedence, the emotional response user testing suggested a desire for student interests to have more prominence. The testing also confirmed we\u2019d got the tone of the design right - \u2018clean\u2019 and \u2018fresh\u2019 were the words that came up most often.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "University of Oxford's New Students page", "image": 1247, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One of our first design principles was that the site provide \u2018a window\u2019 into university life. Full width images or videos on almost every page of the site ensure this. And, while the navigation is tested to deliver on user needs/tasks, the homepage and landing pages can concentrate on showcasing what's going on at the university.\u00a0

Some vital parts of the site (e.g. graduate admissions) had to be phased in, so we planned four separate content launches and used our tried and trusted feature-driven development process to keep things flexible.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "University of Oxford's Undergraduate Admissions page", "image": 1249, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Result"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Needless to say, we\u2019re immensely proud of the result - a responsive, professional and stylish site worthy of a top global university.

"}]
fields.summary: Designing and building a responsive site for the University of Oxford

fields.descriptive_title: Three custom web applications for the Football Foundation
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Grantshot"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Grantshot is an internal\u00a0piece of software we built to help the Football Foundation manage their grant process. A custom Django application, Grantshot integrates with the third-party system\u00a0AchieveForms\u00a0and acts a dashboard to manage and review ongoing grant applications. We made sure the interface provided a great user experience while simplifying the process for organisations who handle grants and money bursaries.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Grantshot homepage", "image": 1286, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Over the last seven years I have worked with a number of different staff at Torchbox and have found them all to be thoroughly professional and personable individuals who genuinely care about their clients' success.\u201d", "attribution": "Duncan Jones, Head of Operations, Football Foundation"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Upshot"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Upshot is our ongoing development of an enterprise-scale monitoring and evaluation system we built to enable the Football Foundation to analyse and report on the impact of their grant-giving on local communities. Upshot allows a club to design a programme of events, track information about participants in those events and monitor the results.\u00a0

For example, you might run a series of national fitness events over ten weeks. Upshot would allow you to log information about participants, including details such as BMI and fitness levels. You could then set evaluation targets and goals for the programme, such as sport uptake after the programme close.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "http://vimeo.com/22396410"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We put together a sequence of user-friendly dashboards that captures data and analysis against these targets in an accessible, friendly format.\u00a0Custom mapping and built-in reporting logs information from across the country, enabling an organisation to measure the impact of their programmes in a meaningful and valuable way.\u00a0

We think Upshot lends itself to a variety of community projects and scenarios.\u00a0Find out more, or watch our short animation above about how your organisation or project could benefit from using Upshot.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cTorchbox do all they can to help, no matter what the request, and demonstrate a fantastic degree of flexibility. Their developers take immense pride in the quality of their work and are extremely thorough in their analysis and implementation - minor inaccuracies are extremely rare and always rectified very speedily.\u201d", "attribution": "Duncan Jones, Head of Operations, Football Foundation"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Pitchfinder"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Pitchfinder is the biggest and most complete\u00a0database of football pitches available around the country. Over 48,000 pitches are currently logged and the site allows visitors from all over to propose new pitches. Pitchfinder can even be embedded easily within a site.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Pitchfinder website", "image": 1287, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cTorchbox are open and honest about the time invested in their work and display a high degree of integrity and flexibility with billing. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend the organisation or its staff.\"", "attribution": "Duncan Jones, Head of Operations, Football Foundation"}}]
fields.summary: Three innovative custom web applications for long-term partners the Football Foundation: Grantshot, Upshot and Pitchfinder.

fields.descriptive_title: A full-scale site redevelopment for CLIC Sargent
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

CLIC Sargent were looking to redevelop their existing site and make the most of digital in the pursuit of their organisational objectives.\u00a0Starting with user surveys, interviews, personas and stakeholder workshops to understand the audience of the site, we developed a fresh new design concept in line with their existing branding.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Clic Sargent homepage", "image": 1283, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What we did"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We used our feature-driven development process to build the site. This provided consultation, training and documentation throughout the project helping CLIC Sargent understand and get the most from their investment.

One of our achievements was the creation of an information architecture that could showcase exciting news and events while also allowing visitors to navigate the depth of content available to cancer sufferers and their families. This content structure was the result of a rigorous discovery process, using tools such as Card Sorting to accommodate different user journeys.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Clic Sargent's fundraising & events page", "image": 1285, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We delivered the site on Drupal 7\u00a0with integration to their existing CRM (CARE) and a Shopify instance, styled to resemble the main site.\u00a0Integration with third-parties is achieved through separate loosely-coupled interfaces. This means CLIC Sargent can replace integrated systems such as CRM, e-commerce, event management and recruitment quickly and easily without interrupting the user experience.

The site uses a responsive design to look great on mobile, tablet or desktop.

"}]
fields.summary: A full-scale site redevelopment for CLIC Sargent

fields.descriptive_title: A suite of Drupal sites for long-term partners WRAP
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019ve worked with the Waste and Resources Action Programme (WRAP) since 2004. We redeveloped the UK-wide site\u00a0wrap.org.uk\u00a0in Drupal. This single Drupal instance also underpins the various national waste and resources sites:\u00a0Zero Waste Scotland,\u00a0WRAP Cymru\u00a0and\u00a0WRAP Northern Ireland.\u00a0Our work has spanned many projects\u00a0including their primary website and the\u00a0Love Food Hate Waste\u00a0and\u00a0Recycle Now\u00a0consumer campaigns.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Recycle Now"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Recycle Now\u00a0is the national recycling campaign for England, supported and funded by Government, managed by WRAP and used locally by over 90% of English authorities. We developed a fresh, intuitive Drupal site that enables visitors to search for recycling outlets, read about the latest recycling tips and methods and engage with the crucial work Recycle Now is carrying out.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Recycle Now homepage", "image": 1295, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Love Food Hate Waste"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Torchbox have been closely involved in the\u00a0Love Food Hate Waste\u00a0campaign since its inception in 2007. During this time we worked with WRAP to deliver both the main Love Food Hate Waste website along with animations, competitions and portion planning tools.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Love Food Hate Waste homepage", "image": 1296, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Beginning with the design and Drupal build, our work on Love Food Hate Waste has since included producing animations and infographics to help promote awareness about reducing food waste. We\u2019ve also carried out search engine optimisation work on the site to ensure that its message \u2013 and extensive database of delicious recipes \u2013 reaches as many people as possible.

"}]
fields.summary: A suite of Drupal sites for long-term partners WRAP

fields.descriptive_title: A complex Drupal build for Chatham House
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Chatham House engages governments, the private sector and civil society in open debate and confidential discussion on the most significant developments in international affairs.\u00a0We were delighted to be commissioned to redevelop the Chatham House website as a platform for\u00a0independent and rigorous analysis of critical global, regional and country-specific challenges.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Chatham House homepage", "image": 1251, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Build"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We carried out the build on Drupal 7 using our existing framework for speed and performance. Major data migration was required to form a\u00a0huge body of content (10,000+ nodes). The depth of the site presented an interesting challenge for navigation and information architecture. We worked closely with the Chatham team to design and implement a structure that served the complex needs of the organisation while maintaining a sleek and usable interface.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A particular achievement was our custom development on events functionality. We applied a views-based approach to run queries and filter events according to the various criteria of potential audiences (members, membership type, etc.). This custom development seamlessly integrated with the existing third-party membership database, EBMS.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Chatham House events page", "image": 1252, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One of the most enjoyable parts of the project was working with the Chatham House team. We achieved a collaborative, fluid approach that allowed us to think creatively and problem-solve setbacks. The result is a site that can comfortably and competently appeal to its primary audience of decision-makers and political influencers.

"}]
fields.summary: A complex Drupal build for Chatham House

fields.descriptive_title: Do you see what I see?
fields.intro:
A glimpse into the lives of refugee children through a stunning website built on our Wagtail CMS

Visit Do You See What I See?
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Photojournalist Brendan Bannon embarked on a writing and photography project with refugee children in Yemen and Namibia. Through a series of workshops, he taught young refugees how to frame the world from their unique perspective using a camera and to write about their images.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Called \u201cDo You See What I See?\u201d, the project resulted in a photo essay seen by over 100,000 people on UNHCR\u2019s Flickr site and physical exhibitions in Yemen, Namibia, Italy, Geneva and New York.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What we did"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

UNHCR commissioned us to build a website to showcase a new iteration of the project that saw Bannon encountering\u00a0children who have fled the war in Syria and sought\u00a0refuge\u00a0in Jordan and Lebanon. UNHCR provided the designs, and we built and powered the site with our Wagtail Django CMS.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "UNHCR homepage", "image": 1518, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The site makes strong use of social media and\u00a0share\u00a0functionality, allowing visitors to easily share individual pieces of content. A particular achievement was the multi-language functionality; the site is available in Arabic as well as English, which presented an interesting challenge for readability.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Result"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The result is a visually striking and sophisticated site that lends itself to the hugely important and emotionally gripping content. Do you see what they see?

"}]
fields.summary: A glimpse into the lives of refugee children through a stunning website built on our Wagtail CMS

fields.descriptive_title: A Wagtail-powered site for the Royal Drawing School
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Overview"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Royal Drawing School is a cool, inspirational place (it's got us drawing more\u00a0and encouraging our families to draw as well).\u00a0We wanted to do justice to this fantastic institution without resorting to flashiness, and I think we\u2019ve achieved that.\u00a0

The site mixes quiet restraint with splashes of bold colour, and showcases thousands of stunning drawings alongside the profiles of hundreds of staff, students and alumni. And, it\u00a0builds successfully on the lovely, new branding work by\u00a0John Morgan Studio\u00a0with its distinctive, custom version of Monokrom's Vinter typeface.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal Drawing School homepage", "image": 1230, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Bringing the art experience to life"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Best of all, however, it brings the experience of the school and the opportunities it offers to life and makes it easy to join in. Whether it be the one year drawing master\u2019s, one of the many\u00a0public courses offered at five studios around London (and out and about:\u00a0Drawing at the National Gallery\u00a0next week, anyone?), or the programmes for children, it\u2019s now much easier to find what you want\u00a0- whatever device you access the site on (obviously).

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal Drawing School Public Courses page", "image": 1231, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We very much wanted to work with the school and were very happy to have won through the pitch process (in no small part thanks to our experience and work with the\u00a0Royal College of Art). We're very proud of what we have delivered.

"}]
fields.summary: A Wagtail-powered site for the re-branded Royal Drawing School

fields.descriptive_title: Redesigning Bath & North East Somerset Council's websites
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Racking up close to a million visitors every year, The Roman Baths is easily one of the most popular tourist attractions in the South West. The nearby Fashion Museum has similar standing as one of the foremost in the world, housing a rare collection of Georgian costumes and featuring the \u2018dress of the year'. Not many people know both venues are both governed by the Bath & North East Somerset Council Heritage Services (BANES).

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "The Roman Baths' homepage", "image": 1219, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Objectives"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our brief was to design a set of sites for the BANES venues, each with a compelling and distinct digital presence that remained part of a clear family.\u00a0BANES were keen to promote their connection with the tourist hotspots of their beloved city.\u00a0Other less well-known venues would be promoted alongside more popular ones, such as the Roman Baths.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Strategy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One of our first concepts was the \u2018site picker\u2019 - featuring a strip of site logos that lets the user choose their desired venue. Once selected, each site changes in colour and content while retaining the same layout. Design-wise, we wanted to convey a sense of place, incorporating the wonderful imagery on offer. Our hope was to inspire potential visitors as well as give them everything they needed to plan their visit.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Site picker", "image": 1222, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We carried out user testing on actual visitors we managed to collar in the queue for the Roman Baths and asked them to complete a series of tasks while we recorded audio, video and mouse movement - turns out plug sockets are a little hard to access in Victorian wood-panelled meeting rooms...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Feedback suggested that we needed to give even greater prominence to our \u2018site picker\u2019, so we worked on getting the wording exactly right, checking in with\u00a0our Google expert\u00a0who recommended\u00a0Other things to do\u00a0as the key phrase for those searching online.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Result"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The result: an elegantly designed family of sites to suitably promote Bath\u2019s cultural treasures.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "The Roman Baths' Shop and Eat page", "image": 1223, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}]
fields.summary: Redesigning Bath & North East Somerset Council's visitor attraction websites

fields.descriptive_title: A full redevelopment on Wagtail for an ambitious health charity
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Meningitis Now came to us as an ambitious health charity that punches hard for their weight.\u00a0They recognised that they needed to totally overhaul their digital offering and got boldly on board with Wagtail; specifying a sophisticated, extensible CRM integration (we built the Salesforce integration onto Wagtail), and took a clear focus on mobile.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Meningitis Now homepage", "image": 1257, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The previous site was somewhat overwhelming, particularly the navigation. It didn\u2019t serve the standard use cases as well as it might. And, it didn\u2019t work well on mobile. The bounce rate and single session levels were very high because the most common use case is people checking signs and symptoms of meningitis in a potential emergency.

"}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Our UX process"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In consultation with internal staff and users (including being invited to the House of Commons to meet some of their key supporters over tea and french fancies), we employed our user modelling process to quickly identify personas, needs, and user journeys.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our process is about delivering on user needs and organisational objectives, so we identified the actions that we wanted people to complete, creating a Wagtail snippet for each. Editors are now able to add the most context relevant call to action at the end of any page.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Call to action from Meningitis Now's website", "image": 1259, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And stories of people are placed at the heart of the experience, we use these as an additional way to expose the fantastic services that the charity offers to support people who have had or are experiencing meningitis.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Selection of stories featured on Meningitis Now's website", "image": 1260, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Design philosophy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We set out to to deliver a strong brand experience but without allowing the brand to overwhelm the content. And the site achieves this. The\u00a0design is particularly strong on mobile as befits a site where 75% of the visits are now on mobile!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The site immediately looks uncluttered and straightforward, which is what you need, especially if you are faced with the terrifying prospect of needing to confirm the symptoms of meningitis. The navigation has been hugely reduced and simplified, as has the number of items visible at any one time.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Meningitis Now's signs and symptoms page", "image": 1261, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Integration"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In parallel to the website redevelopment, Meningitis Now were also introducing a new Salesforce CRM with which the site integrates. Though not our first time integrating Salesforce, this was the first time we have integrated it with Wagtail. We specified, built and delivered a Wagtail integration that captures, backs up and posts to Salesforce all submissions made through Wagtail. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Wagtail is fast and simple for teams to create stunning websites. The interface is intuitive and the language used means non-technical people can use it with ease. You can even edit from your mobile in emergencies.\"", "attribution": "Richard Hudson Director of Digital & Marketing"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Using Wagtail's Formbuilder we delivered a flexible form creation system that allows Meningitis Now to create any kind of form and capture any kind of data request (e.g. contact information, support request, multiple choice questions, etc.) into Salesforce. It offers a robust and scalable approach to Salesforce CRM integration.

"}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Review"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

While the single visit rate and bounce rate are still high as you would expect, the site now has:

  • 50% more repeat visitors than this time last year.\u2028
  • Mobile usage up to almost 75% against a national average of 30%, and this is driving significant growth in traffic.\u2028
  • Organic search referrals up 58% and in the last two months page views are up almost 40% on last year.\u2028

And people are completing more actions on the site too.\u2028\u00a0We are proud of a focused and effective site and have enjoyed every moment of working with Meningitis Now.

"}]
fields.summary: A full redevelopment on Wagtail for an ambitious health charity that punches well above its weight

fields.descriptive_title: A new Wagtail website for Global Witness
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When fellow agency, Mark Boulton Design (MBD) were acquired by Monotype, Global Witness, were in the early stages of working with them on their site redevelopment. They were forced to go looking for a new digital agency. Happily, they chose Torchbox.

That suited us. Global Witness are a fantastic organisation. They do undercover, investigative journalism into some of the dodgiest companies and regimes in the world. And they campaign to change the system and to lift the resource curse that condemns millions of people to lives of poverty and violence. Just the sort of thing that we want to help with.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Witness homepage", "image": 1244, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Discovery"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

First stop, finish the discovery. We built on the MBD audience research by running a user modelling workshop where we:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Broke down the audiences into seventeen types (including groups from developing countries who weren\u2019t really represented in the three crystallised personas)\u00a0
  • Developed quick personas for each audience type\u00a0
  • Identified triggers and contexts for visits for each quick persona\u00a0
  • Identified needs for each persona\u00a0
  • Mapped the possible actions that each persona might want to complete on that visit [this connects the user objectives with an organisations objectives].\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Armed with what we had learnt from this session, we could ground our creative ideas in the real needs of the audiences and it helped Global Witness\u00a0to believe in the process. Further sessions on digital principles, objectives, creative positioning and scoping followed.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Torchbox delivered on a demanding and wide-ranging brief, which included the need to improve our storytelling abilities at the same time as migrate a huge archive of complex and varied material across from our old site.\"", "attribution": "Oliver Courtney, Senior Campaigns and Communications Advisor, Global Witness"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Design"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Gradually, we honed a vision for the site:

  • It needed to grab you, particularly the non-specialist audiences. It had to be more like an online magazine than an academic research repository.
