  • We didn\u2019t want to hide the fact that there is loads of depth to the content, so we needed a sense of layering of content: easy to absorb stuff first with quick access to the detail and archives
  • The current, key campaigns had to real stand out, setting the current agenda\u00a0
  • We needed to extend visit length
  • While they started using Shorthand on our recommendation to bring their stories to life, we wanted to be able to make great report pages without needing to use Shorthand.
  • Previously they had often built report and campaign pages as static micro-sites, as their main site wasn't flexible enough. We wanted to give them the flexibility and creative power within the CMS so that they didn't have to create additional static sites.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Our new website is a central part of our plans for the future, and we are very pleased with its performance so far. Throughout the process Torchbox have been highly professional and enjoyable to work with, and they know their area inside out. We would recommend them highly.\u201d", "attribution": "Oliver Courtney, Senior Campaigns and Communications Advisor, Global Witness"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The result is a revitalised, smart, engaging site. The incredible content shines through, and it keeps on coming. And the whole site, is enhanced by some neat interaction design.\u00a0One month after launch we achieved a\u00a0230% increase in users\u00a0of the website, a\u00a050% increase in time\u00a0on site, a\u00a012% decrease in bounce rate, and a\u00a0fourfold increase in click throughs\u00a0via organic Google searches.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Witness' Conflict Diamonds campaign page", "image": 1246, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here are a few stand out elements of what we have done:

  • The new CMS, Wagtail is the engine behind the site.
  • The striking, \u2018drop-up\u2019 navigation emphasises the priority projects.
  • Alongside the promoted content on each subject area, users can use the scrolling left column to dive into the complete archive of content on that subject from detailed reports and press releases selected tweets.
  • Self-retracting menus leave maximum space for dramatic, full screen presentation of the stories
  • Wagtail\u2019s Streamfield allows for dramatic and flexible storytelling
  • Security has had to be a focus - something that\u2019s already been tested by a number of hacking attempts, presumably by people who don\u2019t like what Global Witness are saying about them.

"}]
fields.summary: A new Wagtail website for Global Witness

fields.descriptive_title: A user-focused Wagtail website for the UK's grocery industry charity
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

GroceryAid provides help to people working in the grocery industry, looking after thousands of people with financial support, grants, free help and advice and a 24/7 helpline. The charity also runs many successful fundraising events around the UK \u2013 balls, sporting events, team challenges, and more.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

GroceryAid appointed us to rehaul their ageing website with a new responsive design built on the open source CMS Wagtail, integrated with their Oracle-based helpline system and Blackbaud event booking.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "GroceryAid homepage", "image": 1279, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Balancing user needs"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are very different groups of users: from people in desperate situations seeking support, to people looking to attend a lavish ball.\u00a0The existing website didn't cater well to the key use cases, with a sitemap that had grown over time and unclear routes through content. Neither did it clearly explain what GroceryAid does.

Our discovery process, including a user modelling workshop, helped to create a clear route through the site for the different groups of users, guiding them to take action.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Torchbox managed a tricky brief, to work with existing databases and processes whilst improving the user experience and giving it \u2018wow\u2019 factor. Through their meticulous planning and execution we now have a website that looks a million times better than before and have already seen an increase in visits to previously unnoticed information.\"", "attribution": "Jenny Fryatt, Communications Manager, GroceryAid"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Increasing engagement with calls-to-action"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The site features a reusable snippet\u00a0allowing editors to create a library of \"actions\" that can be added in relevant contexts around the site \u2013 so on the bottom of pages about applying for help, there's a prominent \"Contact the helpline\" action. Or on event pages, we're pointing visitors toward contacting the events team to sponsor fundraising events.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "GroceryAid call to action", "image": 1274, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Integration and collaboration"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The GroceryAid Helpline is an Oracle-based CRM, so we worked closely with the helpline developers to make sure there are seamless transitions between the two systems:

  • a unified site search that lists both Wagtail and helpline content
  • a realtime header and footer to \"wrap\" around the helpline content
  • Google Tag Manager containers to track users between the domains

The integration means that GroceryAid editors can easily reference content from the helpline within Wagtail.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "GroceryAid's regional branches page", "image": 1278, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're really proud of the collaboration with GroceryAid on bringing a user-focussed approach to their digital work.\u00a0A few weeks on, and the results are starting to show:

  • Bounce rate down from 45% to 35%
  • Average visit duration up from 2:40 to 3:15
  • Average pages per session up from 3.4 to 4.4

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"We have thoroughly enjoyed our working relationship with Torchbox. Our new website is a testimony to their design talents and we have had so much positive feedback.\"", "attribution": "Cathy Mercer, Welfare Development Director, GroceryAid"}}]
fields.summary: A user-focused Wagtail website for the UK's grocery industry charity

fields.descriptive_title: Bringing grant-making impact to life with stories and data visualisation
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were really excited to design and build the Wagtail-powered website for the Children\u2019s Investment Fund Foundation (CIFF).\u00a0The new website is a key element in CIFF\u2019s drive for greater transparency in grant making, and to share what they and their partners are learning.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "CIFF homepage", "image": 1269, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Demystifying the data"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The centrepiece is the\u00a0grant portfolio, an interactive visualisation of live grant data. It allows site visitors to browse grants via a dynamic set of bar charts representing grants by priority area, topic, and region \u2013 and then access the full detail about any particular grant.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This live view across themes and geographies \u2013 previously unavailable, even to CIFF staff \u2013 is a really clear way to visualise the very large numbers involved. We focussed on keeping the interface simple and responsive across all devices from desktop to mobile.\u00a0Of course, there\u2019s a standard filterable listing available if you want to be more selective (want to see\u00a0nutrition grants in Africa?\u00a0Education grants in South Asia?)

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "CIFF grant portfolio", "image": 1268, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The site is also one of the first outings for Wagtail\u2019s\u00a0StreamField feature.\u00a0StreamField is used on the \u201cinsight\u201d pages to give a rich, flexible content layout for CIFF\u2019s editors to tell the story of what they\u2019re learning from key programmes, and bring the data to life.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Without measurement we are guessing"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As with the majority of our projects we\u2019re using Google Analytics \u2013 in this case, to report on how people are using the grant portfolio and on the range of on-site conversions such as signing up to email, viewing key pages and documents, sharing content or following key staff on social media.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After launch, sessions were up by\u00a050%, bounce rate down by\u00a07%, and average duration up\u00a015%\u00a0- a more engaged audience, with increased conversion rate for all goals.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With a client so focussed on data and evidence for their grantmaking work, it goes without saying that we'll be using the analytics to continue to enhance the site over time.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "We wanted a flexible and intuitive content management system\u2026 a simple yet sophisticated site which champions the use of data and evidence\u2026 an adaptable tool to help us embrace transparency in everything we do. Using Wagtail, the Torchbox team has helped design and build an exciting platform which has the potential to help us achieve all of these goals.", "attribution": "James Whittington, Director of Communications, CIFF"}}]
fields.summary: Bringing grant-making impact to life with stories and data visualisation

fields.descriptive_title: SMS support for Kenyan farmers
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Project iShamba: delivering crop prices for local markets, agronomy tips, and weather forecasts to Kenyan farmers with SMS.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mediae is a trusted source of agricultural information in Kenya and the organisation behind hit television series Shamba Shape Up \u2013 a programme helping smallholder farmers improve pest management, irrigation, cattle rearing and crop management techniques.

Approximately 75% of Kenya\u2019s working population are smallholders, many with limited or zero access to the internet. But what they do have is SMS.

Access to additional information beyond the TV programme could enable many farmers to be more productive and ultimately raise their family income. \u00a0\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Smallholder farmers using iShamba", "image": 516, "attribution": "Photo credit: Media", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "iShamba objectives"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Help people make the most of their smallholdings by disseminating important agricultural information via SMS and a call centre service
  • Operate a sustainable social business model

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Solution"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We helped set up two channels to disseminate agricultural information:

  • An opt-in SMS service which sends out tailored information to subscribers based upon a personal profile
  • A call centre with a huge database of agricultural information to provide answers to more complex questions

Both have different service levels and are available as a freemium or premium subscription. iShamba also drives extra revenue by collaborating with local business partners, providing subscribers with vouchers for agricultural supplies.

"}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Data quality"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The information provided to subscribers via SMS and through the call centre is sourced from a variety of places, so a lot of work has to been done to ensure the quality of data remains high. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

See our blog post 'iShamba: Revolutionising Farming in Kenya'

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=72&v=NkdNjmadIcQ"}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Open data"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Contingency plans have been built in for many different scenarios, such as always being able to access third party data when needed, to answer timely questions about the weather or market prices.

"}, {"type": "h3", "value": "Customer data"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Many small farms share phones, so we had to be cleverer than using just a telephone number to identify the account and provide tailored information.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Less than a year after launch iShamba has:

  • Over 8,000 subscribers and is well on target for achieving self-sustainability
  • Been shortlisted for three awards Mobile Innovations Awards (2015)
  • Received a special write-up in the\u00a0Guardian
"}]
fields.summary: iShamba: helping Kenyan smallholder farmers with access to vital data via SMS

fields.descriptive_title: A research-driven UX project
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Breast Cancer Care\u00a0is a much-loved and trusted\u00a0UK charity which aims to\u00a0support anyone affected by breast cancer. Thousands of people have\u00a0benefited\u00a0from the\u00a0extensive help they are able to provide\u00a0- ranging from locally run events\u00a0to help women deal with the realities of treatment and recovery, to a vast library of\u00a0professionally\u00a0authored medical reference material. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At the\u00a0same time though\u00a0the\u00a0sheer\u00a0breadth of services and support on offer presented some major challenges\u00a0for Breast Cancer Care\u2019s digital presence. Their website had become stretched to the limit by the need to serve a broad and diverse constituency of users, who needed to understand what was on offer, and be guided to the most appropriate content. No less important was ensuring that the website did more to bolster fundraising - it's\u00a0an understandable,\u00a0but common misconception that Breast Cancer Care\u00a0receives NHS funding.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "User Experience"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With any user experience\u00a0project,\u00a0the key to a successful outcome is thorough research - and the biggest enemy can be uncritically accepted assumptions.\u00a0We designed a process\u00a0that first helped BCC gain clarity over their own needs before we went on to\u00a0conduct user needs\u00a0analysis.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We synthesised the outcomes of our research work into 20 easily digestible insights, against each of which we suggested specific actions. \u00a0For example, we\u2019d learned not only that 50% of users were consulting the (non-responsive) site on a mobile device but also that most of them weren\u2019t actually doing so \u2018on the move\u2019\u00a0- and so we adopted a strategy of making the site \u2018content first\u2019 rather than \u2018mobile first\u2019.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Simplifying the information architecture allowed for a clear emphasis on information and resources, local support, and fundraising activities, and we fine-tuned the structure and language of the sitemap over five rounds of testing with Treejack.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Finally,\u00a0we turned theory into practice, combining research insight and IA and creating (and then iterating upon) a large set of 20 interactive wireframes, which we honed after extensive lab testing with service users. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The end result is a comprehensive pack of tried and tested UX deliverables which has allowed BCC to hit the ground running on their website build with the confidence that they both understand users' needs and concerns, and know how to deliver content to them effectively.

"}]
fields.summary: A comprehensive research-driven user experience project for Breast Cancer Care, delivering important insights and a great foundation for their website redevelopment.

fields.descriptive_title: Bringing the RAU experience to life
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

On the tree-lined driveway to the Royal Agricultural University, it is clear why the RAU prides itself on its history and heritage. A leader in agricultural education since 1845, its tradition and reputation should be celebrated, but there is more to this university. This is a modern university at the cutting edge of land-based industries. \u201cForward thinking & traditional\u201d was the first principle for the redevelopment of the RAU\u2019s website.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Clarity & simplicity"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

By simplifying the information architecture we have concentrated the site on the key areas of information, with University life being promoted to this top level and the design approach clearing the way for a focus on content.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal Agricultural University homepage", "image": 1298, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Promoting the \u201cRAU experience\u201d"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In user workshops it became apparent that studying at the RAU is a unique experience. \u201cHomely\u201d, \u201ccommunity\u201d, \u201cfriendly\u201d, \u201cdiversity\u201d were a few words that came up again and again. It was clear that the rural setting of this University, the facilities offered and the way of life made the RAU stand out.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Promoting the RAU experience", "image": 1242, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We have brought these unique aspects of the RAU experience to life, answering the key question \u201cwhat is it like to be a student at the RAU?\u201d. Using testimonial blocks throughout the site, the site is instantly humanised: real students telling real life stories about their experience at the university.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Focus on the most important users and task completion"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Making it easy for users to find the information they want was key to the success of the new website. Teaser components and strong calls to action were created and encouraged to be used throughout the site, guiding the user through the site, whether that be through actions intended to be taken, or to other pages that are likely to be of interest.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal Agricultural University's undergraduate page", "image": 1243, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "This is the beginning, not the end"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The launch of the RAU\u2019s website is an achievement we are really proud of and it is already holding its own and performing well. But this is not the end of the journey. We look forward to continuing our partnership with Jess and the team, enhancing the website and working on future projects.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"The Royal Agricultural University required a brand new website, to effectively compete in the global higher education market. We wanted a responsive, easy to navigate, beautifully designed website, with the opportunity to showcase enhanced content relating to our unique specialist university. Torchbox created such a site through their \u2018user first\u2019 approach, which involved an impressive amount of scoping with our stakeholders in order to understand our core audience. Armed with this research, they have created a website which engages our users and provides them with the best possible experience.\"", "attribution": "Jessica Taylor, Head of Marketing and Student Recruitment, Royal Agricultural University"}}]
fields.summary: Bringing the RAU experience to life

fields.descriptive_title: Making the most of Google Grants
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Mission"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Many of the world\u2019s worst environmental and human rights abuses are driven by the exploitation of natural resources and corruption in the global political and economic system. Global Witness is campaigning to end this. They carry out hard-hitting investigations, expose these abuses, and campaign for change. They began using Google Ad Grants in March 2015, and worked with Torchbox to maximise the opportunities presented by the programme.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Google Ad Grant goals"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The main goal for Global Witness is getting their voice heard amongst an audience who are engaged in the issues they investigate.

They wanted to use their initial monthly Google Ad Grants budget of USD $10,000 to:

  • Boost campaign reach
  • Increase traffic to key content and publications, whilst raising awareness\u00a0
  • Feature prominently in Google\u2019s search\u00a0results

Global Witness also wanted to be visible in Google\u2019s search results for debates which otherwise would be more difficult to have their voice heard on. Ranking highly for particular keywords enables Global Witness to keep a light shining on the issues they care about. Google Ad Grants allows Global Witness to appear at the top of Google\u2019s search results extremely quickly, often for keywords that they\u2019d never be able to rank for organically.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Impact"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In the first nine months of using Google Ad Grants, there were over 148,000 clicks through to the website from their ads, with just under 20% of this traffic completing an engagement action \u2014 these included downloading a PDF, signing up to the Global Witness newsletter, and spending more than 3 minutes on site. Within six months of signing up to the scheme, their account qualified for Grantspro, giving them an increased AdWords budget of USD$40,000 per month. This resulted in a significant boost to their traffic \u2014 at one point, traffic from Google Ad Grants accounted for over 50% of total monthly sessions on the site, making it their primary source of traffic.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Google Analytics data showing increase in performance", "image": 1299, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

High-volume keywords such as \u201cmoney laundering\u201d, \u201ccorruption\u201d and\u00a0\u201cglobal issues\u201d have been really strong for bringing quality traffic to the site. However, the biggest impact has come from being opportunistic with keywords. Using Google Ad Grants to respond to time-specific global events such as the Myanmar election has been a big success.

In October 2015, Global Witness launched a report on\u00a0corruption in the Jade Trade\u00a0and tied in the report\u2019s release with the upcoming elections in Myanmar. To promote the report\u2019s launch, we built an ad group containing keywords that focused on specific queries around the elections. Through a combination of well-chosen keywords and highly relevant ad copy with a strong call to action encouraging downloads of the report, Global Witness\u2019s ads ranked number one on Google for high-volume keywords such as \u201cmyanmar elections\u201d. This enabled them to put their priority content in front of a global audience at exactly the right moment, maximising the exposure of the report. As a result, over 380 downloads of the report came from users who clicked on an ad.

Having a Google Ad Grant has had a huge impact on Global Witness\u2019s online presence: increasing engaged, high-quality traffic to the website; exposing Global Witness\u2019s work to audiences who are already interested in the issues they work on; and capturing audiences who might not\u00a0have known about them. It\u2019s been a massive success.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cIt\u2019s been a pleasure working with Torchbox, who\u2019ve been really proactive and helpful. We\u2019ve appreciated the advice and expertise of our account manager and are delighted to have got to Grantspro status so quickly. We set ourselves a target of achieving Grantspro in six months so we were really chuffed when we achieved it.\u201d", "attribution": "Adrian Emanuel, Communications Assistant, Global Witness"}}]
fields.summary: How we helped Global Witness make the most of $10,000 of free advertising per month.

fields.descriptive_title: Twitter Cards Campaign for IPPF
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "What we set out to achieve"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In 2000, the UN launched a\u00a0fifteen year\u00a0plan called the Millennium Development Goals. In September 2014, the UN\u2019s General Assembly gathered to discuss plans for the next 15 years.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In the run-up to this meeting, International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) launched the #IDECIDE campaign, the objective of which was to gather support for putting sexual and reproductive rights at the heart of the UN\u2019s economic, environmental and social development agenda.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • 220m women in the developing world want contraception, but can\u2019t get it.
  • 1 in 3 women has experienced violence.
  • Every year 47,000 women die of unsafe abortions.
  • An estimated 67 million girls are married before their 18th birthday.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This campaign was a multi-layered approach that also included a Facebook campaign, YouTube videos, several promoted tweets and a billboard in\u00a0New York\u2019s Times Square, all of which lead to encourage signatures on the petition. One of the stars in this campaign was the Lead-Generation Tweet, which meant that people could sign the petition from within Twitter itself.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Torchbox suggested that we test Twitter cards to promote the 'I decide' campaign. We were prepared for modest results and were absolutely delighted to see that we achieved such fantastic conversion rates.\"", "attribution": "Ben Davies, Senior Communications Adviser, IPPF"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The Tweet"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are many things to consider in order to get the best possible results from a promoted campaign on Twitter. Optimising every aspect from the language to the targeting is important as it\u2019s very simple for small changes to against what is best practice. This was the Tweet that was sent out at the height of the IPPF activity.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It was promoted using what we felt was the best possible targeting and we monitored it throughout the day, making small alterations to the ad spend .

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Every user who clicked the blue \u201cSign the petition\u201d button, their Registered name, Email and Twitter Handle was saved. This could then be exported automatically to a number of CRM programs or exported as a CSV file.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Sexual and reproductive health and rights are essential for helping ensure that we can build a more equal and sustainable world by 2030, so it was encouraging to see how wide our message has travelled on Twitter and how well it converted people into supporting the campaign. We will definitely look to try this again.\"", "attribution": "Ben Davies, Senior Communications Adviser, IPPF"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Repeat Success"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

On 11 October, we ran the campaign again to coincide with International Day of the Girl, a\u00a0UN designated\u00a0day to bring these issues to the forefront. Building on what we had learned in the previous campaign, we ran a similar campaign and changed the wording to reflect the day.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Next Steps"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The people who clicked the petitions were added to a list and sent a thank you Email for their involvement in the #IDECIDE Twitter campaign. The Email was personalised with their Twitter handle and contained more information and further calls-to-action. This is a great list as they could be called upon to support\u00a0Twitter-based\u00a0campaign in the future.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • The promoted campaigns had 1,875 ReTweets, created 742 new followers and \u00a0generated 3,006 Email leads that were added to the petition.
  • The benchmark for Average Engagement Rate for Promoted Tweets is about 1%. These Lead Generation Tweets managed an average of 1.93% with one Tweet managing 2.43%!
  • Based upon the entire spend on promoting the Tweets, the average cost-per-lead (CPL) of about around \u00a30.89. One campaign even managed to get as low as \u00a30.45!

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Thanks Torchbox for helping us to promote the important message that every women and girl should have the right to decide her future to millions of people.\"", "attribution": "Ben Davies, Senior Communications Adviser, IPPF"}}]
fields.summary: Less than £1 Cost-per-Lead (CPL) for non-profits

fields.descriptive_title: Could you be a School Maker?
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

When SGOSS asked us to help them recruit new school governors, we focused on raising awareness of the vital role they undertake, in a fun and interactive way. The results surpassed all expectations.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What did we set out to achieve?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were asked to develop the concept and build an interactive digital element to raise awareness of the school governor role and encourage people to volunteer. Additionally, we planned and implemented a digital campaign to circulate it to as wide an audience as possible. The target, based on the success of previous campaigns, was to generate 75 applications.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Developing a theme"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We immersed ourselves into the world of the school governor. We searched a lot and we read a lot. We\u00a0learnt\u00a0that school governors make really important decisions like appointing \u00a0a head teacher and setting the school\u2019s aims and budget, but that the public\u00a0were\u00a0largely unaware of this.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We felt the key to recruiting new governors was showing the public how important the role is, the sort of decisions that governors make, and that there are openings available.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The theme for our campaign was: \u2018Could you be a School Maker?\u2019.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Compelling content"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We wanted to bring the role to life in an entertaining and cost effective way. We did this by developing an interactive video using Rapt Media\u2019s platform. Three children formed an interview panel and asked users what they would do in situations school governors face \u2013 for\u00a0example\u00a0whether to sell off part of the school field in order to be able to replace IT facilities. Users would be able to choose what they would do and the children would act out the consequences.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Three children formed an interview panel and asked users what they would do in situations school governors face \u2013 for\u00a0example\u00a0whether to sell off part of the school field in order to be able to replace IT facilities. Users would be able to choose what they would do and the children would act out the consequences.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Friends and family"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The production of the video really was a Torchbox affair! The actors in the video are two of Olly Willans\u2019 (our Creative Director) children and one of their friends and it was shot at a local school where Tom Dyson (our Tech Director) is a governor!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You can watch the final piece here:\u00a0www.sgoss.org.uk/schoolmakers.html

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u2018The latest initiative from SGOSS is the School Makers campaign, which saw the launch of a new, and rather brilliant, interactive video campaign.\"", "attribution": "Peter Henshaw, Editor, SecEd"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Making it famous"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were excited about the video and wanted the world to know about it!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A PR campaign focused on survey results showing the lack of knowledge about the decisions school governors make and encouraged people to apply for vacancies. Widespread coverage was received on national, regional and online media such as Radio 2, Radio 4, Radio 5 Live, over 20 regional BBC stations and the BBC website.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "A clip from the SGOSS School Makers interactive video", "image": 1450, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To give the campaign a further boost, SGOSS arranged for promotions to be secured with partners such as Aviva, Deutsche Bank, Lloyds TSB and Teach First.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The content was also well received on social platforms and a Thunderclap promotion gave people the chance to donate a Facebook post or Tweet to support the campaign.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were to be judged on the number of applications received and the campaign completely surpassed expectations.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • The target number of applications was 75.\u00a0
  • The campaign delivered 804, beating the target by 972%.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"All our carefully thought out and realistic targets based on previous campaign data were smashed within 36 hours of launch. We couldn\u2019t have achieved this without the great work from Torchbox.\"", "attribution": "Christopher Parker, Former Head of Marketing & Communications at SGOSS"}}]
fields.summary: Beating the target by 972%

fields.descriptive_title: An 'unbelievable' Chris Kamara soundboard
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When Marie Curie approached us about raising awareness of their partnership with the Football League and how they could encourage football fans to sign up to climb Kilimanjaro with Chris Kamara, we came up with an unbelievable piece of content.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What we did"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We made a video soundboard which gave fans the chance to get Chris Kamara to say some of his most famous phrases such as 'unbelievable', 'the man mountain' and 'couldn't hit a barn door'.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The result was a really fun piece of content that was well received by fans, bloggers and third-party sites.\u00a0It received a great deal of buzz and exceeded the targets that had been set. We even did a follow-up campaign around Christmas time with Chris in a Santa suit!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Caught Offside called it a 'Hilarious Must Have For All Football Fans'.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Chris Kamara Soundboard", "image": 550, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}]
fields.summary: A video soundboard of Chris Kamara for Marie Curie

fields.descriptive_title: Helping Yahoo Sport make the most of its UK Facebook page
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We\u2019ve been working alongside Yahoo on their UK Sports Facebook page since April 2011. Back in 2011, the page had c. 150,000 page Likes. Since then, it has grown organically to c.\u00a01,200,000.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What did we set out to achieve?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We set out to drive community engagement and referrals from the\u00a0Facebook page\u00a0to\u00a0Yahoo UK's\u00a0excellent sports offering.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Open all hours"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Sports news can break at any minute of any hour. Much of the action takes place outside of office hours. In order to deliver for Yahoo, we work on the page on evenings and weekends as well as 9-5. If something happens of note, we want to cover it as it happens.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Editorial style"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We have worked hard to deliver an editorial style that fits Yahoo's values. We take the best of the content from their offering and make it available via Facebook using an editorial style that fits the tone of the post.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Algorithm obsession"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We follow the Facebook algorithm incredibly closely and use our knowledge to help deliver the best service to Yahoo and our other clients. We won't bore you with the details here, but it's fair to say to say we are ever so slightly obsessive about the workings of the Facebook algorithm!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Keeping Track"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We monitor a wide range of metrics in order to gauge page health. This isn't just something we do on a weekly or monthly\u00a0basis\u00a0though! We track the performance of every single post in the constant quest for\u00a0insight\u00a0that can help us improve post performance. We wrap the findings and recommendations up\u00a0in to\u00a0a monthly report which we share with Yahoo.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Doing more"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As our relationship with Yahoo has developed, we have worked on a number of additional projects. These range from a major design and build\u00a0job\u00a0around the French Presidential Election, to working with other Yahoo editorial departments on their approach to social media and creating and managing Tumblr accounts.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u2018The team at Torchbox have worked hard to understand the Yahoo brand and we\u2019ve enjoyed working closely with them. They combine editorial skills, marketing know how and an understanding of how the algorithms work in order to deliver a service that has produced outstanding results.\"", "attribution": "Richard Blake, Director, EMEA Consumer Marketing & Partnerships, Yahoo"}}]
fields.summary: Helping Yahoo make the most of its Yahoo Sport UK Facebook page

fields.descriptive_title: Search and social campaign for the RCN
fields.intro: A search and social recruitment campaign for the Royal College of Nursing.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Royal College of Nursing is the UK's largest nonprofit professional nursing body, representing more than 435,000 nurses, student nurses, midwives,\u00a0health care\u00a0assistants and\u00a0assistant practitioners in the UK and internationally.

To communicate its membership benefits to the UK healthcare workforce, the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) sought our help to create its first ever digital recruitment campaign.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Objectives"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The campaign's objectives were:

  • Communicate\u00a0that health care assistants, assistant practitioners, nurses and students can join the RCN and explain what the membership benefits are in a compelling fashion.
  • Reach\u00a0target audiences and drive memberships in a cost effective way.\u00a0
  • Optimise\u00a0the campaign in real-time by measuring the success of\u00a0activity.\u00a0
"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"I appreciate the time taken by Torchbox to interpret the brief and the wider market conditions that the RCN operates in. This helped form a truly collaborative partnership that allowed us the room to be responsive and conduct an effective campaign based on the test, learn and optimise framework.\"", "attribution": "Yasser Hussain, Marketing Manager, Royal College of Nursing"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Strategy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We first ran a series of test campaigns to identify which channels generated the greatest number of memberships at a cost effective ROI. Based on the results, we developed a campaign strategy which leant on paid search and Facebook advertising to drive audiences to sign up for RCN membership. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Our strategy for Royal College of Nursing's search and social campaign", "image": 1039, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Implementation"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Landing Pages
The pages we wanted to drive audiences to did not exist, so we created responsive, mobile-friendly landing pages. Next, we focused on creating a compelling list of benefits for each of the audience landing pages.\u00a0We communicated the RCN\u2019s five membership points to health care assistants and assistant practitioners, listed reasons why nurses should join the RCN and promoted educational support benefits to nursing students.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal College of Nursing landing page", "image": 1176, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Paid Search
We built and ran granular AdWords campaigns to target health care assistants, assistant practioners, nurses and students. To ensure we were targeting the right audiences with the correct messaging, we created bespoke ad copy which resonated with each audience. To increase traffic to the target landing pages, we expanded our ad campaigns to include specialty terms and more relevant job titles.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cThis campaign went a long way towards helping exceed our membership targets for the year. A low cost per acquisition (CPA) coupled with high revenue really speaks for itself. The ability for us to show true measurement metrics will be a huge positive as we look to extend this kind of activity in the future.\u201d", "attribution": "Yasser Hussain, Marketing Manager, Royal College of Nursing"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Facebook Advertising
We ran a campaign to test seven different creatives. The best performing adverts achieved a 10 out of 10 Facebook relevancy score and drove audiences to target landing pages for a very low cost per click. To broaden our reach, we expanded the job titles campaign to include variations used in different UK locations. Interestingly 79% of clicks came from mobile users.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal College of Nursing Facebook ads", "image": 1177, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Attribution
To monitor the effectiveness of our campaign, we created a unique attribution model to understand which channel accounted for each conversion. This approach provided valuable insights which we used to optimise the campaign.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "An example of the attribution model we built for Royal College of Nursing", "image": 1178, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • The communications we used to target each of our audiences proved to be convincing and compelling. Of the 35,084 visitors we drove to our target landing pages, 6,543 continued through to the membership registration page, and 1,412 went on to sign up for RCN membership.
  • Using a mixture of clever targeting techniques, we have been able to drive audiences to sign up for memberships in a cost effective way. For every \u00a31 spent, our campaign returned 629% revenue.
  • We continuously optimised our AdWords and Facebook advertising campaigns to improve the performance and results. This helped to increase hte number of memeberships generated throughout the life of the campaign by 571%.\u00a0
"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cA highly successful campaign for us, not only from a results point of view but also from an agency/client perspective.\"", "attribution": "Yasser Hussain, Marketing Manager, Royal College of Nursing"}}]
fields.summary: A search and social recruitment campaign for the Royal College of Nursing (RCN).

fields.descriptive_title: Reinterpreting the Museum of London’s brand
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The\u00a0Museum of London\u00a0tells the story of one of the world's great cities; from prehistoric times through to modern life. Each year, the award-winning organisation welcomes just under 1.2 million visitors to its two main attractions: the Museum of London and the Museum of London Docklands.

Like London itself, the Museum has bold ambitions. Not least is its intention to increase visitor footfall to 1.5 million by 2018. To achieve this target, the Museum recognised a digital refresh would play a critical role.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"We wanted our new web site to be clearer for users, to showcase our galleries, to create a new virtual space where we can publish our perspectives on London, to optimise e-commerce opportunities and to reflect our brand.\"", "attribution": "Nigel Ludlow, Director of Assets, Museum of London"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Objectives"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Museum of London sought our expertise to turn a set of wireframes, created by WebCredible, into a beautiful, modern website to better represent its sophistication and relevance to the City of London\u2019s cultural dialogue.

The specifics for this project were:

  • Go bold and modern, without compromising user experience
  • Reflect the Museum of London\u2019s distinctive brand personality
  • Create an interactive and immersive experience
  • Streamline across mobile, tablet and desktop
  • Drive interest and action
  • Keep it simple

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Strategy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Moodboards
Based on the objectives set, our design team collated a range of ideas and themes for the new website. These ideas were then presented in the form of\u00a0moodboards\u00a0to senior stakeholders during a live feedback session.\u00a0\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Museum of London moodboard", "image": 1180, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Design Concepts\u00a0
Following the\u00a0moodboarding\u00a0session, we created design concepts for three of the Museum of London\u2019s key pages. Rather than working with flat images, we developed these designs in the browser - creating interactive HTML web pages to give the Museum of London a feel for how our concepts would respond to different user interactions and screen sizes.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ User Testing
Once the design concepts had been signed off, we headed over to the Museum of London for a day of user testing. Our aim was to engage with the Museum\u2019s key audiences - in\u00a0particular\u00a0working professionals and cultural connoisseurs. We captured lots of useful feedback, and the designs and functionality of the website tested really well.\u00a0

+ Further Templates
We then proceeded to broaden our design concepts to produce an additional 26 HTML-based page designs. In tandem, we created a comprehensive user interface component library which allowed for an easy handover of our design prototype to the Museum of London\u2019s development team.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Reflect the Museum of London\u2019s brand personality
Our aim was to create a design which embodied the Museum of London\u2019s brand promise: \u2018We are London\u2019. By playing on the contour lines from the Museum of London\u2019s logo, we\u2019ve created a design feature which subtly resonates with the current brand, whilst facilitating future brand changes.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Museum of London homepage", "image": 1235, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Drive interest and action
To provide clear and recognisable signposting for users, we employed colours and separate navigation elements to differentiate between the museums; pink for the Museum of London and blue for the Museum of London Docklands.

+ Go bold and modern without compromising user experience
By clearly displaying upcoming events on the\u00a0homepage\u00a0and\u00a0What\u2019s On\u00a0pages, we have increased the ecommerce conversion rate by 52.96%.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Museum of London Docklands homepage", "image": 1236, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Streamline across mobile, tablet and desktop
We took advantage of the extra space available on desktop devices to add navigation features to better serve core user journeys. Drawing on the strengths of each platform, we\u2019ve created a responsive design which adapts to different devices.

+ Create an interactive and immersive experience
To promote the Museum of London\u2019s main offering,\u00a0London in 9 free galleries, we designed an interactive timeline at the top of the homepage. Within each gallery subpage, we included artefact showcases to stimulate interest and intrigue. By using engaging design tactics, we have increased average session duration by 7.34% and lowered overall bounce rate by 8.36%.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Medieval London gallery page", "image": 1237, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Drive interest and action
By clearly displaying upcoming events on the\u00a0homepage\u00a0and\u00a0What\u2019s On\u00a0pages, we have increased the ecommerce conversion rate by 52.96%.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Keep it simple
The simplest solution is often the best and we will do the hard work required to make it happen. The result: a clean, simple and slick experience.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cWe\u2019re delighted that the new site delivers each of these objectives in a way that has dramatically improved our online presence.\u201d", "attribution": "Nigel Ludlow, Director of Assets, Museum of London"}}]
fields.summary: Reinterpreting the Museum of London’s brand for the contemporary digital space.

fields.descriptive_title: Social video campaign drives record downloads
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background & Objectives"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

\u201cThe Africa Progress Panel report of 2015 explains the bold steps that leaders globally and in Africa must take and it holds Africa\u2019s partners to account for the promises they have yet to keep. Above all, our report shows that the global climate movement is also Africa\u2019s moment.\u201d - Kofi Annan, Chairman, Africa Progress Panel

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Chaired by former UN Secretary General, Kofi Annan, Africa Progress Panel seeks to ensure that African social, political and economic issues remain prominent in global development discussions.

In 2015, the Africa Progress Panel planned to launch one of its more critical reports, which focused on climate change and its effects on Africa. To drive maximum exposure and action, the Africa Progress Panel sought our help to create a social video campaign to drive awareness and interest in the report.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "2015 Africa Progress Report", "image": 1266, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Strategy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Turning to Twitter and Facebook, we created three pre-launch campaigns to generate awareness and intrigue amongst international audiences. One campaign challenged user\u2019s views on the effects of climate change on Africa. Another used six teaser videos to promote the report\u2019s launch date and a third encouraged users to register their email details to receive a copy of the report once it had launched.

We also created a three-minute video which used slick visuals and strong narration to communicate the report\u2019s top-level findings on climate change, food production and energy supply. Narrated by Kofi Annan, the video launched alongside the report and was promoted across Facebook and Twitter.

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/giRe0EMROVk"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

All of this activity and exposure helped to drive the results that really mattered: views of the main video and report downloads. Since launch, the video has been viewed 242,000+ times on Facebook and Twitter, helping to drive 18,000 report downloads.

The pre-launch campaigns worked their magic. In the two weeks leading up the report\u2019s launch, the campaigns reached 8.3 million Facebook and Twitter users, resulting in 720,000 engagements, 422,000 teaser video views and the collection of 1,914 email addresses.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"The numbers speak for themselves. The reach we achieved through this campaign surpassed our expectations. We managed to successfully highlight the impact of climate change on Africa in the critical months leading up to the December 2015 Climate Conference in Paris. To this day, we continue to use the video to emphasize our climate-related messaging.\"", "attribution": "Caroline Kende-Robb, Executive Director, Africa Progress Panel"}}]
fields.summary: Social video campaign drives record number of report downloads

fields.descriptive_title: The UK's first centralised source of youth homelessness data
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "h2", "value": "Background"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Centrepoint\u00a0is a youth homelessness charity which provides people, aged 16-25, with a safe place to live in London and the North East of England.

Despite youth homelessness figures being widely recorded across the UK, there are major discrepancies and disparities within the data. One of the winners of the\u00a0Google Impact Challenge 2014, Centrepoint sought our technical expertise to combat this problem by creating the UK\u2019s first Youth Homelessness Databank.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Youth Homelessness Databank homepage", "image": 1240, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Objectives"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Centrepoint wanted the Youth Homelessness Databank to act as a central data repository for youth homelessness in the UK. This online tool needed to capture, measure and display youth homelessness data from multiple sources including the government, local authorities, charities and housing providers. The specifics for this project were:

  • Create a web-based dashboard which would allow third-party data providers to easily upload normalised youth homeless data from disparate sources.\u00a0
  • Collate the uploaded information and present it in an easy-to-understand, digestible way to provide a true view of youth homelessness in the UK.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Policy about youth homelessness is currently made in the dark, with no agreement on even the most basic question: how many young people are homeless? No-one really knows! Here at Centrepoint\u2019s Youth Homelessness Databank we are delighted to have worked with Torchbox to develop the UK\u2019s first ever website that turns youth homelessness data from across the country into youth homelessness knowledge.\"", "attribution": "Gaia Marcus, Youth Homelessness Databank Manager, Centrepoint"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Challenges Faced"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are more than 400 local authorities in the UK. Each collects and stores youth homelessness data in a different way. Our challenge was to consolidate this body of data into one central source, without sacrificing the integrity or nuance of it in any way. We also had to ensure that the process of adding data to the Youth Homelessness Databank was simple and straightforward, to encourage uptake and use. This was a particular consideration for local authority data providers; we needed to design an upload process which would facilitate adding data to the system without creating additional work for them.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Strategy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Discovery Phase
We began by analysing the existing user research previously undertaken by the Centrepoint Youth Homelessness Databank team, which gave us insight into user\u2019s\u2019 requirements and needs. These insights were expressed in the form of user stories (for example, \u2018as a user I need to filter the data by date so that I understand how recent the data is\u2019). We used these stories to develop a list of potential features for the Youth Homelessness Databank, which we then worked with Centrepoint to prioritise.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Alpha Phase
We then moved into our Alpha phase, creating an underlying data model to define how the Youth Homelessness Databank would represent the aggregated data. This was a complex process because of the range of ways in which homelessness statistics are currently captured; as an example, some data providers break data down by age ranges of 16-17 and 18-24, whilst others treat this as a single large group. In parallel, mockups for the web-based dashboard user interface were created, and these were user tested to validate the initial premise of the product.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cThe beta website is a design that we can be proud of and that we are receiving positive feedback on. We look forward to using it to help create the evidence base necessary to create real change.\u201d", "attribution": "Gaia Marcus, Youth Homelessness Databank Manager, Centrepoint"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

+ Beta Phase
Once the solution from the alpha phase had been fully tested and iterated, we focused on developing the site\u2019s visual design and user-facing features. We worked through our prioritised feature list and drew on our user research to add key functionality, such as the ability to compare data from two different local authorities. A final round of user testing was conducted to test the dashboard\u2019s usability amongst target audiences.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Youth homelessness data comparison", "image": 1189, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Working in partnership with Centrepoint\u2019s Youth Homelessness Databank team, we have successfully developed the UK\u2019s first central source for youth homelessness data. The Youth Homelessness Databank not only allows local authorities and charities to easily upload data, but it also consolidates and presents youth homelessness data in an easy to understand, digestible format which can better help affect future change.

"}]
fields.summary: Creating the UK's first centralised source of youth homelessness data.

fields.no_jobs_that_fit: Not the right role for you? Please do get in touch anyway. We’re always on the lookout for talented people to join our team.

fields.intro: Google Analytics is a wonderful source of data about your users. However, it's all too easy to focus on the obvious rather than dig down for some real treasure. In this post, I outline five user insights from Analytics that are worth their weight in gold.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Google Analytics is a wonderful\u00a0source of data about your users. However, it's all too easy to focus on the obvious rather than dig down for some real treasure. In this post, I outline five user insights from Analytics that are worth their weight in gold.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Taming the beast"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Google Analytics is a powerful tool, but with power comes (sometimes bewildering) complexity. The best way to deal with this\u00a0is to think about the questions you want the answers too.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Most of what I talk about below involves using segments; these are my preferred way of slicing and dicing analytics data into more insightful chunks. If you've not done this before (or haven't used the new interface for segments), there are many blog posts to help you out, such as\u00a0Justin Cutroni\u2019s from last year. Don\u2019t forget that stacking multiple segments allows comparison between them; if you don\u2019t want to compare between segments then use the \u201cAll Visits\u201d segment to compare your segment with all site traffic.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "1. New visitors"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We spend a lot of time optimising home pages to provide an excellent means of showing all that a site has to\u00a0offer,\u00a0when often people arrive elsewhere from a search. For many organisations new visitors are particularly important (are they signed up to email? / my latest campaign? / etc.), so knowing where they land is vital. The question I\u2019m interested in is: \u201cWhat pages are visitors new to the site landing on?\u201d Analytics provides a built-in segment for new visitors, so fire it up. Here it is favourited in the segments drop-down:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Now take a look at landing pages (Behaviour > Site Content > Landing Pages). Ensure that any well-visited ones have the appropriate navigation and retention features.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "New users segment in Google Analytics", "image": 6, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "2. Mobile"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Understanding the journeys made by users on mobile / tablet is now very important - and vital if you\u2019ve not yet optimised the site.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The question I\u2019m interested in is quite wide: \u201cAre mobile / tablet users coming to the site for different reasons than desktop, and what pages are they looking at?\u201d

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

First up, take a look at your overall mobile traffic - nothing complex here, just look in Audience > Mobile > Overview. Our clients are seeing anything from 5% to 50% from mobile/ tablet combined. However, a low number doesn\u2019t mean that you don\u2019t have to cater for mobile/ tablet - it could be a worrying sign that people are bouncing from your\u00a0unoptimised\u00a0website.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To look at this further I use the built-in \u201cMobile and Tablet Traffic\u201d segment (favourited in the screengrab below):

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Mobile and tablet users segment in Google Analytics", "image": 7, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With this segment (and All Visits selected for comparison), I\u2019ll take a look at landing pages (Behaviour > Site Content > Landing Pages) and see if there\u2019s a high bounce / exit rate for the mobile / tablet segment.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I then look at the search terms people are using to get to the site, and see if these differ from the desktop segment. If it does, it might mean that people are coming to the site from mobile / tablet for a different reason, and I should look to cater for this. I then look at the landing pages for those\u00a0terms,\u00a0and check if these (whether optimised or not) help people on mobile / tablet complete the tasks suggested by the search terms.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "3. Scroll depth"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You\u2019ll need a developer to set up the code to track scroll depth. But - if you manage a site with long pages (including your homepage), it\u2019s essential. Once it\u2019s working, you\u2019ll find it as an event in Behaviour > Events.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The question I\u2019m interested in is this: \u201cAre long section index pages providing a barrier for my users?\u201d

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To answer this, I create a custom segment showing scroll depth of > 75%. This will appear under the Conditions tab (click on the \u201cAd\u00a0content\u201d drop-down and then search for \u201cscroll\u201d to find it in the list). Once the segment is created, I look at exit rate from these pages (via Behaviour > Site Content > All Pages).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Any pages that have an anomalously high exit rate probably aren\u2019t doing a good job at linking users onwards, and I can look at the in-page analytics for each of these to see why.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "4. Site search"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Site search (Behaviour > Site search) is a vital means for understanding not only what users are searching the site for, but the language and phrasing that they are using. It\u2019s also often possible to pick up an anomaly between your navigation and what people are searching for - a popular search term might mean that people aren\u2019t easily finding the link to the page(s) relating to it.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

However, site search isn\u2019t something that\u2019s set up by default in Google Analytics. You will have to configure Analytics (and might have to get a developer to do it).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Once it\u2019s working (leave it for a month or two before analysing), check the usage; if it\u2019s low it suggests a possible problem.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Then take a look at the search terms and look at the destination pages. Check that there are no weird mismatches.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Then view the \u201c% Search Exits\u201d metric. This tells you the percentage of searches in which the user left your site after searching instead of clicking any of the search results. It\u2019s possible that your content (or search function) isn\u2019t optimised for these searches.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Scroll depth in Google Analytics", "image": 12, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "5. Organic search"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Sadly, \u201c(not provided)\u201d means that the organic search data (Acquisition > Keywords > Organic) is almost useless for providing user insight:-

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

However, there are ways around this. Personally, I favour the Google Webmaster Tools solution (method 4 in that link) as it also includes the clickthrough rate for particular terms, and the approximate impressions, too. This means that you can see how well or poorly you perform for particular searches, and, from a user research perspective, gives you clues to the language and wording that your users phrase their tasks with. This allows you to (manually) find the landing pages for those terms you\u2019re not performing well for, and then optimise the pages accordingly.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Want to find out more?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To understand how you can make the most of our Google Analytics data, please get in touch\u00a0and one of our experts will get back to you.

"}]

fields.intro: I’ve recently been doing some research on accessibility — in particular, designing for blind or partially sighted users. I found a bunch of useful research, articles and videos and thought it would be good to share them with you.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

I\u2019ve recently been doing some research on accessibility \u2014 in particular, designing for blind or partially sighted users.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I found a bunch of useful research,\u00a0articles\u00a0and videos and thought it would be good to share them with you.\u00a0If you only read one thing make it\u00a0this great presentation\u00a0by, Head of Accessibility at GDS, Joshua Marshall.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Here are some of the other things I found:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • How Blind People Use Twitter & YouTube on the iPhone 4S
  • How blind people use the internet
  • RNIB: Design and build accessible websites
  • Blind Community Fights for a More Accessible Web
  • How ARIA landmark roles help screen reader users
  • Make the most out of ARIA landmark roles
  • ARIA and progressive enhancement
  • Using OSX\u2019s voiceover
  • Skip links
  • Technology for life
  • Sim daltonism
  • BBC Accessibility

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It was nice to refresh my accessibility knowledge and I got a lot from the videos of blind and partially sighted people using the internet.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about accessibility for blind and partially sighted users, why not get in touch to discuss the options available.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Big news, Torchbox has released a brand new, open source content management system, Wagtail.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Big news, Torchbox has released a brand new, open source content management system, Wagtail.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Who is it aimed at?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Wagtail\u00a0is a powerful,\u00a0well featured\u00a0content management system, built on the popular, respected Django framework. It can power sites of any size, but it'll be particularly effective for medium to large sites with sophisticated content management requirements. Wagtail has a fantastic user interface that makes it easy and enjoyable to publish great content.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Wagtail interface", "image": 41, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Where has it come from?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We developed Wagtail with the\u00a0Royal College of Art for their new website, with the aim of releasing it as an\u00a0open source\u00a0project. The RCA site was launched last year and now has over 5000 pages and 8000 images in its Wagtail CMS. You can watch a\u00a0video case study\u00a0about the RCA implementation.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How do you feel about it?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We've been building content managed sites for 14 years. Wagtail takes the best CMS\u00a0concepts,\u00a0and is built using the latest web development practices. It may not yet have the wealth of plugins of some CMSs, \u00a0but it's a pleasure to extend. We love it and we are already seeing the benefits for developers and editors. The user experience is second to none.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How it's taking off?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So far, so good. We've done a very limited, developer-focused launch: a\u00a0new Django conference in Cardiff\u00a0and a story on\u00a0Hacker News. And, in just two weeks we have:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • 1000 stars\u00a0on Github
  • other agencies interested in implementing it (watch this space)
  • pull requests\u00a0from community contributors outside of Torchbox
  • people\u00a0saying nice things\u00a0about it
  • hosting companies\u00a0supporting it
  • almost 70%\u00a0test coverage
  • volunteers adding\u00a0translations for the admin interface, so German and Greek editors can use it
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And, look out for the relaunch of Torchbox.com on Wagtail in the next couple of weeks.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Are you still doing Drupal?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Yes. We continue to build and support Drupal sites for some fantastic organisations. Many organisations have implemented Drupal, but for those that want to look at other options, you may well find that\u00a0Wagtail\u00a0is the right one.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about Wagtail and the benefits it could bring your business, please don't hesitate to get in touch.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Since its launch a month ago, we've been working hard on making it easy to get started with Wagtail, our new open source CMS.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Since its launch a month ago, we've been working hard on making it easy to get started with Wagtail, our new open source CMS.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The\u00a0release notes for 0.2\u00a0have the details: Redis has been removed as a dependency, along with\u00a0npm\u00a0(used for\u00a0Coffeescript\u00a0and Less), and Wagtail can use its database as a simple search backend when Elasticsearch isn't available.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At the same time, we recommend that people take advantage of all the performance and functionality benefits of the optional third party services when they're using Wagtail in production. To this end, we've written one line installers for Ubuntu:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

curl -O https://wagtail.io/ubuntu.sh; bash ubuntu.sh

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

and Debian:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

curl -O https://wagtail.io/debian.sh; bash\u00a0debian.sh

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These scripts install all the dependencies for a production-ready Wagtail site, including PostgreSQL, Redis, Elastic,\u00a0Nginx\u00a0and\u00a0uwsgi. Fire up a $5 Digital Ocean box and you can be running Wagtail five minutes later!

"}]

fields.intro: The image formats we’ve grown accustomed to on the web are inflexible. JPG, PNG etc aren’t human-readable, aren't editable without re-saving and they’re un-scalable without loss of quality.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

The image formats we\u2019ve grown accustomed to on the web are inflexible. JPG, PNG etc aren\u2019t human-readable, aren't editable without re-saving and they\u2019re un-scalable without loss of quality.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

They\u2019re so ubiquitous you wouldn\u2019t think of these as limitations but if you consider modern graphic use on the web, these file formats feel increasingly restrictive and\u00a0backward.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Vector-based graphics use mathematical expressions to represent position. Since an expression scales indefinitely so does a vector image, without loss of quality. Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) - a popular vector format compatible with the web - uses XML as a file format and being a human-readable language SVGs aren't the locked black box that predecessor formats are.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The need for scaling graphics is relatively new. With the release of\u00a0high pixel-density\u00a0display devices e.g \u201cRetina\u201d screens, images using raster formats can be seen to get lower resolution overnight. Try using the \"zoom\" function to view an old iPhone app on an iPad. Yuk!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Web designers understand this and typically solve it by creating images twice: once at double-resolution for Retina devices, another at\u00a0standard\u00a0resolution for everything else. Developers also have to code with two versions of each image in mind. It's not ideal.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Many website images are simple vector shapes - consider an RSS icon or a Twitter bird - and aren't much more complex than the letters of the alphabet. Fonts are vectors too so \"icon fonts\" were born: a font storing simple vector images instead of letters. You remember \u201cWingdings\u201d, right? -\u00a0same\u00a0thing, except icon\u00a0fonts\u00a0can be\u00a0created from scratch, with every \u201cletter\u201d of the font lovingly crafted by a designer and collated into a bespoke font for your own brand/site.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Icon\u00a0fonts, therefore,\u00a0solve the Retina issue: a font loses no detail at any pixel density.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

They also improve image production workflow too since anything we can do with real fonts on the web can be done with icon fonts too. Consider a designer creating the same image in red, blue and yellow to suit the colour themes of a site. These colour variations can now be created by a developer in a fraction of the time - literally by typing 6 characters - using the same elementary technology we\u2019d use to make a heading font red, or a link blue - remember: they\u2019re just fonts!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

However just as you can\u2019t\u00a0shade\u00a0a letter \u201cT\u201d with two colours simultaneously, neither can you colour an icon font. So while they have more flexible than raster images, icon fonts are still limited to monochrome.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

SVG advances vector use one step further by supporting multiple colours, plus with XML as a file\u00a0format\u00a0the shapes and colours are all dynamically changeable with javascript and CSS. As developers are capable of making significant graphic adjustments using familiar development languages without a designer\u2019s input, this is hugely significant.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Yet despite SVG having existed since 2001 and first supported by Konqueror (anyone\u00a0remember\u00a0that?) since 2004, it\u2019s been Microsoft\u2019s reluctance to adopt the standard till IE9\u2019s release in 2011 that has held SVG use back.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Fortunately,\u00a0use of unsupportive browsers is dropping rapidly. Torchbox are dropping support for IE7 wherever possible and now Microsoft have adopted a more forceful upgrade policy IE8 won\u2019t be long behind. This means IE9 will be the lowest supported browser and with IE9 supporting SVG, this changes the world of web graphics considerably.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As SVG can be manipulated and animated live, we will likely see the web change quite a bit. Adverts, charts, indeed practically any graphic that isn\u2019t a photograph could become far more interactive with far less effort. Exciting times are ahead!

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Do you remember the Choose Your Own story adventure books? They went a little something like this...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You\u2019ve just started reading a blog post. It is dark outside. You hear an owl hoot. You keep reading. Suddenly in the\u00a0distance\u00a0you hear a scream. You look up.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Choice: Do you go outside? (turn to page 2)

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Or: Do you keep reading the blog? (go to page 27)

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I got well into these books for a while. I liked the fact I could decide where I would go next.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I think the modern day equivalent is interactive videos.\u00a0Ones where you are given choices, and the story\u00a0develops based on your choices.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For the past few months, I\u2019ve worked on an interactive video project with SGOSS - the School Governor recruitment charity.
