We\u2019ll take a more detailed look at the ace campaign - which stars two of Torchbox Olly\u2019s children and their friend - and its results in more detail in a future blog but for today I\u2019d like to focus on the platform we used to make it happen.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Choice: Do you have a go at the interactive video now? (hit the play button below)

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Or: Do you keep reading the blog (just scroll down a bit please)

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So when it came to building the video, we could have used YouTube Annotations. But they don\u2019t work on tablet or mobile. We could have programmed it ourselves. But that could have been tricky and\u00a0time consuming. We chose to use Rapt Media\u2019s platform which allows you to build interactive videos quickly and cost effectively (as we were working with a charity, Rapt gave a discount on their white label product).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I guess you always face challenges when developing content and I was pleased with the support Rapt gave us when we needed it, including out of hours.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The video has done really well so far. It gives people the chance to make the sort of decisions which School Governors have to make on a day to day basis.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It allows the story to be told in a compelling way and a way which the user feels involved in.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The aim is to recruit new School Governors and early indications are it is doing exactly that.\u00a0To find out more, please visit\u00a0Rapt Media's website.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you think interactive video could help bring your organisation's story to life, please get in touch.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Big week, last week. We launched the Royal College of Art website. If you aren't familiar with the RCA, it's the world's best graduate art and design school.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Big week, last week. We launched the Royal College of Art (RCA) website. If you aren't familiar with the RCA, it's the world's best graduate art and design school.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were delighted to win the four-way pitch for UX consultancy. Better still, we ended up building the whole site and creating an exciting new CMS, which we will be open sourcing - look out for more on this soon.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The RCA is one of the most inspiring and exciting organisations I could hope to work with. They totally embraced our collaborative, agile approach to running a project and my thanks go to their project leader, Octavia Reeve, who has been fantastic, and the wonderfully\u00a0acronymed\u00a0Web Task Force project board.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Even better, we worked with Research Studios, Neville Brody's design outfit, who delivered all the visual design. As well as having designed the BBC website (alongside all the other things that have made him one of the\u00a0best-known\u00a0graphic designers in the UK), Neville is the Dean of the School of Communications at the RCA and recent RCA Visual Communication graduate, Jack Llewellyn, was a core member of the design team.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We had a couple of significant changes of direction, most notably RCA's decision, mid-project, to abandon Squiz CMS and commission us to develop a new CMS and implement the site on it. Despite\u00a0these\u00a0we were delighted to launch the project on schedule for the key 2014 REF deadlines.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My thanks also go to everyone who worked on our project team: Chris Rogers, Matthew Westcott, Dave Cranwell, Helen Chapman, Karl Hobley, Balazs\u00a0Endrezs, Nick Smith.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The RCA site is driven by our new, blazing fast Python/Django CMS, which we will be launching as an open source project in early 2014. It integrates with EPrints for research records, and the College's LDAP server for authentication; it uses Stripe for donations, Elasticsearch for, um, search, Eventbrite for event booking, and it drives the screens around the College that tell students and staff what events are happening, every day.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Thousands of images and records were imported from the previous site including all show data and profiles on previous students, current researchers, staff, images of artworks, research records, and news. The site is responsive and optimised for desktop,\u00a0tablet\u00a0and mobile.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about the Royal College of Art website, or would like to discuss your exciting project, please don't hesitate to get in touch.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: I was fortunate enough to get the opportunity to attend Hackference at the Fazeley Studios in Birmingham at the end of August.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

I was fortunate enough to get the opportunity to attend Hackference\u00a0at the Fazeley Studios in Birmingham at the end of August.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

While not specifically designed for a single technology or skill set it was a great opportunity to meet people who built things for the web across a wide spectrum of technologies and products.\u00a0The Fazeley Studios\u00a0venue was an intriguing mix of marble, fine\u00a0art\u00a0and trendy office spaces and must be an inspiring place to work on a day to day basis.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Hackference", "image": 85, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The conference was keynoted by\u00a0Syd Lawrence\u00a0(of\u00a0instac.at\u00a0fame - possibly the finest use of the Austrian TLD?) who, through the medium of animated gif slides, reminded us of the positive effects hack days have both to the development of personal tech skills as well as being able to fold those experiences back into the workplace. It's important to periodically remind yourself that you shouldn't be working just for the sake of work, but for fun. Play/fun/making something... these are great motivating factors and whether it's with Lego, wood, paint or Javascript (other languages are available!) we should all strive to enjoy what we create.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There were\u00a0great\u00a0session on good API design from\u00a0Lorna Jane, an introduction to Clojure and how it improves on Java, building algorithms to make rhyming couplets from Twitter with Go, and a really fun demonstration how node.js is used to power\u00a0quadracopters. For those of you who haven't seen one of these\u00a0Parrot AR\u00a0drones\u00a0they're pretty amazing, and\u00a0Andrew Nesbitt\u00a0was controlling one over wifi with\u00a0an xbox360\u00a0controller and later, a Javascript library for a Kinect. We didn't even have any injuries in the audience.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There were sessions on the latest tools for automating workflows and dependencies, such as\u00a0grunt.js\u00a0and\u00a0bower. I've used grunt.js a little over the Summer and I'm keen to put it to use on a future Drupal project where we expect it to compliment tools such as\u00a0drush.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The conference was a great opportunity for me to find out first hand about\u00a0Riak\u00a0- an open source distributed database for people with lots, and lots, and lots of data who need fault tolerance and availability over data consistency. The guys from Basho were really great to chat to and we've now got\u00a0The Little Book of Riak\u00a0in our office.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Next time I'd love to stick around for the hack day too, but overall I find conferences like Hackference are great for taking stock of other technologies and sparking ideas for both existing and new projects. For instance, I'm always struggling to remember which bin goes out at the end of the week... there's a potential side project in the form of a page scraper/parser for my local council site and a weekly email/tweet to remind me.

"}]

fields.intro: I recently had the pleasure of project managing and co-building a new site for DataKind, a New York-based organisation, which brings together data scientists and NGOs.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

I recently had the pleasure of project managing and co-building a new site for\u00a0DataKind, a New York-based organisation, which brings together data scientists and NGOs.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Their volunteer data geeks work with the data collected by NGOs, in order to make new insights \"that can solve the most complex and intractable problems we face\".

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The volunteers come from all sort of industries and give their time for free, either in weekend events known as \"DataDives\" or longer projects of up to six months known as \"DataCorps\". DataKind is also spreading its wings worldwide by setting up related organisations in other countries, most recently with DataKind UK.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

DataKind already had a design, so the challenge for us was to find a CMS that matched their needs and budget, and we decided on Mezzanine. We chose it because:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • It's free and open source
  • It's written in Django
  • Customisations\u00a0are relatively straightforward
  • It gives you the benefit of simple, complete control of the HTML markup at the templating level.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It's a fairly immature, open source project so it isn't the\u00a0best documented\u00a0system in the world, and the administration interface wouldn't object to a little UX love, but it was fun and satisfying to work with Mezzanine - and we can easily hack on it in Django.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And, working transatlantically, with no physical meetings, went pretty well (thanks Craig for getting up early for some of those calls!).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

DataKind\u00a0is\u00a0a great\u00a0organisation\u00a0and lovely to work with. If you're a data geek,\u00a0check out\u00a0the opportunities.

"}]

fields.intro: At Torchbox, we've started to invite interesting people to join us for lunch on Friday. They get a free meal in exchange for a short talk about what they do — everyone's happy!
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

At Torchbox, we've started to invite interesting people to join us for lunch on Friday. They get a free meal in exchange for a short talk about what they do \u2014 everyone's happy!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Last Friday we were treated to a talk by Niko Brian, a sound engineer/sound recordist/sound\u00a0designer\u00a0and composer from Oxford. He was recommended to us as someone who could help with sound design on an animation project we were working on.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Niko's talk was about his Record and Ride project, which saw him undertaking a 5-month cycling tour of Europe; recording local musicians as he went. Almost all of his\u00a0accommodation\u00a0on the trip was provided by the generous musicians and friends he met on his travels.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

He started out with a very loose plan of what he wanted to achieve but ended up travelling to France, Belgium, Holland, Germany, Poland, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, Italy (Bari), Greece and Israel. The musicians that he recorded would hook him up with musicians in other countries and that would become the next destination on his tour. Over the five months, he recorded in some pretty amazing places, including a sewer and an abandoned cold-war Radome in Berlin.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It was great to hear about Niko's adventure and about the serendipity you're exposed to by putting yourself out of your comfort zone.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Find out more about the trip and listen to some of the recordings he made at his website: record-and-ride.com

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to give a short talk at Torchbox,\u00a0get in touch.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

For the past few\u00a0months\u00a0I\u2019ve been spending my evenings helping to arrange\u00a0Frontend United\u00a0with a dedicated\u00a0team of Drupal users. There were times when I wanted to give up and it didn\u2019t seem like we were going to pull it off, but I plodded on through and last weekend it all came together.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Frontend United tries to pick unusual and creative locations, this year we raised the bar and picked a nightclub, we hired the \u00fcber-trendy\u00a0Cargo in Shoreditch, it wasn\u2019t without its pitfalls but it was a very inspiring and stimulating space for our attendees. You can see all the buzz about Frontend United at\u00a0eventifier.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Even though the core of the event is Drupal we tried hard to focus on frontend topics which do not solely need to be applied to Drupal. As\u00a0Bruce Lawson\u00a0mentioned in his entertaining closing talk on Saturday, we had provided a browser sandwich:\u00a0Christian Heilmann\u00a0and Bruce were first and last of our fantastic speakers on Saturday. The conference started off with an opening session from Christian, he showed us what excites him in the web world and got some of us excited about FirefoxOS. I would like to tell you more about this, but\u00a0to be honest\u00a0at this point I was outside the club with the other team members doing a little dance, ecstatic that we had actually made it - it was actually happening!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We covered a broad range of topics over the weekend.\u00a0Z\u00e9lia Sakhi\u00a0spoke about the Golden ratio in her quest for beauty in design and reminded us to try and apply the techniques we learned in art school to our websites.\u00a0Edward O'Riordan\u00a0whisked us through 800 years of art history to remind us that code is\u00a0tool\u00a0in creating modern day artwork. Then at the other end of the scale we had very specific Drupal talks from\u00a0Th\u00e9odore Biadala\u00a0about Javascript in Drupal and how to make it better, whilst\u00a0Matt Fielding\u00a0\u00a0joined\u00a0James Panton\u00a0to reprise the famous session on the\u00a0Death of a\u00a0Themer, from Drupalcamp London: revealing to us who killed the\u00a0themer; telling us how they, as designer and developer, work together harmoniously.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At the after party\u00a0Alex Pott\u00a0and\u00a0Kristof De Jaeger\u00a0committed some very important code to Drupal 8 core, which was met with a round of applause and cheers from all of the attendees. This mega patch will make deploying sites with many different field settings so much easier in future: a relief to all frontend designers who occasionally have to tinker with deployments.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I feel that even though there was such a wide range of sessions there were a few recurring take home messages:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Communicate with the team.\u00a0Constant communication with all involved helps to stay focused and achieve the desired outcome, try new things and overcome obstacles before they become unmanageable.
  • Design in the browser.\u00a0Eliminating Photoshop as much as possible and sometimes even wireframes to get to the desired outcome faster.
  • Keep pushing yourself, not only in web development but in life.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In my personal experience, the Drupal community\u00a0continue\u00a0to support me and push me through all aspects of my life, not just the crazy theming goodness that Drupal brings. Helping to organise Frontend United was my way to give a little back.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Some months ago now I gave a Torchbox University talk on Display Suite, a Drupal module that we use on pretty much all of our Drupal based sites.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Some months ago now I gave a Torchbox University talk on Display Suite, a Drupal module that we use on pretty much all of our\u00a0Drupal based\u00a0sites.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

More recently, Justine, J-P and I went to DrupalCamp London where everyone was inspired by James Panton's session, 'Death of a\u00a0themer', which proposed using tools like Display Suite to simplify Drupal's markup (and incidentally to generate unemployment by firing\u00a0themers).

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "So to back up a bit, what does Display Suite actually do?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal's standard markup output is not the cleanest, and has often been referred to as 'div soup' (in other words endless nested div tags with different classes applied). Drupal has a system of template files which allows you to control this markup and the layout on pages of the site.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These use a mixture of the PHP templating language and theming functions to determine what the page actually looks like. Of course if you're not in the business of changing Drupal's default output then you don't need template files at all, but if you want to create a good-looking site that doesn't just look like an \"out-of-the-box\" Drupal site then it's pretty inevitable that you're going to have to dig into template files at some point.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

They're not the most straightforward things to get your head around, and it's traditionally the job of\u00a0themer\u00a0to take Drupal's default output, pass it through the magic of the template files, and output some markup that is reasonably sane and lays the page out how the designer intended.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Step in Display Suite"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This module allows you to make flexible changes to the page layout using a GUI rather than via template files. While core Drupal allows some layout changes, Display Suite gives much more fine-grained control over how you order and arrange your content on the page.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With the Display\u00a0Suite\u00a0Extras module enabled you can pretty much control the markup for every single field (simple unit of content) that you output. You can set your own classes, and use any tag you like for example '<section>' and '<article>' instead of endless '<divs>'.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Behind the scenes, Display Suite still creates theming functions, but you no longer have to code them from scratch. This can help to give more consistency in your markup across the site, but also increases security. Display Suite is thoroughly tested by the community and regularly updated to prevent\u00a0cross site\u00a0scripting attacks, in a way that your own theming code can never equal.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In my Torchbox University\u00a0talk\u00a0I gave a detailed overview of how to use Display Suite. I don't plan to write that up in full here, but if you want to find out more I can recommend\u00a0this series of videos\u00a0which covers the topic in more detail than the drupal docs.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "We use Display Suite for pretty much all of our builds"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

How does this differ from James Panton's proposal of killing the\u00a0themer? James' proposal was to ditch almost all of the template files or pare them down to the very bare minimum. He recommended never using a template file, and always using modules (Display Suite included, but he also recommends\u00a0Semantic Panels). His argument is that this gives the designer complete control of the markup and CSS, makes for more consistency in the markup, and means that template files don't get abused with model logic (this basically means putting more deep level code such as database queries into the template file when it belongs elsewhere).

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "But there are big drawbacks to all of this"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

But there are big drawbacks to all of this. Apart from the fact that moving all the markup up to be entered with 'point-and-click' just doesn't *feel* right, it means that it isn't under version control. This basically means that there is no way to see a history of changes to the markup - you can only ever see the state of it at the current time - so if a big mistake is made, it's not easy to roll back.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Secondly, and worse, if someone added some dodgy PHP into a code field (hopefully not something anyone would be silly enough to do), there\u2019s a danger of\u00a0whitescreening\u00a0your whole site, with no recovery options apart from raw database updates. \u00a0Finally, given that we have a development build, a staging site and a production site for every Drupal build, the pointing and clicking potentially\u00a0has\u00a0to be done three times, unless we use Features to help distribute the \u00a0changes, which has its own complications. (As an aside, the deployment of configuration changes looks set to become much much easier in Drupal 8, but that's for another blog post).

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For our\u00a0purposes\u00a0Display Suite is great for setting up some display defaults for our White label build - the basis from which we start new Drupal sites. We also use it widely to help with different layouts of the same content -\u00a0for example\u00a0an article on the site might appear on a page in its own right, as well as in summarised form on a listing page, in a newsletter or in an RSS feed. Each of these versions of the same content needs to be output in different ways, and Display Suite handles that well. But as for ditching all our template files and killing our\u00a0themers? We'll probably hold on that for now.

"}]

fields.intro: As you may know, we built a tweet, talkin' moose last Christmas. Before we forget him completely, I want to review the short, and not always 'sweet' life of Manuel the Moose.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

As you may know, we built a tweet, talkin' moose last Christmas.\u00a0Before we forget him completely, I want to review the short, and not always 'sweet' life of Manuel the Moose.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How did you make a tweet talking Moose?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Inspired by the deer of Cornbury Park, the talking moose scene in Fawlty Towers, and Tom wanting to use 'Text to Speech', we came up with the idea of Manuel the tweet talking moose.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We ordered a fake moose head from an\u00a0ebay\u00a0reseller in\u00a0Canada,\u00a0and called Tod (an engineer friend of Olly's, who can make anything from\u00a0coil guns\u00a0to\u00a0bollock daggers) to talk about 'enhancements'.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One of our devs, Matthew, hooked into the\u00a0Twitter API\u00a0to harvest tweets with #tbxmoose in, put together a\u00a0node.js\u00a0script to pipe them into the\u00a0Festival open source speech synthesiser\u00a0and got it all running on a\u00a0Raspberry Pi, a computer small enough to fit in a\u00a0Moose\u00a0head.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Meanwhile\u00a0Tod dusted off his animatronics chops,\u00a0lopped\u00a0Manuel's lower jaw off, added the necessary bits and bobs and put him back together again complete with fake teeth and lolling tongue.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The audio feed attaches to this handy little\u00a0Autotalk Interface Board, which moves the servo in response to audio or speech. The signal is split so it goes into the Autotalk board and into a speaker. Now we can hear Manuel speaking and see his jaw moving, at the same time.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Sarah and James designed and built the site, We rigged up a webcam, hooked it into Ustream \u00a0and\u00a0Manuel went live.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Was he a success?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Good question. The figures tell of a pretty successful Christmas stunt:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Manuel was live for about a week and was viewed\u00a022,316 times
  • The biggest referrer was\u00a0Raspberry Pi with 2.667\u00a0followed by Spiegel and Reddit
  • Ustream clocked up\u00a02453.4 viewing hours
  • Manuel was tweeted\u00a08046 times\u00a0with another\u00a01201 messages\u00a0via the web form (which we turned off on day two)
  • Best celebrity tweet was by Brian Blessed
  • Most popular tweet:\u00a0'There's a moose loose about this hoose'
  • Number of tweets blocked by profanity filter:\u00a0349
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

However, Manuel was not the perfect office mate. He wasn't always witty and original. He often repeated himself (normally one word over and over). He \u00a0mis-spelt\u00a0his way around the swear filter. He was scrupulous when reading out backslashes and other special character aitch-tea-tea-pea-colon-backslash-backslash and so on.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Did I mention his accent?\u00a0Well\u00a0lets\u00a0just say that open source text to speech voices aren't as polished as the nice lady on your TomTom.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Probably the worst thing about Manuel was that he could be senselessly offensive at times. There are plenty of\u00a0potty mouthed\u00a0Twitter users out there, and they don't mind what goes on their Twitter streams. Of course, we knew this might happen, but we figured we could take it. Some of the time, it turned out that we couldn't!

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "So, what has become of him?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Manuel's servo, or the audio driver, packed up on Dec 24th. This was pretty much expected as he wasn't specced to last. We have spares of\u00a0both,\u00a0but haven't got round to fixing him yet.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I'd like to fire him up again, and have him speak out @torchbox tweets in the office. We don't get THAT many, and they generally aren't offensive.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "So, what are you going to do next year?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Nothing that speaks out loud in our office, that's for sure!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In fact, we may take a break next year. After doing many cool things over the last few years, we don't want to do it just because we feel that we should; we don't want it to be like that. So, we may not do a 'Christmas card' next year. Perhaps we'll turn our attention to 'valentine's day' or 'bonfire day' or 'cycle to work day' instead. Any which way, we'll do our next fun site because we are excited by an idea, rather than because we feel we ought to.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Adios Manuel, RIP.

"}]

fields.intro: Nuffield Trust asked us to redesign all of their email templates, wanting a facelift to bring their templates in line with the rest of their site. We ended up completely rethinking the way they communicate with their subscribers, leading to a big improvement in click-throughs.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Nuffield Trust asked us to redesign all of their email templates, wanting a facelift to bring their templates in line with the rest of their site. We ended up completely rethinking the way they communicate with their subscribers, leading to a big improvement in click-throughs.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Email templates aren\u2019t the sexiest projects to be working on but they can be an important part of an organisation\u2019s digital marketing. Nuffield Trust came to us with a set of wireframes but I asked Claire Richardson, our client at Nuffield Trust if she\u2019d mind us trying something a bit different. It was a big departure from the existing approach, but they were interested in our ideas.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There were a few issues with Nuffield Trust\u2019s existing emails that we helped to address.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Copywriting"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Each email felt like a formal letter from their Director including a \u201cDear\u2026\u201d and a signature at the bottom. For a modern and forward thinking\u00a0organisation\u00a0this was coming across as stuffy. We suggested breaking down the copy into discrete points - each with an individual action. People don\u2019t have time to read long emails and tend to scan headlines. Breaking down the content in this way made the information more engaging and easier to scan.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Layout"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Over the years, HTML emails have morphed into mini versions of an organisation\u2019s website. The problem with this is that multi-column layouts are hard to scan \u2014 should I be reading top to bottom or left to right? I wanted Nuffield Trust to use a single column and focus on a single lead item at the top, listing other content, in order of importance, underneath. People glance quickly at newsletters, so you have to get them interested straight away; we lead with a big striking image followed by a nicely laid out list of content below, allowing recipients to easily scan through the items. There\u2019s a nice blog from Campaign Monitor that includes some eye-tracking research to illustrate why this is a good idea: Email usability: The science of keeping it short and sweet.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Mobile"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When the existing email templates were originally conceived, mobile wasn\u2019t really a consideration. However, a significant number of Nuffield Trusts subscribers were opening their emails on smartphones and would have been finding them difficult to read as the text was so small. With all email templates, you\u2019re very much at the mercy of the email client but we were able to do lots with the iPhone\u2019s native Mail app, which made up a large proportion of Nuffield Trust\u2019s mobile users.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There were some other benefits too \u2014 Nuffield Trust\u2019s main typeface, Futura, is a standard iOS font, meaning we could keep the emails on brand and fallback to Helvetica and Arial for other users. Campaign Monitor\u2019s Responsive Mobile Guide is a great starting point to see what\u2019s possible with mobile on email these days.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We took a mobile first approach to the redesign, which helped to trim down the content to the minimum that needs to be there to get users to click through to full articles or to download reports.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The result"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Nuffield Trust\u00a0were\u00a0really pleased with the end result and so\u00a0were\u00a0we. Click through rates instantly went up by 10% and the emails look modern and are easier to read both of desktop and mobile. However, one of the best things to come out of the re-design is that Nuffield Trust\u00a0have\u00a0changed the way they communicate with their audience. Gone are the long, stuffy formal letters and scrappy images, which have been replaced but eye-catching photos and snappy copy.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Since the redesign, Claire Richardson and the rest of the organisation have done a great job with editorial \u2014 keeping the copy short and using images well. I now get a little glow of satisfaction every time one of their emails drops into my inbox.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Sign up for Nuffield Trust's newsletter here.

"}]

fields.intro: Read our highlights from Google's recent event in London. Topics include the client-agency relationship, mobile, YouTube, social media, Google Analytics and AdWords.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Torchbox were invited to the Google Engage: Box of Tricks 2012 event in London on Friday 23 November 2012. Here are the insights that got us excited:

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Client-agency relationship"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Is monthly reporting always necessary? Some agencies are no longer creating monthly reports and are instead setting up dashboards so their clients can log in themselves and see reports on demand.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Mobile"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here's how Adidas designed a mobile attribution model to assign a value to clicks on the store locator link on their mobile website:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • They assumed that 20% of people who use the store locator will visit a store.
  • 20% of those who visit a store will make a purchase.
  • Average\u00a0in-store purchase is $80.
  • Average value of a click on the store locator is $3.20 (0.2 x 0.2 x 80).
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Clicks on the store locator are therefore valuable to their business and were encouraged by placing it in a more prominent position at the top of the mobile page.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "YouTube"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • People watch on average two hours of video a week on YouTube. This places YouTube on the same level of influence as TV channels such as BBC2 and Channel 4.
  • YouTube advertisers don't pay for clicks when users skip their ads in the first 5 seconds.
  • 20% of users choose not to skip ads on YouTube.
  • Charities and not-for-profit organisations should apply for the\u00a0YouTube Nonprofit Program\u00a0to get an optimised YouTube channel (worth about \u00a340,000).
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Social media"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Organisations should set up and maintain a Google+ page to enable the \"knowledge panel\" in the right-hand column of Google SERPs and dominate their brand terms.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Google Analytics"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Segment internal site search queries by paid search users to see where your landing pages are falling short: what users were expecting to see but didn't find. This is also a good source of new AdWords keywords.
  • Segment \"true new visitors\" with a custom advanced segment by excluding brand keywords, email campaigns, direct visitors and users who login.
  • \"Universal Analytics\"\u00a0is coming in 2013, providing the functionality to track the same user's actions across multiple channels and devices. Google plan to make it possible to import CRM data into Google Analytics.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "AdWords"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • One of the most creative uses we've seen of Google Trends is using it to\u00a0predict who's going to win the X-Factor final\u00a0without actually having to watch the show! According to recent search trends in the UK, you should have put your money on Union J - whoever they are - in mid-November. It's a good job we didn't because apparently they got kicked off last week! However, this method did\u00a0correctly predict the US presidential election.
  • New AdWords features to look out for in 2013 include the communication extension, which will allow advertisers to collect email sign-ups in search ads.
  • Google will also be rolling out remarketing for search ads. This will help advertisers retarget the 96% of users who click on an ad and leave without performing the advertiser's desired action and the 70% of users who click on an ad but abandon the shopping cart.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The importance of the long tail:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • 20% of daily searches haven't occurred on Google in the past 3 months.
  • Nearly 40% of search queries are longer than three words.
"}]

fields.intro: We've found Jekyll to be really useful in the creation of websites and in the delivery of HTML for use in other CMS. Combined with Github Pages, it's a powerful toolset.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We've found Jekyll to be really useful in the creation of websites and in the delivery of HTML for use in other CMS. Combined with Github Pages, it's a powerful toolset.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Not all of our work involves Django or Drupal. Although we love them, there are times when a considerably simplified approach to content management is all that's necessary.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We've recently launched several small sites which don't need to be regularly updated by a large number of editors. In these situations a custom Django application, even an out-the-box Django CMS could be overkill. Drupal similarly might be a sledgehammer to this proverbial nut. Instead, we've turned to a 'Static Site Generator'.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are several static site generators out there:\u00a0Jekyll,\u00a0Hyde,\u00a0Middleman\u00a0and more. Jekyll has arguably the larger following and for this reason (among others) is our site generator of choice.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For\u00a0oxford.geeknights.net,\u00a0digitaloxford.com\u00a0and\u00a0symplectic.co.uk\u00a0we're using Jekyll's limited, predetermined concept of chronological, related content e.g blog posts, news items etc. The news or blog item can be written without HTML, using\u00a0markdown\u00a0or similar, then Jekyll converts it to HTML and inserts the item automatically into the listing of news/blogs on the site. This is pretty much the limit of content management in most static site generators. It's very basic, but it's often all we need.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Behind\u00a0this\u00a0we're using\u00a0Github Pages\u00a0as the host. Github Pages is a service in which a Github repository is used as the source directory for a website which Github host for you. Pages\u00a0is\u00a0particularly handy because it supports Jekyll projects by default. If you commit a Jekyll-configured directory into your repository, Github can compile, deploy and host your Jekyll website whenever you make a \"push\" request to Github.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If a simpler editing interface than Github is needed, we'd recommend\u00a0prose.io. It provides a simplified git repository browser with a file editor and new file creator (something that at\u00a0time\u00a0of writing Github doesn't provide) that neatly sidesteps detailed command line git knowledge.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Version control, code editor, deployment tool and hosting all rolled into one and for free? Sign me up!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The fun doesn't have to stop here. We use Jekyll for front end projects even when we're not hosting or deploying the site ourselves. And, sometimes not even for websites at all!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Where the deliverables are purely\u00a0front-end\u00a0files (HTML, JS, CSS) Jekyll can still help with the templating. We've used it recently generating sets of\u00a0Campaign Monitor\u00a0HTML email templates and\u00a0dynamic maps for the World Economic Forum. Jekyll comes with the Liquid templating engine (from Shopify) so if you're\u00a0componentising\u00a0sections of code for reuse over a variety of templates or simply sharing the same header/footer between several similar pages, Liquid helps you with a very simple syntax.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our client doesn't necessarily know or care what Jekyll is in this instance. What matters is that our code is maintainable and modular and this translates to clear benefits to everyone.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Previously front-end developers might have delivered HTML mixed with PHP or Apache SSIs - they would have needed some kind of \"include\" technology during development. They'd probably deliver the files to the client as they are, accompanied\u00a0with\u00a0documentation about installing the require software and caveats about how the HTML they've delivered isn't actually complete without Apache/PHP so can't be double-clicked to be viewed.\u00a0All in all,\u00a0it wasn't a particularly satisfying experience for the client or developer.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With\u00a0Jekyll\u00a0we're delivering complete, static HTML pages which can be launched straight away or drag-dropped into the browser. When reviewing files is this simple, quick sign-off, rapid iteration and design in the browser becomes more realistic too.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Interestingly President Obama's 2011/12 fundraising campaign was recently\u00a0blogged about by Kyle Rush\u00a0and it turns out they too were using static site generators - specifically Jekyll - at the core of their technology stack.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

What's clear from our experience and Kyle's is that having the right tools for the job is vital and Jekyll has become an invaluable tool in our box.

"}]

fields.intro: Google Analytics is full of hidden treasures that some website owners don't use. Learn about eight features you should know about and follow our best practice tips.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Google Analytics is full of hidden treasures that some website owners don't use. Learn about eight features you should know about and follow our best practice tips.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Last week was the seventh anniversary of the launch of Google Analytics, so we decided to mark the occasion by highlighting seven features you should be aware of and one new kid on the block that might revolutionise how you track user journeys on your site. We'll also propose some best practice guidelines and pose one problem we haven't figured out yet.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

But first,\u00a0naming\u00a0of parts.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Account vs Property vs View"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Google Analytics n00bs are sometimes confused by the terminology of the GA structure. I got my head round it this way:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

An\u00a0account\u00a0is\u00a0the top-level. But what's the difference between a\u00a0property\u00a0and a\u00a0view? A property in GA could be your main website, your blog or a mobile app. A view (aka profile) is a subset of data about a property. It's at the view level that you access reports and filter your data. You can set up a view to\u00a0exclude\u00a0traffic from your organisation's office IP address or to isolate traffic from your\u00a0Google Grants ads. We'll revisit views in our best practice tips later on.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "8 things you should be aware of"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#1 Tracking multiple domains or subdomains"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You can track traffic across multiple domains or subdomains in a single GA property. This is useful if your user journeys\u00a0spans\u00a0more than one domain or subdomain - for example, users might read about an event on www.example.com/event, buy a ticket on shop.example.com and return to www.example.com/thank-you for confirmation of their order. Ideally, your conversion funnel would track that whole process. If you didn't have multiple subdomain tracking set up, you'd lose track of users when they left the event page for the shop.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We'd like to see new GA instances set up with multiple\u00a0domain\u00a0tracking as standard so that you can accommodate new subdomains in your default property at a later date. If you want reports on a subdomain in isolation, you can create a separate filtered profile for that.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#2 Advanced segments"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These are filters you apply to your data after it's in the account. For example, you can compare paid and non-paid search traffic. You can also define custom segments. We created an advanced segment to exclude one of our client's branded keywords from their search traffic reports.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#3 Event tracking"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You can track user actions (or \"events\") such as a PDF downloads, clicks on a video's play button or even clicks on your navigation links. GA now allows you to convert events into conversion goals and import them into AdWords so you can better optimise your ad campaigns.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#4 Ecommerce tracking"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Not all sites have a need for\u00a0ecommerce\u00a0tracking, but for any that collect donations or sell products, this is essential. You'll need to install a bit of extra code to get it working.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#5 Google Analytics debugger"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There's a handy\u00a0Chrome extension\u00a0that shows you what data is passed to GA when a page loads.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#6 Site search"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you have a search function on your site, set this up to gather users' search queries. Next time you redesign your\u00a0site architecture, you'll know what they couldn't find. It's also a great source of SEO and\u00a0PPC\u00a0keywords and can highlight gaps in your site's content or navigation.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#7 Content experiments"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Formerly known as Google Website Optimizer but now fully integrated into GA, content experiments enable you to run A/B tests on your pages to compare the effectiveness of different designs and layouts. Use it to optimize landing or conversion pages.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "#8 Google Tag Manager"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Finally, the new kid on the block. Google launched this product on 1 October 2012 to help marketers manage all their tracking tags in one place. Install a single snippet of code in the <body> and define which tags are fired with rules you set in Google Tag Manager. You can use this to manage standard tags for Google Analytics and AdWords as well as custom tags e.g. for a checkout process or confirmation page. Once it's set up, marketers can create tags for new campaigns and products without further technical assistance from a developer.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Google Analytics best practice tips"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Leave a default GA view untouched to gather all data. If you're going to apply filters, create separate views\u2026
  • \u2026For example, exclude your organisation's office IP address in a new view.
  • Insert the GA tracking snippet immediately before the closing </head> tag, not in the <body>\u2026
  • \u2026If you do, you'll be able to verify your site easily in Google Webmaster Tools.
  • Associate your Webmaster Tools account with your GA account in the admin property settings to import SEO data on search queries and landing pages into the traffic sources report.
  • If you've got an AdWords account, link it to GA via your\u00a0Google Analytics\u00a0property settings.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Now that you've read all our advice, how about a little payback?

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "A problem we'd like you to fix"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We haven't yet figured out how to set up event tracking on embedded third-party code such as Vimeo,\u00a0SoundCloud\u00a0and Slideshare. If you know a good solution, get in touch with me on Twitter\u00a0@domeheid.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Torchbox University sessions are held weekly (normally on Wednesdays). They last for up to an hour including Q & A and clients and friends are welcome to attend. Follow us on\u00a0Twitter\u00a0for notifications of upcoming sessions.

"}]

fields.intro: Each year, the brilliant folk at the World Economic Forum (WEF) create a Global Competitiveness Index "providing insight into the drivers of their productivity and prosperity". This post tells how we built them a map visualisation of the Index, which has featured on the Guardian, Economist, LA Times, Chicago Tribune and more.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Each year, the brilliant folk at the World Economic Forum (WEF) create a Global Competitiveness Index \"providing insight into the drivers of their productivity and prosperity\".\u00a0This post tells how we built them a map visualisation of the Index, which has featured on the Guardian, Economist, LA Times, Chicago Tribune and more.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The map is an engaging way into the Global Competitiveness Index. Designed to be embedded, it will automatically centre itself on your country of location. We built it as part of a programme, we are working on with WEF, to help drive links and traffic to the Global Competitiveness Report - and it is doing just that.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And it will carry on delivering. As Fernando Zarur, Associate Director of Digital Content at\u00a0WEF,\u00a0puts it:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

\"This sort of content is a way to explore the long-tail potential of our publications, working as channels of continuous interaction that can be maintained and updated year after year, extend sharing, benefitting SEO and hopefully making our different web channels grow in relevance.\"

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The visualisation uses mapping services from\u00a0Mapbox.com\u00a0and some custom code largely reliant on\u00a0Mustache.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mapbox.com provided the key ingredients:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Tilemill: a desktop application for creating and styling map tiles and merging\u00a0geo-spacial\u00a0data
  • Mapbox hosting: a worldwide network of servers which serve up your tiles from the nearest data centre to your users
  • Mapbox.js: a javascript library for adding the maps to your\u00a0html\u00a0and adding the fancy bells and whistles
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tilemill\u00a0is the real story here. It's a powerful tool used to add layers of data to a map of the world. Tilemill comes with some well-featured examples, but without your own dataset of points/shapes to display, its purpose is less clear.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Your data has to be provided in some specific formats (SQLite, PostGIS or\u00a0Shape files) which require some work in themselves, but these can also be generated by other freely available third party tools. We used the country boundary lines shape files\u00a0provided free by Natural Earth\u00a0and combined the Competitiveness data from WEF using\u00a0QGIS, a cross-platform desktop cartography program.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Once the data is imported, you can completely customise the visual style using CartoCSS, a language with a syntax closely resembling\u00a0LESSCSS, in which individual points, countries, cities, streets, their labels etc can be customised to suit your preferred colour scheme. Using just a handful of lines of CartoCSS, we colour coded each of the countries based on\u00a0it's\u00a0rank in the Competitiveness Index.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our custom code uses the Mustache templating language to display the raw Competitiveness data in a popup when you click on one of the countries.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mapbox also\u00a0curate\u00a0some other projects we had less time to play with which are worth further investigation:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • The\u00a0MBTiles specification: a standard for graphical tile and data storage in SQLite databases,
  • Wax: a javascript \"gateway\" providing a standard way to add functionality and features provided by other third party Javascript map libraries, to maps from sources such as google,\u00a0openstreetmap\u00a0etc as well as mapbox.com themselves.
"}]

fields.intro: We make heavy use of drush make in our builds, which usually includes a new Drupal core.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We make heavy use of drush make in our builds, which usually includes a new Drupal core.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

By default, Drupal installs with a robots.txt file in the root. For those of us that use the\u00a0robotstxt\u00a0module, one of the installation steps is to delete this file. This allows Drupal to handle the HTTP request and it allows site administrators to manage the contents of their robots file through the admin interface.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When you\u2019re rolling out automated deployments of entire Drupal sites the last thing you want to do is have to delete that file each and every time. There are a few potential solutions to this problem - perhaps a post-install process to tidy up the file - but we opted to submit a patch into the robotstxt module's\u00a0issue queue.\u00a0This patch adds a rewrite rule into the .htaccess file that always ensures Drupal handles requests for robots.txt. This means we don\u2019t have to delete the robots.txt file and can deploy/redeploy sites that use\u00a0robotstxt\u00a0safely.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The patch affects a file that is part of Drupal core and while we\u2019re aware this is normally something to avoid, we have a really specific requirement and the patch is part of an automated process. This means we can easily take it out and redeploy the entire build when a more suitable solution is available.

"}]

fields.intro: Over the last few months, we've been working on a great project with Yahoo! France and iTélé. It's called Cher Président and it's a participative ideas and voting site, set up for the French Presidential election in April 2012.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Over the last few months, we've been working on a great project with Yahoo! France and iT\u00e9l\u00e9. It's called Cher Pr\u00e9sident and it's a participative ideas and voting site, set up for the French Presidential election in April 2012.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

How does it work? Well, it's pretty simple; someone submits an idea to Cher Pr\u00e9sident and the crowd votes on it. The ideas with the most votes float to the top of the leaderboard and the best ideas each month get displayed around the Yahoo! Ad Network, get turned into cartoons, and are discussed by big cheese politicos on iT\u00e9l\u00e9's current affairs TV show.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Cher Pr\u00e9sident was inspired by a project that Yahoo! ran for the General Election in the UK . We've worked with Yahoo! France to design and build a French equivalent, that has great participation levels and has better integration with Yahoo! Actualit\u00e9s' Presidential Election content. And, we're delighted to say, so far so good. In just over three weeks, we've had over 10,000 ideas submitted and a whopping 2 million votes cast!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are still almost two months to go until the first round of voting on 22nd April, and we're striving to get the most out of Cher Pr\u00e9sident, so watch out for how it all changes in the last month of the campaign.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about\u00a0Cher Pr\u00e9sident, or how we can help with your upcoming tech project, please get in touch.

"}]

fields.intro: Right, it's the end of November 2011 and we've been so busy on client work that we haven't got around to the agency christmas card. And, no, we can't just quietly forget about it either.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Right, it's the end of November 2011 and we've been so busy\u00a0on\u00a0client work that we haven't got around to the agency Christmas\u00a0card. And, no, we can't just quietly forget about it either.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Thanks to the great Christmas cards that we've produced over the last couple of years ('Snowtime' and 'Starry night' to name two), expectations were high, and our friends were letting us know it. Cue the brainstorm.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The challenge"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • it must stand out, even amongst all the other agency Christmas cards
  • it can't take too long (we didn't have long)
  • it must involve the whole team\u00a0
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The idea"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A few hours later, the Torchbox Choir was born. Each member of the crew was recorded singing a single note and we combined them into musical arrangements of various popular Christmas carols. It shows off our technical virtuosity, makes us look a bit silly (hopefully in an endearing way), and has some shareability.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Torchbox Christmas Choir", "image": 1310, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And, that was the basic idea, before the 'builds' started. Actually, that remained the basic idea, we just added a few jingle bells and\u00a0whistles,\u00a0and ended up with a pretty sophisticated web-based keyboard on which anyone can compose and record tunes performed by the Torchbox choir (have a go, if you think you are musical enough). You can even arrange a tune offline and import it into the Choir.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The result"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The result was something a bit special (especially if you know some of our team and appreciate their vocal contributions!). The\u00a0carols,\u00a0are great, but the standout number (for me, at least) is the choir's rendition of the Nightrider theme tune. If you haven't heard it, listen to it now. Happily, this one found it's way\u00a0onto\u00a0the playlist of the Hoff himself, who tweeted his appreciation:

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "David Hasselhoff's tweet about the Torchbox Christmas Choir", "image": 1311, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The project won third place in the IAB's Creative Showcase for December.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We're delighted\u00a0to report that, having been nominated in two categories, our work on the\u00a0Nuffield Trust\u00a0website has been recognised with a 2011\u00a0Bima Award\u00a0in the Health & Healthcare category.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're really proud of our new Drupal-powered site for Nuffield Trust. It is a major new website for the health and social care community and a huge step forward for the Trust.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Nuffield Trust are one of the most important health policy think tanks and a key voice in the discussions about the future of the NHS.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This project has been a\u00a0full scale\u00a0redevelopment from full discovery with audience consultation, persona development, and stakeholder workshops through to design and build.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The audience of health professionals, academics and policy makers will now be able to access an exciting range of Nuffield Trust's\u00a0talks,\u00a0data visualisations,\u00a0analysis\u00a0and\u00a0reports.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is a significant, new Drupal site for Torchbox that includes a range of exciting interactive elements including\u00a0dynamic charts\u00a0and\u00a0maps, and a number of content pieces like the\u00a0PBRA animation\u00a0that will bring the Trust's important work to life.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about the website we created for Nuffield Health, or want to discuss your exciting project, please get in touch.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Could your non-profit organization be entitled to $10,000 free ad spend a month?
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Could your non-profit organization be entitled to $10,000 free ad spend a month?

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What is a Google Grant and how do you qualify?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A Google Ad Grant is $10,000 a month of free AdWordsadvertising that Google gives to selected charities to promote their websites. It entitles the charity to run free keyword-targeted text ads on Google search results pages.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you meet certain criteria, you can also upgrade to $40,000 a month with\u00a0Grantspro.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Are there any restrictions on how I can spend the advertising budget?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Yes, you are limited to a budget of $330 a day and the maximum bid you can place in an ad auction (the system Google uses to decide which ads are displayed next to search results) is $2 per click. You are also only allowed to run text-based ads on Google search results pages, not on any of Google's other search and display networks. So you couldn't run a banner ad on the\u00a0Guardian\u00a0website or a video ad on YouTube. For\u00a0that,\u00a0you would need a separate paid AdWords account.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Is my organization eligible to apply for a Google Grant?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You're eligible if you're a charity or non-profit organization based in the UK and registered with the Charity Commission of England and Wales, the Office of the Scottish Charity Regulator or the Inland Revenue. However, some non-profits are ineligible, including governmental entities and organizations, commercial organizations selling goods and services, membership groups, and political or religious groups, so it's worth checking the\u00a0eligibility\u00a0criteria. Google Grants are also available in other countries.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Sounds great! How do I apply?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you think your organization may be eligible, read through Google's explanation of how it works and then (if your organization is based in the UK and registered with the Charity Commission for England and Wales) apply to the\u00a0Google for Nonprofits\u00a0programme.\u00a0You'll find most of the information you need in your organization's mission statement, the\u00a0Charity Commission\u00a0website, and Google Analytics. You may also want to do a bit of keyword research using the\u00a0AdWords Keyword Planner.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Organizations in\u00a0Scotland and Northern Ireland should apply here.\u00a0Other countries\u00a0have their own application process.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How long do I have to wait?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Google will review your website and application and will notify you by email whether or not you've been successful. If you're approved, you will then have to set up your AdWords account and submit that for further approval before your $10,000 monthly budget is activated. It can take up to four months for Google to approve the application. In our experience, it took a month for Google to approve the initial application and a further month to active the AdWords account once it had been set up. In total, it took three months from application to getting the first ads up and running. But it can take much less than that.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Torchbox is a\u00a0Google Partner.

"}]

fields.intro: We take a look at how brands are increasingly using perks to reach influencers.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We take a look at how brands are increasingly using perks to reach influencers.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "A tweet arrives..."}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

'Hello - you've been selected by Down Under Airways because of your online influence to receive a free trip to Australia!'

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Do you think:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • A) This is some sort of scam. That stuff only happens to celebs off the telly...
  • B) Get in! That time and effort I've spent in becoming influential about travel on Twitter\u00a0is\u00a0paying off...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I get option A. Free stuff has been given to celebrities for years in the hope that they'll wear it or talk about it. Until recently I don't think B would have happened much. Social has changed all that. It is no longer just traditional media channels who have the power to wield reach and influence.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Each of us who are on Twitter, Facebook, Google+, etc. are a kind of media channel. We're broadcasting information to an audience. Some people have become quite BIG so they have. They have\u00a0reach, they're respected by their audience, they wield influence.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So I guess it's natural that brands would give them some VIP treatment. Particularly as my guess is that when those who live in the real world get cool stuff, they are probably going to talk about it to their circles.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And brands are increasingly looking to give influencers VIP treatment. This is in part due to\u00a0enterprising\u00a0folk, at companies, who measure and reward influence. I'm thinking of\u00a0Klout\u00a0(self-proclaimed\u00a0'standard for online influence') and PeerIndex (recently tied up with eConsultancy to find the top 100 most influential people in digital marketing) in particular who both have algorithms that decide how influential a person is. They give a score out of 100. They tell you what they are influential about.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These players in the influencer market need to drive revenue and brands want to target influencers. Put these factors together and you get the Perks programmes which both have been rolling out. Programmes that see tweets like the made up one at the top of this blog post turning up...here are some examples to read up on:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Now at a recent Social Media Council meeting, I mentioned Klout and PeerIndex as something to debate. The debate was lively. It was heated. It could have gone the distance. But unfortunately the bell went and the bout was cut short...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My view is that if these companies can help brands get the right message to the right people (who might just pass it on to their mates) they have got a bright future \u2013 but I'd love to hear your thoughts...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

What do you think of measuring influence in this way? Would you use\u00a0this kind\u00a0of service? Would you be happy to receive perks?

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

P.S. A very big hello to anyone from Klout who happens to stumble upon this. My score seems to move between 50-60 and\u00a0I'm\u00a0influential about media, marketing, Facebook, and apps. However, I also feel I should be considered influential on\u00a0curry\u00a0and the Octonauts. So if you could please tweak your algorithms accordingly and fix it for me to receive perks on these subjects I would very much appreciate it.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Perks rock don't they?

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This article was first published on IAB UK.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Seven years after our first University of Oxford website, we were commissioned to redesign and rebuild it. I'd been looking at the site for a few years thinking how great it would be to be able to get another crack at it, so we were really excited to get the chance.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Seven years after our first University of Oxford\u00a0website, we were commissioned to redesign and rebuild it. I'd been looking at the site for a few years thinking how great it would be to be able to get another crack at it, so we were really excited to get the chance.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In its time, the University of Oxford website had been the top-rated university site in a Times Education Supplement survey and was much imitated (even copied!). However, after more than seven years of duty, it had become dated and, critically, it wasn't responsive.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Oxford's Radcliffe Square", "image": 137, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

From experience, we knew that the team (ours and Oxford's) would be answerable to a huge number of stakeholders \u2013 the administrative hierarchy, the departments and divisions, the colleges, and the myriad arms of the University. We knew that our ideas would need to have a solid rationale behind them; and they'd need to be research-based, user-tested and preferably guided by a clear, agreed vision.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So, we set out to establish a set of principles that could help guide the project. We've used principles successfully before \u2013 it's particularly useful where there isn't\u00a0clear\u00a0hierarchy of objectives \u2013 but the\u00a0best known\u00a0example of their use is by\u00a0gov.uk\u00a0and this has definitely influenced the way that we use principles.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "GDS Design Principles", "image": 1307, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We got together with the project team to define digital principles and principles for the information architecture. We ended up with eight digital principles, which guide both the approach to design:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

\"\u2026life at the University should come bursting through in every page and piece of content, reflecting Oxford's unique character.\"

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

and the development of the content:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

\"\u2026great content keeps interested users coming back and engages disinterested users. Great design helps the content to do this.\"

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Similarly, we had some guidelines for information architecture. I like MIT professor John Maeda's Ten Laws of Simplicity, especially laws one and two. They are useful when addressing the need to reduce options in navigation to\u00a0avoid paralysis.\u00a0In this case,\u00a0we set out to limit ourselves to a maximum of six links in any menu structure [1] - the\u00a0power of information scent\u00a0does the rest.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "The Laws of Simplicity by John Maeda", "image": 1309, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We refined our new site map, following testing using\u00a0Treejack, Optimal Sort's automated remote tree testing tool, incorporating several different test setups for different audience types.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It was important to start working in the browser as early as possible, so \u2013 as is often now the case \u2013 we opted to do HTML prototypes rather than conventional wireframes.

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/0Dpn6mawkj4"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And, this progressed into our 'design in the browser' process. Here's a version of page mid-way through the design process.

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/9OJV6OtK3zk"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Normally we manage user testing ourselves, but to be absolutely robust we were keen that testing was conducted independently. Bunnyfoot were selected to manage this process which included wide consultation within Oxford to make sure that people had the opportunity to feed in. It provoked a few design changes and helped to guide us to the final designs.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Jump forward to now and the new site has been successfully up and running for several months. One of the markers of success has definitely been the internal acceptance of the site as well as some positive feedback from external users.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Footnotes"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • I'm referring to page menus here. Structured categorisations for specific types of content can be much longer lists because they are normally organised alphabetically, so are easier to scan and search.
  • Neither the prototype nor this more worked-up version are functionally perfect, at this point in the process we are trying things out and agreeing direction rather than creating flawless HTML, CSS or JavaScript.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about the University of Oxford website, or how we can help you with your upcoming project, please\u00a0get in touch.

"}]

fields.intro: Medieval Icelandic writings spoke of Sunstones, a mineral that allowed the seafaring vikings to locate the sun in a completely overcast sky. Here are my six sunstones for social media.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Medieval Icelandic writings spoke of Sunstones, a mineral that allowed the seafaring\u00a0vikings\u00a0to locate the sun in a completely overcast sky.\u00a0Here are my six sunstones for social media.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There was a big developmental leap in navigation tools when holding a rock at the sky turned into\u00a0holding a stick. Navigators were essentially being asked to find the way and not doom the entire crew by looking very hard.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Today, there are satellites.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Sunstone", "image": 249, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The seas of social media probably have the tools of the 15th century, where the best navigators have compasses, sextants, star\u00a0charts\u00a0and hourglasses. Although, once in a while all you\u2019ve got left is to go outside and look at the sky. With a rock in your hand.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here are my six sunstones. My most basic tools for not getting dashed on the social media rocks to help us to do the best we can for our clients.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "1. Google Spreadsheets"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is always\u00a0a first\u00a0step for me. I create a spreadsheet so that planning,\u00a0recording\u00a0and tracking\u00a0is\u00a0all in one place. I know that there are probably more complicated tools to project manage a social media account, but I like the simplicity and easy way multiple people can work on posts. Even if I was working alone on a social media channel, I like to keep drafts of what I\u2019m doing.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Google spreadsheet", "image": 142, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here, I\u2019ve even\u00a0made you a template\u00a0to get you\u00a0stated. Look out for comments (little orange corners\u00a0on\u00a0the cell) to give you hints.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Be sure to make a copy to your own Google Drive.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "2. Bitly"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You\u2019ll notice the Spreadsheet template has \u201cclicks\u201d (on the 'Results' tab of the sheet\"). For this, I create a Bitly account for every social media channel I manage. That means there can be less confusion as to the number of clicks I deliver which is important for some clients. Be aware, the \u201cclicks\u201d from Facebook Insights are not the same as clicks on a URL as they include clicks on images, clicks to expand comments etc.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "3. Google URL Builder"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is always useful as it allows you to create tracking parameters for a link that will go on your social media channels. This means you can track, for example, how many people complete a petition action on your website from a request on Facebook, Twitter, or on Google+. It\u2019s really easy to use and incredibly useful.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "4. TwitterCounter"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Sometimes, you just need to know how many Twitter followers you had on a particular day about 3 months ago. Finding this out on using any system will not give you a 100% accurate figure because of the nature of how Twitter works, but I like TwitterCounter as it will give you a simple graph showing your follower growth over time.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I do recommend signing in with your Twitter account to get the most out of it. The free version lets you see your follower growth over the past 3 months. Premium lets you go back up to 6 months as well as a bunch of other stats.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "5. Topsy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is a great little tool. It can count the number of Tweets that have used a keyword or a hashtag over the past 30 days, ideal if you want to keep track of a campaign and drill down into types of tweet or language. I really like the ability to compare the use of 3 keywords alongside each other.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This could also be a great way to find and follow similar accounts to you. And of the best things about it? There\u2019s\u00a0lot\u00a0of great data available on the free version.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "6. Sprout Social"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Probably not a sunstone, this is more like my version of an\u00a0octant.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Whilst the other five tools are free to use with possible premium additions, Sprout Social is a paid service and my management tool of choice. The costs are $59 per user/month or $99 per user/month, depending on the service you need. I\u2019m often having to track many social media streams and need the data for reporting in one easily searchable place. The collaborative tools are quite useful, such as the Smart Inbox. It is great at keeping an eye on every incoming message. Nothing should slip through the net. I\u2019ve been impressed with the mobile apps and very impressed with their support services, who are quick to answer and solve almost any question.

"}]

fields.intro: Watch the Wagtail launch event video to find out how Wagtail came about and what our users have to say about it.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Earlier this month, we staged an event in the Senior Common Room at the\u00a0Royal College of Art\u00a0where we had the chance to introduce Wagtail to interested parties.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It was a great night of presentations,\u00a0demonstrations,\u00a0and conversations. All washed down with a nice glass of wine, tasty\u00a0canap\u00e9s,\u00a0and delicious Wagtail cupcakes!

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/MQj2vI59sIo"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To get a feel for the occasion, find out what Wagtail is all about and why people are enjoying working with Wagtail please do take a minute to watch the video.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like If you'd like to discuss any opportunities you have to work with Wagtail or if you'd like any more information, please do get in touch.

"}]

fields.intro: The big bits in the latest version of Wagtail.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We\u2019re aiming to share point releases of Wagtail on a monthly basis,\u00a0around\u00a0the end of each month.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Point releases\u00a0are traditionally focused on bug fixes and cleanups, and these certainly form a good proportion of our changes, but we\u2019re using the same monthly cycle to add features and improve existing user experiences. Here are some of the highlights from May\u2019s 0.3 release:

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Edit bird"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The idea that CMS's should allow editing from the 'front end' has been in and out of vogue,\u00a0rougly\u00a0since the dawn of\u00a0contentEditable.
