There are some impressive implementations \u2013 Squarespace is a good example - but it becomes a complicated UI problem when pages are made of up content from elsewhere on the site.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With Wagtail, we've taken the position that content authoring should be handled within an interface which is optimised for writing, rather than reading, but our new 'edit bird' feature is a nod towards the quicker gratification of the alternative approach. It\u2019s a toolbar which sits discreetly on the edge of public pages and is only visible to logged-in editors, who can expand it to edit the current page or add another one like it, provided they have the relevant permissions. We\u2019ve consolidated the approve / reject options from the moderation workflow into the same toolbar, for better consistency.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Alternative image processing backends"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is a feature for site developers, allowing them to replace Wagtail\u2019s standard\u00a0Pillow\u00a0image processing library with an alternative, like\u00a0Wand, the Python wrapping for ImageMagick. Unlike Pillow, Wand handles a feature commissioned by the Royal College of Art: support for resizable animated GIFs! Does this make Wagtail the first Django CMS with this crucial capability? More importantly, this feature illustrates our push to modularize Wagtail, allowing developers to swap in alternative libraries where our defaults aren\u2019t the most suitable for their projects.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Form builder"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You can now create single-page forms, such as a \u2018Contact us\u2019 form, as pages of a Wagtail site. Editors can build forms within the usual page editor, consisting of any number of fields. Form submissions are stored for later retrieval through a new \u2018Forms\u2019 section within the Wagtail admin interface, and can be optionally e-mailed to an address specified by the editor.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Static site generation"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Static Site Generators (SSGs) have been all the rage in CMS-land over the last couple of years, with the rise of tools like\u00a0Jekyll, and high-profile posts from organisations like\u00a0Development Seed\u00a0on embracing the simple file. Wagtail has now muscled in on this game, with the help of\u00a0Context Information Security, who commissioned Torchbox to add static site generation to Wagtail\u2019s feature list.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you want to generate a version of your Wagtail site as static files, either for performance, or\u00a0security,\u00a0or simply as a snapshot of your content which will last longer than the whims of CMS suppliers, we have a new command for you: ./manage.py\u00a0staticsitegen. This piggy-backs on the\u00a0django-medusa\u00a0library, and will whirr away building each page before uploading them to your server, or to Amazon S3.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Among the other changes in 0.3, we\u2019re particularly pleased with the improvements to\u00a0Wagtail\u2019s\u00a0documentation,\u00a0and grateful for\u00a0Jeffrey Hearn\u2019s eloquent contributions to it. Keep track of ongoing work on our\u00a0Github repo, and stay tuned for 0.4!

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

The story of our successful video campaign for\u00a0SGOSS \u2013 Governors for Schools.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What did we set out to achieve?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were asked to develop the concept and build an interactive digital element to raise awareness of the school governor role and encourage people to volunteer. Additionally, we planned and implemented a digital campaign to circulate it to as wide an audience as possible. The target, based on the success of previous campaigns, was to generate 75 applications.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Developing a theme"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We immersed ourselves into the world of the school governor. We searched a lot and we read a lot. We\u00a0learnt\u00a0that school governors make really important decisions like appointing \u00a0a head teacher and setting the school\u2019s aims and budget, but that the public\u00a0were\u00a0largely unaware of this.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We felt the key to recruiting new governors was showing the public how important the role is, the sort of decisions that governors make, and that there are openings available.\u00a0The theme for our campaign was: \u2018Could you be a School Maker?\u2019.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"The latest initiative from SGOSS is the School Makers campaign, which saw the launch of a new, and rather brilliant, interactive video campaign.\"", "attribution": "Peter Henshaw, Editor, SecEd"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Compelling Content"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We wanted to bring the role to life in an entertaining and cost effective way. We did this by developing an interactive video using Rapt Media\u2019s platform. Three children formed an interview panel and asked users what they would do in situations school governors face \u2013 for\u00a0example\u00a0whether to sell off part of the school field in order to be able to replace IT facilities. Users would be able to choose what they would do and the children would act out the consequences.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Friends and family"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The production of the video really was a Torchbox affair! The actors in the video are two of Olly Willans\u2019 (our Creative Director) children and one of their friends and it was shot at a local school where Tom Dyson (our Tech Director) is a governor! The video was shot by Ross Harrison - the son of Susan (our Financial Manager).\u00a0

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"All our carefully thought out and realistic targets based on previous campaign data were smashed within 36 hours of launch. We couldn\u2019t have achieved this without the great work from Torchbox.\"", "attribution": "Christopher Parker, Head of Marketing & Communications, SGOSS"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Making it famous"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were excited about the video and wanted the world to know about it! Watch the video here.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A PR campaign focused on survey results showing the lack of knowledge about the decisions school governors make and encouraged people to apply for vacancies. Widespread coverage was received on national, regional and online media such as Radio 2, Radio 4, Radio 5 Live, over 20 regional BBC stations and the BBC website.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To give the campaign a further boost, SGOSS arranged for promotions to be secured with partners such as Aviva, Deutsche Bank, Lloyds TSB and Teach First.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The content was also well received on social platforms and a Thunderclap promotion gave people the chance to donate a Facebook post or Tweet to support the campaign.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Watch Rob Salmon\u2019s talk on School Makers from ECF 2014:

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/aRVG2qkwT9w"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Results"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We were to be judged on the number of applications received and the campaign completely surpassed expectations:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • The target number of applications was 75.\u00a0
  • The campaign delivered 804, beating the target by 972%.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about SGOSS's interactive video campaign, please get in touch. We'd love to hear from you.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Google have re-opened Grantspro applications for Google Ad Grants. Charities can now increase their free AdWords budget from $10,000 to $40,000 a month. Find out how.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

After a 15-month hiatus, Google are once again accepting Grantspro applications for their Google Ad Grants programme. This means that charities can apply to increase their spending cap of $10,000 a month of free advertising on AdWords to a whopping $40,000 a month.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In this video, I explain how charities can qualify for the $40,000 upgrade and what existing Grantspro holders will need to do to maintain their Grantspro status.

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/0xUyLjr3xGE"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Need an\u00a0introduction to Google Ad Grants\u00a0or help with\u00a0AdWords management? Get in touch via\u00a0Twitter\u00a0or email\u00a0christopher.whalen@torchbox.com.

"}]

fields.intro: We love a challenge at Torchbox and being commissioned to redevelop the Chatham House website in just five months (including the migration and integration of 10,000 items) was a task we couldn't refuse.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We love a challenge at Torchbox and being commissioned to redevelop the Chatham House website in just five months - including the migration and integration of 10,000 items - was a task we couldn't refuse.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Chatham House, home of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, is an independent policy institute and world-leading source of independent analysis, spearheading informed debate and influential ideas on how to build a prosperous and secure world for all.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Chatham House hompage", "image": 1250, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Requirements"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

They wanted a modern, responsive website with a clean design that would provide a better user experience and increase traffic. Additionally, one of the requirements was to integrate the website with their events and membership management software which is the backbone of the organisation for its\u00a0members\u00a0online experience. The previous integration between the two systems was very limited.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Of course, within all this, we wanted to ensure that we'd meet Chatham House's objectives:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Promote new policy ideas \u2013 publications and research projects \u2013 to our target audiences;
  • Measure and be seen as a primary resource for international affairs analysis, including being regarded as a source of thoughtful, insightful commentary on relevant external events;
  • Operate as an effective and efficient e-commerce site (for servicing conferences and membership in particular);

  • Provide an engaging and valued portal for members.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Why Drupal?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Chatham House\u00a0has\u00a0been using the Drupal CMS since summer 2011. The previous Drupal 6 site was suffering from intermittent performance issues, a dated, non-responsive design and did not integrate effectively with Chatham House\u2019s internal membership management software. It was decided to stay with Drupal as it proved to be a powerful and\u00a0customisable\u00a0platform that would cope well with their complex content structure and processes.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We worked with Chatham House to produce a fresh, modern and responsive design on a new Drupal 7 instance. Replacing a lot of custom content with tried and tested combinations of contributed modules \u2013 code provided by the community to extend Drupal's core \u2013 and a large, rolling content migration (more than 10,000 items) was required to move content from the old Drupal 6\u00a0site,\u00a0to the new Drupal 7 site. Given the content heavy nature of some of the research topics on the new website, having real content available made both prototyping new features and final acceptance testing far easier than relying on placeholder content.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Starting in January 2014, the Drupal development of the new website was broken into 94 individual features and followed our\u00a0Kanban driven\u00a0approach.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What's new?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Some key features of the site are the main navigational menu, mixing both traditional navigation items and content. Drupal\u2019s menu system doesn\u2019t permit this so we created our own menu. Fortunately, both the links to research departments and other parts of the site were relatively static; only requiring a few minor changes throughout the year. This made the process of building it a little more straight forward. We\u2019ve mixed the main menu, membership\u00a0login,\u00a0and some featured content into this navigation menu \u2013 making it interactive and providing a lot of information in one small space, neatly.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Another new feature was the integration with the membership system, which greatly improves the member experience by providing a logged-in member dashboard, authentication support against the membership system (very similar to the LDAP module) and provides feeds of events from approved events data. It is also an authoritative data source for member data, asynchronously pulling in changes every 15 minutes. Meaning, the website will not go down or become unresponsive if the back end data store becomes unavailable.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "When did we achieve this?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After five months of intensive development, rolling content migrations,\u00a0testing\u00a0and final content entry, the new Chatham House website was launched on 2 June 2014. The retention of Drupal as a CMS platform provides yet another example of the capability of this Open Source platform as a highly capable solution for other similarly sized and high profile organisations throughout the world.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Read the full\u00a0Drupal.org\u00a0featured case study.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about Chatham House's website, or want to discuss your upcoming project, please get in touch - we'd love to hear from you.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: You’re having a new version of your website built, and you need to transfer your existing domain to the new site. Or maybe you’re building a completely new site and need to set up a new domain for it. Your developers have asked you to arrange the DNS transfer, lower the TTL and set up a reverse proxy ready for launch. Have you come out in an anxious sweat? If so, this blog post is for you
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Your developers have asked you to arrange the DNS transfer, lower the TTL and set up a reverse proxy ready for launch. Have you come out in an anxious sweat? If so, this blog post is for you

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019re often in the position of those developers asking you to do confusing things. The way domain names are managed and transferred can be tricky to understand for the uninitiated, so this post will hopefully help you see the wood for the trees.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What is DNS?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

First, a little background.\u00a0DNS\u00a0stands for \u2018Domain name system\u2019 and is the protocol whereby a\u00a0user friendly\u00a0domain name, such as \u2018torchbox.com\u2019 is transferred to the\u00a0IP address\u00a0of a server which is hosting the site. The IP address is the unique numerical address for a particular computer on the internet. Think of it like the coordinates of a location on a map.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Domain names need to be unique, otherwise, the whole system would\u2026 fall over! It would be like looking up Oxford on a map and finding it was located in two different places. So this is why your domain needs to be registered. A\u00a0registrar\u00a0is\u00a0the company\u00a0that handles this for you, such as 123-Reg or Gandi. These companies are acting according to the rules of ICANN - the body that enforces unique domain names across the internet. Each registered domain is stored in the\u00a0registry\u00a0for the\u00a0top level domain (TLD)\u00a0it's registered under, e.g. 'torchbox.com' is registered with Verisign, the registry for all domains ending in '.com\u2019.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Specific computers handle requests for particular domains - these are called the\u00a0domain name servers\u00a0(often referred to as\u00a0DNS servers\u00a0or just\u00a0name servers). The name servers that are allocated to handle a particular domain are known as the\u00a0authoritative servers\u00a0for that particular domain. Collectively, name servers act a bit like a road map, telling your computer where it should go to retrieve a particular web page. The piece of information that holds that critical domain name to IP address mapping is known as the\u00a0DNS record.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Maps, coordinates, roads, and records: it\u2019s all simple so far, right?

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Looking up the address in the DNS 'road map\u2019"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Let\u2019s look in more detail at what happens when you visit a particular address in your browser, such as\u00a0http://www.torchbox.com. The first thing that will happen is that your browser will make a\u00a0request\u00a0to a particular domain, which is\u00a0it\u2019s\u00a0way of simply asking for information. This will typically go through to a name server at your Internet Service Provider (ISP). This server will then check if it manages the domain you\u2019ve requested itself (this is unlikely), and if it doesn\u2019t, it will send the request off to other name servers within the DNS system. It will continue contacting other name servers until it either:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

a) finds a name server that is authoritative for that\u00a0domain; or

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

b) finds a cached record on another name server for that domain (I\u2019ll touch on this shortly)

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In either case, the IP address of the server where the site is hosted is returned back to your computer (directly from the authoritative server or from a cached record). Your computer can then contact the server with that IP address to fetch a web page to display in the browser.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So there\u2019s a whole system in place to deal with your one request to find a web page.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The DNS hierarchy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The process that deals with sending out requests to other name servers isn\u2019t random. Given a\u00a0look up\u00a0for \u2018www.torchbox.com\u2019, the request will first ask the root servers for the address of the \u2018com\u2019 name servers. It then asks the \u2018com\u2019 name servers for the address of the \u2018torchbox.com\u2019 name servers.\u00a0Finally\u00a0it asks the torchbox.com name servers for the IP address of \u2018www.torchbox.com\u2019. Each step gets cached along the way.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Caching of DNS records"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You\u2019ll recall that I mentioned that rather than contacting the authoritative name server directly, your request for a particular domain might end at a cached DNS record on a different name server. This is interesting because it gets\u00a0at\u00a0the nub of how thousands of interconnected name servers efficiently process requests.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When the authoritative server for a domain sends out the DNS record, the name server that requested it will store that information for a period of time, ranging from a few seconds to a few days. When another name server looking for a record for that domain asks the name server with the cached record, it will use that rather than going on to the authoritative name server.\u00a0In turn\u00a0it too will cache the record, so that gradually more and more name servers will hold a record of the map between domain name and IP address. You may hear this referred to as\u00a0DNS propagation.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The length of time a name server will cache a record for is known as the\u00a0time to live (or TTL). This can often be configured with your registrar, and is important to know about when you are transferring your domain to a new IP address - more on that below.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Hosting"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The name server doesn\u2019t host your web site, a different server does this. In some\u00a0cases\u00a0you may use the same company that you registered your domain name with to host your site, but often it will be hosted with another company. Hosting is just a fancy word for storing the code for your website - code that the browser on your own computer can fetch and render into web pages. Your computer contacts the host server directly once it has retrieved the correct IP address for a domain from a name server.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Your DNS record"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The information about where your site is hosted is stored in a file known as a zone file or in a database.\u00a0Usually,\u00a0your registrar will provide a web form for you to update the information required. There are a number of different records in the zone file relating to different aspects of your domain, such as web and email hosting.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • A record - Historically this is the primary record for your domain - it maps your domain name to an IPv4 address (an IP address in the form of four 3 digit numbers such as 192.168.3.1)
  • AAAA record - the primary mapping to an IPv6 address (an IP address stored as 8 groups of 4 hexadecimal digits such as 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334). IPv6 is the new standard for IP addresses.
  • CNAME - this is not essential but is used to set up an alias for your domain that\u00a0repoints\u00a0to your primary domain. For example, you might want everyone coming to \u2018www.torchbox.com\u2019 to be pointed to the same server as \u2018torchbox.com\u2019, or anyone coming to bbc.com to be pointed to the same server as www.bbc.co.uk.
  • MX Record - this should be used to direct incoming mail to your domain. If you are setting a new website up on an existing domain already used for handling mail, it\u2019s important not to change where this record is pointing.
  • SOA (start of authority) - The zone file also contains the information about the authoritative name servers for your domain. You\u2019ll only need to update this if you want to change your registrar or configure your own name server for your domain.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What happens to your domain when you create a new website"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "New domains"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If your domain is brand\u00a0new\u00a0and is not pointing to an existing site, you can set up your DNS record with your domain registrar in advance. You can password-protect new content to prevent any visitors (or search bots) from seeing the new site before it is complete. In this situation you don\u2019t need to worry about the time it takes for your DNS record to propagate through all the name servers which might want to cache it, as you can make sure this is done in plenty of time in advance of launch.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "Transferring existing domains and lowering the TTL"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A very common situation for our clients is that they are replacing an existing website with a new one. The existing DNS record needs to be updated to point to a new IP address. Unless you happen to be hosting your new site on exactly the same server, you\u2019ll need to update your DNS record to point to the new IP address.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You\u2019ll only want to do this once you\u2019re ready to launch, so what can you do about all those name servers who have cached your DNS record for the old IP address? The answer is to lower your TTL down to a few seconds for your domain - well in advance of your launch date (or at least further in advance than your existing TTL). It is important to set the TTL as low as your registrar allows. This way name servers are only allowed to cache your record for a few seconds before they must start asking around for the authoritative server again to check their cached record really is correct. Your DNS propagation will happen in a matter of seconds rather than taking a few days.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "Proxying requests"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Another option when transferring a domain to a new server is to set up a reverse proxy on your new web server. This sounds fancy but it is just a means of updating your DNS record to point to the new IP address before you launch.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Some special configuration is set up on the new web server to redirect any requests coming through for your domain name back to the old IP address - effectively the current\u00a0website\u00a0is served up via the new server. This means the process of launching the site is very smooth indeed - all that needs to be done at launch is for the configuration on the new server to be updated. Propagation of the new DNS record has already happened so visitors will see the new site instantly.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Note: an alternative process to reverse proxying is that after launch you could configure your old server forward requests to the new server.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And that\u2019s really it!\u00a0Hopefully,\u00a0if you were in a sweat before you\u2019re now feeling cool and collected and ready to discuss name servers and reverse proxies with the best of them. Just in case you\u2019re hungry for even more information on this exciting topic, I\u2019d recommend this article on DNS at\u00a0howstuffworks.com.

"}]

fields.intro: I was reading Ben Terrett’s blog post about how frustrating the process of re-downloading music from iTunes is – having to re-enter password and having to click “buy” when you’re actually downloading it for free. It’s a bit of a palava.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

I was reading Ben Terrett\u2019s\u00a0blog post\u00a0about how frustrating the process of re-downloading music from iTunes is \u2013 having to re-enter\u00a0password\u00a0and having to click \u201cbuy\u201d when you\u2019re actually downloading it for free. It\u2019s a bit of a\u00a0palava.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Ben talks about how this is a\u00a0straight-forward\u00a0problem to fix, so you might ask 'why don\u2019t Apple just fix it?'. The reason is likely to be that they have very little incentive to do so. It probably doesn\u2019t cost them anything, so why spend developer time on the issue?

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Quality isn\u2019t free"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As we become reliant on web services, these frustrating interactions will become more and more part of our daily lives. In fact, this sort of problem crops up offline all the time: Why isn\u2019t the bus clean? Why does it take so long to get through to a call center? Why don\u2019t the buttons on cash machines line up with the screen? The reality is that none of the companies who could fix these problems have a financial incentive to do so.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Are kludges inevitable?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Kludges, or quick and dirty fixes, are sadly the norm. In\u00a0Kludge, Gary Marcus argues that the human brain is a result of millions of years of kludges, which is why for the most part, we get through life but we still suffer from cognitive problems such as anxiety and phobias.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Is there anything we can do?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Probably not. The fact is that most organisations have a single core motivator and that is money. They will always plump for solutions that are the cheapest and quickest. However, there might be one saving grace for us all \u2013 pride.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019m not an evolutionary biologist, so I can\u2019t tell you why, as humans, we evolved a sense of pride in some of the things we do but it\u2019s a reality: we decorate our houses at Christmas, we wash our cars, we pick up litter in our neighbourhood. People sometimes do things, not because they\u2019re getting paid, but because it\u2019s important to them.\u00a0If we want to see the same sense of pride in the world around us, companies need to start employing people that care about the things they do.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The only way that Apple will do something about the iTunes issue is if one employee stands up and says \u201cI\u2019m going to fix this!\u201d not because they\u2019re told to but because they won\u2019t sleep knowing it\u2019s still a problem for users.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Organisations don\u2019t have a sense of pride but individuals\u00a0do\u00a0and harnessing it is the key to making the world around us a less frustrating place to be.

"}]

fields.intro: We asked the team members at Torchbox what their resolutions were for 2015, and some of them told us.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We asked the team members at Torchbox what their resolutions were for 2015, and some of them told us.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Pete\u00a0-\u00a0Get fit and run two half-marathons. More yoga. Give up cheese for January. Give up alcohol until March 11. Finish reading 20 books over the year.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Olly\t\u00a0-\u00a0Meditate every day. Cycle to work one hundred times this year. Give up sugar. Do 'marriage night' on Wednesdays (hat tip to @jwebster).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tom D\u00a0-\u00a0Eat less meat. Write a short story. Climb a big French mountain on my bike.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Justine\u00a0-\u00a0Lunge more. Less sugar. Start the veggie patch I've been meaning to for three years now.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Rob C\u00a0-\u00a0Learn something new. Get more awesome at Marketing. Spend more time on improving my house. Get back to exercising regularly.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Jonny\u00a0-\u00a0Read a minimum of 25 books, visit 3 new countries, learn a new skill, gym four times a week, spend less time staring at screens.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Dan\u00a0-\u00a0Cycle more. Learn something new. Play more.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

James M\u00a0-\u00a0Not to share my resolutions.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Karl\u00a0-\u00a0Finish developing a game. Learn more Japanese. Do more exercise.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tom S\u00a0-\u00a0Vegan January. Cycle from Cornwall to Scotland. Complete a personal project using Wagtail/Django.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Kate\u00a0-\u00a0Read 52 books. Complete first year Jedi training. Get fitter.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Phil\u00a0-\u00a0Indoctrinate Dylan into my way of thinking re. music. Keep sourdough starter alive for the whole year.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Helen W\u00a0-\u00a0Strength training with the aim of doing kettle bell classes with no kettle bells less than 12kg. Become much better acquainted with my cordless drill.\u00a0Phnar\u00a0Phnar.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Chris W\u00a0-\u00a0Go to Man Choir on Thursday at 19:00. Pass the AdWords display and video exams. Host an a capella sea shanty night. Reach my target weight by Bloomsday. Give at least 2% of my income to charity. Go to the Coburg samba festival in Germany. Play at Notting Hill Carnival with the London School of Samba. Watch Shakespeare at The Globe Theatre. Join Zappi's cycling club. Go swimming at Charlton lido. Cycle to work for a whole week. Go swimming at work. Swim in a\u00a0Snowdonian\u00a0llyn\u00a0(tarn). Learn how to dive. Learn long-distance open\u00a0water front\u00a0crawl.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Paul V\u00a0-\u00a0Start composing music again. \u00a0Average 12.5k swimming a week. \u00a0Get better at switching off so as to attain a state of zen-like calm and stop biting fingernails (been on\u00a0list\u00a0for 33 years, only RH index finger left to conquer).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Dave H\u00a0-\u00a0Go on six overnight\u00a0micro adventures. Learn to play one new song a fortnight. Use the standing desk for at least one hour each day.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Ged\u00a0-\u00a0Get back to how fit I was in 2007 (use the same training programme, compare logs. Match the numbers by May. Beat them by August. Maintain until December). Stop going to the deli for lunch. Have a day out with my dad.\u00a0

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Do you know\u00a0what your organisation's core values are?\u00a0Can you reel them off? Try it, not very many of us can.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And, when we tried and failed to instantly recall our core values in a management meeting, we realised it was time to revisit them. We\u2019ve been here before a couple of times, but we\u2019ve failed to ingrain the core values deeply enough.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So we went back to them\u00a0and did them again:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • We put together a working group of a few people from a few different areas of Torchbox
  • We reminded ourselves what our existing core values were, then threw them out
  • I swotted up on core values and what they mean and why we need them. Here\u2019s a useful article \u2018Make your core values mean something\u2019 by Patrick Lencioni (note the difference between 'core values' and 'aspirational values')
  • We had a look at a few\u00a0other organisations' core values\u00a0for inspiration. Our favourite was probably\u00a0Atlassian\u2019s
  • We went through a ten pack of stickies: describing Torchbox with a game of boggle bingo (don't ask)\u00a0in adjectives and adverbs to get a sense of what we are like, our traits and intentions
  • We did a\u00a0Mountains & Valleys\u00a0exercise
  • Then, individually, we wrote our top three, core values for Torchbox
  • We reviewed and\u00a0grouped them and marvelled at the level of agreement
  • I went away and drafted the top values that had come out of the workshop, ending up with the four
  • Tom and I then co-wrote them
  • Then we shared with the working group and the\u00a0team,\u00a0and tweaked them based on feedback
  • And, here they are\u2026
"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Torchbox's Core Values", "image": 342, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "1. Make things better"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We are an ethically driven company. We do great work with organisations that are making the world a better place.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "2. Make clients happy"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We listen, thoughtfully. We work in our clients' best interests. Our goal\u00a0is to\u00a0exceed\u00a0expectations.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "3. Never stand still"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We always look to improve: individually, and as a team. We learn new skills, improve our processes, and search for better solutions.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "4. Enjoy it"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Half our waking hours are at work, so we make the most of them. We enjoy what we do, we respect our colleagues and we are proud of our company.

"}]

fields.intro: We're building the back end of a service to deliver focused agricultural support to farmers in Kenya.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We're delighted to be working with\u00a0Mediae, a Nairobi-based organisation 'dedicated to improving the livelihoods of large audiences in Africa through the development of educative, entertaining and effective media'.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The project is part-funded by\u00a0TRAC, who have defined some impressively challenging measures of success.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The service we're building is called iShamba, after the Swahili word 'shamba', which means something like 'smallholding' or 'subsistence farm'.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Smallholder farmers in Kenya", "image": 344, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Smallholder farming produces the majority of Kenya's agricultural output, which itself occupies around 75% of working Kenyans. Mediae's TV show 'Shamba Shape Up' has been broadcast to huge audiences across Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania since 2012; it follows the weekly make-over format familiar to viewers of 'What Not to Wear' or 'Pimp My Ride', but with more emphasis on maize and goats than kitten heels and alloy rims.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

\u00a0iShamba builds on the success of this show \u2013 and the knowledge which has been amassed through its production \u2013 and takes advantage of Kenya's well-documented\u00a0mobile tech revolution, delivering precisely relevant data to subscribers via SMS.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "iShamba Workflow", "image": 351, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our part in this is to build the systems which store agricultural data and map them to users. The interfaces are almost entirely SMS and voice: a farmer\u00a0subscribes\u00a0by texting a short code, which triggers a payment request via M-Pesa, Kenya's ubiquitous mobile payment system, and creates a time-limited subscription.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A call centre operator gathers information about the farmer's location,\u00a0crops\u00a0and\u00a0lifestock, and associates this with the account. We gather data about market prices ('sweet potatoes are selling for X shillings per kg at market Y within Z miles of your home') and local weather, and pick the most relevant tips from our agricultural database, based on the time of year, where the farmer lives, what animals she has and what she's producing.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These are delivered over SMS by a local provider, who also provide a Twilio-style voice API which we're using to handle incoming calls from subscribers, allocating them to call centre staff, whose screens will show all the relevant details of the farmer they're helping.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "iShamba Django admin", "image": 352, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're building iShamba in Django, with Redis for queued requests, AngularJS for the call centre screens and\u00a0Pusher\u00a0for\u00a0real-time\u00a0updates. The first SMSs should be sent out in the next few weeks; although with no public-facing web interface this is an unusually private project for us, we're terribly excited about launching it.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about iShamba, or want to discuss your exciting tech project, please get in touch.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Drupal 8 has been in development for the last few years. We're looking forward to its release. Here's why.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Drupal 8 has been in development for the last few years. We're looking forward to its release. Here's why.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

PHP is a programming language that\u2019s used to build websites and web applications. In fact, it\u2019s the\u00a0most widely used\u00a0of all programming languages used on web servers. The thing is, PHP isn\u2019t great - it\u2019s a rough-and-ready language that\u2019s always been the choice of pragmatists, rather than people who insist on their languages being simple and elegant. While it\u2019s been criticised for being inconsistent, ugly and harder to use than other languages, people have built amazing things with PHP, like Wikipedia, Flickr, Wordpress, and the focus of this blog post: Drupal.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

But now, PHP has started to change, for the better. The length of time between releases has decreased. Each release has brought improvements: programs run faster and require less memory, and new features bring it in line with other modern programming languages.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Simultaneously, the community of projects that use PHP pulled together to form a working group -\u00a0PHP-FIG\u00a0- with the aim of co-operating on standards that every project could use and benefit from.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Technical improvements\u00a0and a set of standards that encourage the use of those improvements have led to a renaissance in the PHP community. For the Drupal project, the timing couldn\u2019t have been better. Drupal 8 - the next major version of Drupal - has been in development for the last three years, and has taken advantage of the improvements in both PHP and other projects built in PHP.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal 8 brings new features as you\u2019d expect. It\u2019s also simpler and more familiar to developers who\u2019ve never used Drupal before. It\u2019s almost as if Drupal 7 and previous versions were developed in isolation; Drupal\u2019s community of developers came up with solutions that work\u00a0well,\u00a0but in unique and often unusual ways. Drupal 8, however, has opened up the community to the wider ecosystem of PHP programmers, who\u2019ve bought with them tried-and-tested solutions and conventions that any programmer should be able to understand.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One great example of this is Drupal 8\u2019s use of\u00a0Symfony. This is a set of components used by\u00a0many other web projects. The Symfony components used by Drupal provide the parts of a web application that every application needs. It\u2019s like if you were building a house, you wouldn\u2019t make the bricks yourself or\u00a0plane\u00a0your own floorboards - you\u2019d go out and buy some.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This leaves Drupal free to not worry about the basics, and able to concentrate on what it\u2019s meant to do; dealing with content.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal 8 is built in a modern style. That\u2019s great, but what improvements does it bring to the table? Well, plenty as it happens:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • All Drupal\u2019s\u00a0built in\u00a0themes will now provide a great experience on phones, tablets or desktop computers. (Known as\u00a0Responsive Web Design)
  • Drupal can now provide custom listings of content (previously, this required installing the community-built Views module), and a\u00a0WYSIWYG\u00a0editor installed by default.
  • The multilingual capabilities are much improved, with the ability to translate pretty much everything on a site without adding any additional modules.
  • And\u00a0lots more...
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The core development team has taken a lot of the functionality available in modules provided by the community for Drupal 7, improved them and integrated them into the core of Drupal 8.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019re really looking forward to using Drupal 8 at Torchbox. Each major version of Drupal core has provided a more powerful, more flexible toolkit for us to build sites with and Drupal 8 will be a bigger step forward than any other step before it. However, I think the most interesting change is the change in the Drupal community. Drupal is\u00a0open source software; it\u2019s been built on the principles that if the developers freely share the source code, more people will use the software. More usage leads to people providing fixes and improvements back to the project, so it grows and improves. Everybody wins.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With Drupal 8, the community\u2019s more open than it has ever been before, leading to even greater improvements in the quality and functionality of Drupal. There\u2019s a lot for our development team to learn, but as a web\u00a0developer\u00a0you have to be constantly learning as the web constantly reinvents itself. We\u2019ve got a lot of work to do, but it sure is going to be fun.

"}]

fields.intro: With the first beta release of Drupal 8 published at the end of 2014 there are a number of key questions and considerations for developers, site administrators and organisation leaders to consider in advance of the first Drupal 8 release candidate being released.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

With the first beta release of Drupal 8 published at the end of\u00a02014,\u00a0there are a number of key questions and considerations for developers, site\u00a0administrators,\u00a0and organisation leaders to consider in advance of the first Drupal 8 release candidate being released.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What is a release candidate?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A release candidate is normally created once there are no more critical bugs reported in a beta release. At the time of writing this post, there are around 70 outstanding critical issues remaining before the first D8 release candidate, typically referred to as\u00a08.x-rc1, being created.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What changes can I expect in Drupal 8?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our earlier post by\u00a0Rupert Jabelman\u00a0is a great overview of\u00a0what Drupal 8 offers and why we're looking forward to it. To recap:\u00a0some of the key changes in Drupal 8 include:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Responsive design in core:\u00a0Drupal is now engineered with support for mobile and tablet devices and uses HTML5.
  • Symfony components:\u00a0The new plugin system and the adoption of many Symfony framework components removes many of the 'Drupalisms' (strange or unusual ways of doing things or getting things done in Drupal) found in Drupal 6 and 7 and permits an even greater number of experienced and talented developers to contribute\u00a0into\u00a0the Drupal project or even hire to maintain or develop your site.
  • Twig templating:\u00a0The new Twig templating system is far more intuitive and than the existing PHPTemplate based system and allows greater control of markup.
  • Web services:\u00a0Drupal's new internal architecture makes it easy to handle non-HTML requests and responses which\u00a0makes\u00a0it easier to use Drupal as a backend API for mobile or other web-enabled applications.
  • YAML:\u00a0The new\u00a0YAML-based configuration system means keeping configuration in code and not in the database. This makes it far easier to safely and quickly move your site between different environments or export existing configurations to source control.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Is there anything I can do to prepare for adopting Drupal 8?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This period of time between the beta and release candidate is also a great opportunity for many organisations to consider preparing by performing one or more of the following tasks:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Content audit:\u00a0is there any old content you need to archive or unpublish? This could be a good opportunity to remove any unwanted material or streamline your site content before moving it to Drupal 8.
  • User experience assessment on key parts of the site:\u00a0are there any parts of your website that could be made easier to use or more focused on the end user's objectives? Finding out in advance will make it easier to focus on important changes when adopting Drupal 8.\u00a0
  • Digital strategy and SEO review:\u00a0before you undertake any work to update to Drupal 8, have you made sure you're making the most of your organisation's digital products and that your SEO strategy is still well-aligned with them?
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you are already running a Drupal site this is the time to start assessing things such as:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Auditing what\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules you use\u00a0and whether there are any undocumented changes to them. The\u00a0hacked\u00a0contrib\u00a0module is a brilliant way to check whether your live site's version of a module has been changed since it was first downloaded from drupal.org.
  • Reviewing and listing any custom functionality or features\u00a0that you want to have on your new Drupal 8 site.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We can help with both these things and help you to draw up a specific action plan for your site.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "I have a Drupal site and want to upgrade. How much work will it be?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal 8 has done away with the\u00a0much maligned\u00a0upgrade.php script that traditionally promised much and often delivered a lot less than was desired. Instead, moving to Drupal 8 takes a far more sensible standpoint of treating everything as a content migration from your old site into Drupal 8. The migrate module is now included in Drupal 8 core and, when connected to an older Drupal site, can provide a migration path for core components such as content types and blocks. However, if you have\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules or custom code (it's very likely!) you can expect to have to present these to the migrate module yourself and define your own mappings. This really isn't as bad as it sounds and\u00a0migrate\u00a0makes it easy to tell Drupal where data can be found on the source system, what to do with it and where to put it in the destination system.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It is worth noting that the migration path from Drupal 7 to Drupal 8 is currently being finalised based on the work done for the Drupal 6 to Drupal 8 migration path. We expect this to be completed as part of, or shortly after, the first release candidate.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The amount of work involved\u00a0for\u00a0adapting custom code will depend on a variety of factors including what other modules (if any) it depends on, whether it is compatible with PHP 5.4.5 (required for Drupal 8) and how well it adheres to Drupal development\u00a0best practice guidelines\u00a0and\u00a0coding standards.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "When can I start building my site with Drupal 8?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In short: it depends on your project requirements, but at this time unless you're happy to tolerate or contribute towards fixing any critical beta bugs you're probably going to be eagerly awaiting the first release candidate. The beta release in December 2014 provided a feature freeze on the backend APIs and was soon followed by the front end APIs and interfaces. As a result, we expect there will be a steady increase in Drupal 8 releases of\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules that are often as important to the success of a Drupal project as Drupal core itself. The specific requirements of your own project will also dictate how soon you can get started with Drupal 8. You may find you only use a small number of common modules that will enable you to get started much sooner, whereas if your project requires the use of specific\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules you may find you either have to wait\u00a0for,\u00a0or consider contributing to, a first 8.x release for the things you require.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We will be providing a more detailed look at both progress in the Drupal 8 issue queue and a look at how popular\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules are progressing in the very near future.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "I need to use Drupal 7 now but want to move to Drupal 8. How can I provide a smoother transition?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Dave Reid's \"Future proof your Drupal 7 site\" presentation from Drupalcon Amsterdam is a useful introduction to how some\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules are being applied or adapted for Drupal 8. Some common tasks or features with recommended Drupal 7\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules include:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Entity references:\u00a0Entity reference
  • Responsive images:\u00a0Picture
  • Multilingual support:\u00a0Internationalization (i18n)
  • URL fields:\u00a0Url\u00a0(replaces the link module)
  • Web services:\u00a0RESTful Web Services
  • Date fields:\u00a0Date\u00a0(ensure you use ISO format to avoid unwanted conversions when upgrading)
  • Configuraton\u00a0management and export:\u00a0Features
  • WYSIWYG editor:\u00a0CKEditor
  • Content layout management: consider\u00a0Entity view modes\u00a0for non-complex layout\u00a0requirements,\u00a0or\u00a0Display Suite\u00a0for more complex configurations or where more control needs to be given to site builders.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There is also a list of\u00a0core modules on drupal.org that will be discontinued, along with\u00a0recommendations for suitable\u00a0alternatives.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "I would like to contribute to Drupal 8. Where do I begin?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In the first instance, review the \"Help to get Drupal 8 released\" page. Better yet, pop along to your local Drupal user group or Drupalcamp and\u00a0find a core mentor. Core mentors are volunteers to enable and encourage new core contributors and help them find suitable tasks to begin contributing to core and\u00a0contrib\u00a0projects. There are\u00a0normally\u00a0tasks for all abilities and skills ranging from triaging new issues through to development or maintenance of core components.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're really looking forward to helping our clients adopt and develop with Drupal 8 and in each\u00a0case\u00a0we'll be carefully assessing their needs against what is available at the time. We've also\u00a0begun contributing to Drupal 8 core\u00a0itself\u00a0(thanks,\u00a0Justine!)\u00a0- every little helps.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more Drupal 8 and the benefits it could bring your business, please get in touch. We'd be more than happy to answer any questions you have.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: There are so many options and tons of customisation available for your Twitter campaign. The trick is not to get over enthusiastic.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

There are so many options and tons of customisation available for your Twitter campaign. The trick is not to get over enthusiastic.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For someone who has never done a Twitter campaign before, the ad platform can appear daunting. The good news is that Twitter has made creating a new campaign very simple and straightforward. Even if you aren\u2019t sure what type of campaign you\u2019re after, the \u2018help me decide\u2019 option makes it easy to work out exactly what you want.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here are the five different types of campaign options:

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Different types of Twitter campaign objectives", "image": 1321, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Tweet engagements\u00a0- Do you have a particular tweet that you want to to get retweeted or\u00a0replied to? This will likely be what the majority of campaigns will use.
  • Website clicks or conversions\u00a0- Got an article or page that you want to drive traffic to? This requires a small snippet of tracking code to be copy-pasted on the website so the clicks or conversions can be measured. Not too tricky to set up, but I suggest reading up about it before starting this kind of campaign.
  • App installs or app engagements\u00a0- This is a campaign to increase installation numbers of an app on a mobile device using a Twitter \u2018card\u2019. This also requires\u00a0conversion\u00a0tracking and may be a little tricky for\u00a0someone without previous experience in this kind of campaign. If this campaign is for you, I\u2019d recommend reading everything you can beforehand. However, Twitter does streamline the process.
  • Followers\u00a0- Helps grow your follower numbers. Exactly what you\u2019d expect. This campaign will put a tweet in your targeted audience\u2019s timeline with a \u2018Follow\u2019 button.
  • Leads on Twitter\u00a0- This one is my personal favourite, as I\u2019ve had a lot of success with it. It creates a Twitter \u2018card\u2019 that helps encourage people to submit their email address to an exportable database with one click.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A Twitter \u2018card\u2019, if you\u2019re wondering, is an additional piece of content that gets attached to a tweet.\u00a0Click here to read more about the different types. It\u2019s likely that you\u2019ve seen plenty of them on Twitter before, so you may recognise some.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Now you\u2019ve chosen your campaign, you have a fair idea of what your\u00a0Key Performance Indicator (KPI)\u00a0should be. KPIs are important, especially when you consider your original objective. This leads us to my Golden Rule for Twitter Campaigns:

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Do One Thing Well"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It is a common mistake to cram your campaign tweets with junk that doesn\u2019t add anything to your KPI.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For example (KPI - increase retweets):

Example Tweet:\u00a0\u201cIf you like this post then retweet it! #RetweetingIsFun\u201d\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As you can see, the above tweet has a hashtag - thousands of people click the hashtag and nobody retweets. You pay for all those hashtag clicks, when what you really wanted was your campaign funds to go towards getting retweets.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The above is obviously just an example, but it\u2019s worth noting that anything clickable counts as an engagement alongside retweets or replies. This can include clicks on hashtags, Twitter handles, links, pictures, videos, etc. However, not all of these engagements have the same value. On average, the cost-per-engagement on a retweet will be higher than a click.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Using @ in Promoted Tweets"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There is another common mistake: Putting a Twitter @ mention into a promoted tweet. This is often the case when there is some kind of celebrity endorsement or for when the tweet is trying to associate itself with a Twitter account with more followers.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With a clickable Twitter handle in a promoted tweet, you\u2019ll be paying to drive traffic to that account and not to engagements with your content. If the involvement of a large Twitter account is important, it is always better to email them asking them to retweet a particular tweet. Or, add the Twitter handles to non-promoted tweets of the same content, that means they still get the exposure and can still retweet something that mentions them.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Like all rules, there is something of an exception...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Say, you have a campaign where you want lots of exposure to look at a photo, infographic or video. You know that a click on this content is considered an engagement so\u00a0will\u00a0be part of the cost-per-engagement.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The important action is to lay out the\u00a0priorities\u00a0of the KPIs. Twitter Analytics will tell you the number of retweets and will also tell you the number of \u2018Embedded media clicks\u2019, which can be a click on an image, a click to play a GIF file or a click to play an embedded YouTube video. This data can be just as useful as the number of retweets because it is showing you how Twitter users are engaging with your content.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My Golden Rule for Twitter Campaigns is mostly about keeping your tweets optimised for a specific purpose and your campaigns as cost effective as possible. Keep this in mind when designing your campaign and you should find much more pleasing results.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Mystic Meg here. I predict Drupal 8 will be released on 14th May 2015. No, wait! This isn\u2019t a crystal ball in front of me and my driving license tells me I\u2019m called Justine, so maybe I can\u2019t predict the future after all.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Personally, I don\u2019t think my prediction is too far off and I\u2019ll explain now how I\u2019m making that guess. Firstly, we recently had\u00a0Global Sprint Weekend\u00a0which saw 48 sprint groups all over the world work on over 400 issues. The final data isn\u2019t in yet on exactly how much work was done, but the fact that there are normally 4 test bots keeping an eye on what is being submitted (and over that weekend there were 19), production on Drupal 8 really did increase.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Crystal Ball", "image": 363, "attribution": "Image Credit: Sean Creamer", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Since October the number of\u00a0critical issues\u00a0have\u00a0dropped from 120 to less than 70. The progress chart on the get involved page is taking a steady slide downwards; when we reach zero critical issues Drupal 8 will be changed from\u00a0Beta\u00a0to\u00a0Release Candidate\u00a0and then we\u2019re good to go!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Another potential justification supporting my premonition of its release in May is\u00a0Drupalcon. This year the American conference will be\u00a0held in glitzy Los Angeles and pretty much every single one of the 2400+ core developers would love to hear Dries Buytaert address the audience with the words \u201cDrupal 8 is Released!\u201d. That\u2019s a big drive for core contributors like myself to crack on with helping resolve these critical issues.\u00a0Also\u00a0there is usually some large announcement at these events, Drupal 8 went into Beta in the European conference in October so lots of people are working towards Drupalcon as a goal.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Though we might be able to look at the key facts and make an educated guess on when Drupal 8 will be released, we are best to simply prepare our sites and put the champagne on ice. It still might not suit everyone to jump straight onto the shiny new Drupal 8 boat, as soon\u00a0it's launched. There are other considerations to be made,\u00a0Johan covered a few of these last week, depending on how heavily your site relies on contributed modules and how active their maintainers are could mean you might have a little wait on your hands, for that key module to be ready.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you have a simple site with some basic pages, taxonomy and listings then you\u2019re pretty much good to go now - actually please do so. If you\u2019re planning on upgrading a heavily customised site or one using big modules like Commerce or Organic Groups then you\u2019d be better off waiting for the time being, because there aren\u2019t any\u00a0upgrade plans\u00a0yet, and it will take some time for developers to get it to a stable state.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Anything that sits in the middle, could well still suit Drupal 8. If you can invest some time into fixing these core issues and help finish Drupal 8 faster\u00a0then\u00a0not only will you be one of the first in the world to have a new Drupal 8 site, but you\u2019ll have a lot of good karma and warm-fuzzies coming your way - as you would have helped to make Drupal 8.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So basically, the more developers involved with fixing the core issues, porting\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules and helping with documentation - the quicker it will be launched.\u00a0Investing in your developers to do a few hours work a week will make a difference. If you are a developer or just fancy chipping in yourself, then head to the\u00a0get started pages\u00a0and give it a go. Let\u2019s get Drupal 8 into release candidate and onto your servers!\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're really looking forward to helping our clients and future clients adopt and develop with Drupal 8. If you\u2019ve got any questions about Drupal 8, please get in touch. We'd be more than happy to answer any questions you have.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Putting webpages on an intranet used to be complicated. But now there's a variety of small computers well-suited to this task. So let's have a look at one of them: the\u00a0Banana Pi.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When creating webpages, one of the most important factors is usually page speed and the number of users you want to support simultaneously. For pages with many users, you may need two or three servers, a separate database, and probably a load balancer to manage it all.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So what kind of hardware would you use when specifying the needs for an internal\u00a0webpage\u00a0with a limited number of users and quick ethernet connections?\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here's what we used for one of our customers:

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "This is a Banana Pi, a competitor of the Raspberry Pi.", "image": 364, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This little box contains a 1GHz dual-core processor, 1 GB\u00a0RAM\u00a0and a Gigabit ethernet port. Combined with an 8GB SD card to hold the system software and a 2GB USB stick for user data, this little computer is perfectly suited for small networked tasks such as serving an intranet page.\u00a0There are quite a few more connectors, like an SATA port, an HDMI port, audio connectors, a microphone and even an IR input, that we're not using for this project.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It runs off a regular micro-USB power adapter and only uses\u00a03W of power, so it's great as an always-on device.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The whole setup costs about\u00a0\u00a350, so it's not a big investment either.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It gets even better from a user perspective. Since we preload the device to work on the\u00a0customers\u00a0internal network, the system knows how to set itself up. All the customer has to do is plug it into their network -- et voil\u00e0! The computer automatically configures itself via DHCP and assigns itself a known\u00a0DNS name\u00a0on the local network, so the page is immediately available in every browser in the local network. Security is very high\u00a0because the device is protected by the regular network firewall. No outside connections are needed.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

System upgrades are easy, too: We simply send a new SD card to the customer. They pull out the old card and put in the new one. Quick and easy!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

From a developer standpoint, the device doesn't differ much from our other, more conventional servers. It runs a variant of the\u00a0Debian Linux\u00a0distribution called\u00a0Raspbian, which offers the same software packages as regular servers. The web server is configured as\u00a0an NGINX\u00a0system with our usual Django deployment packages.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Whilst it's not the fastest computer in our arsenal, it's perfectly fine for serving low-load user pages. Load times are between 0.4-0.6 seconds for a complex page and the server can handle about 5 concurrent requests per second. A regular user clicks about once a minute, so as long as there are less than 100 active users at a time the page will be very responsive. Another factor for page loading times is the network transmission. This isn't an issue in this setup since both server and consumer are on the same fast network.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Serving an intranet\u00a0webpage\u00a0from such an appliance is only one of the\u00a0many\u00a0exciting applications for these great small devices.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Johannes is a freelance Django and mobile developer living in Germany. He's contributed to Wagtail and works with Torchbox frequently. As an amateur cake-eater and trained\u00a0mathematician,\u00a0he's happy to work with Pi often.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

So you\u2019ve read our posts about when to upgrade and how to prepare for Drupal 8, but just as you\u2019re about to jump, you ask that big question. Why am I doing this? Read on and I\u2019ll tell you why\u2026

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Support and security"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As mentioned by Rupert in his\u00a0earlier post, Drupal is now made using Symfony. This means that Drupal\u2019s standards have greatly improved. We\u2019re now forced to use an industry standard, we\u2019ve got\u00a0object-oriented\u00a0code and the latest PHP standards. This makes it easier to find more developers - you won\u2019t need a Drupal specific developer to understand your site, any PHP developer should be able to pick it up.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As well as more developers supporting Drupal, Symfony also provides better security. We greatly reduce the possibility of XSS vulnerabilities with the introduction of Twig. Currently, it is possible for a developer to put vulnerable code into the theming layer. Twig however, removes that possibility. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Performance"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As a frontend developer myself, I\u2019m very aware of how several thousand <div>s on a\u00a0webpage\u00a0can make a difference on the sites performance. Historically, Drupal is famous for its multitude of <div>s. Twig will make it easier for\u00a0frontend\u00a0developers to produce the exact code required to do the job with nothing extra floating around and bloating ever-precious download times. More and more users are using their mobile data connection, which results in slower download times. Large page sizes simply cannot cope, resulting in users getting bored and possibly going elsewhere.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Because we have more control over the markup in Drupal 8, it makes it much easier to ensure the accessibility of your site is\u00a0top notch. More thought can go into what screen readers see - remember that Google is the most active blind internet user there is!\u00a0Better\u00a0code ensures better accessibility, which in turn ensures better SEO rankings. Everyone is a winner!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Out of the\u00a0box\u00a0Drupal 8 has been rewritten from the ground up using a mobile first approach. This means your site is already able to work on mobile before we\u2019ve even put our designers\u2019 magic touch on it. Now you can even update your site easily on your phone - so you can now instantly add that breaking news feature (or cute cat photo).\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There\u2019s a new HTML element coming out called <picture>. Chrome is already using it and Firefox isn\u2019t far off. This new element has set the frontend world rejoicing. It means we can offer better picture quality and therefore download speeds over all your devices. This element is in Drupal 8 and ready to use. It\u2019s even got clever fallbacks for browsers that don\u2019t support <picture> yet. As such, we now have full control over what images appear and what the quality will be. Say 'goodbye' to long download times when you\u2019re on the train checking out those cute cat photos.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019ve also got the addition of key form elements already built in and ready to go; meaning we can create forms on any node. It also means we have complete control over them e.g. we're able to get placeholder text and other accessibility problems working in the first instance.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "New features"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019ve covered all the wonderful new ways Drupal is built, but that isn\u2019t all that comes with Drupal 8; it has some great new features built into it. Admittedly, most of these were\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules in Drupal 7 like\u00a0Views\u00a0but the problem with too many\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules is that a site can quickly become something resembling overcooked spaghetti.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For instance, we use the\u00a0Media\u00a0module a lot here at Torchbox. In the early days of D7, there were several other modules we needed and sometimes these modules wouldn\u2019t play nice with\u00a0Media\u00a0module. We had to wrestle with them and create custom code to get them to behave the way we wanted. Now that\u00a0File Entity\u00a0is in core, the\u00a0Media\u00a0module has been scaled down to just the best bits and it\u2019s easier for new modules to work in harmony. Better file integration\u00a0all-round\u00a0is a great new introduction to Drupal 8.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For website\u00a0editors\u00a0there\u2019s a fancy new\u00a0Quick Edit\u00a0module that gives you in-place WYSIWYG editing. No more scrolling through to the endless blocks page to try and find that one block you want to change, just click and edit. Here\u2019s a\u00a0quick Demo of it in action.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tour\u00a0module is a clever little module that I think most of our clients would like. It adds a step-by-step walk-through of the different elements to your site. Filling in a donation\u00a0form\u00a0for example, suddenly becomes more interactive with pop-up boxes explaining what happens at different points of the form. More information for users without the need to clutter the form with text and risking putting users off donating.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Happy Developers"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

All of the things we\u2019ve covered help to make us developers happy. No longer do frontend developers have to pester backend developers for help in creating better markup. No more \u201cDrupal does it differently\u201d from the rest of the PHP world.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal is reaching a maturity where it is no longer alongside its\u00a0peers,\u00a0but is slowly dwarfing them with its wonderfully clever qualities that have made it so popular to date.

"}]

fields.intro: What do you get when you cross Elvis, content and promotion? Torchbox's Rob Salmon dons his Vegas jumpsuit and gives you the low down - and a little song too!
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

What do you get when you cross Elvis,\u00a0content\u00a0and promotion? Torchbox's\u00a0Rob Salmon\u00a0dons his Vegas jump suit and gives you the low down - and a little song too!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Rob Salmon (aka Elvis) talking at Ve Interactive's Forum 'Giving Charities the Digital Edge', on his love of Content, Elvis and Promotion.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Wagtail is a Django content management system focused on flexibility and user experience. In this post we add a simple, extensible map feature to a Wagtail site by integrating geopy, a small geocoding library for Python.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Often, our sites contain geographical information that we would like to be able to display on a map. For advanced geographical features we can use a framework like\u00a0Geodjango, but for a small\u00a0project\u00a0this may provide more than we need. Wagtail is flexible enough that adding a map feature to it is easy. To demonstrate this, we'll build an example site that satisfies the following requirements:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Administrators can associate pages with locations. These will be referred to as locatable pages.
  • A map can be added to any page.
  • Site\u00a0vistors\u00a0can search for locatable pages
  • Administrators can categorise locatable pages.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our site must be able to do the following:

    "}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
    • Take the names of locations and convert them into latitude/longitude pairs that can be plotted on a Google map.
    • Associate locations with pages and save that information in the database.
    • Perform the correct calculations to be able to find locations within a specified radius of a particular latitude and longitude so that site visitors can search for locatable pages local to them.
    "}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

    We will use the Google Geocoding API to convert the names of locations into latitude/longitude pairs.\u00a0geopy\u00a0will be used to communicate with the API and to calculate the distances between those pairs. The results will be plotted on a Google map. If you would like to follow along with this post you can find all of the code\u00a0here. If you try it with your own Google Maps API key, make sure to enable the relevant APIs in the\u00a0Google APIs Console.

    "}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

    To begin, we use Wagtail Template to set up a new Wagtail build called wagtail_map. Our only additional dependency is\u00a0geopy\u00a01.1.2, which goes in requirements.txt.

    "}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

    The core of the project is the Location model:

    "}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://gist.github.com/mope/460120da27fb7e5fce5b"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

    Converting the name of a location into a latitude/longitude pair is called \"geocoding\". To geocode the name of a location with the Location model, instantiate it, set\u00a0Location.name, then call\u00a0Location.geocode().\u00a0If the Geocoding API is available and the name is\u00a0geocodable,\u00a0Location.latitude\u00a0and\u00a0Location.longitude\u00a0will be set. You may now save this object to the database and create foreign key relationships between it and other models. If you would like to find Location objects that you have saved previously and that are within a specified distance of the current Location object (specified by\u00a0Location.SEARCH_RADIUS, in km) call\u00a0Location.find_nearby_locations().

    "}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

    A couple of implementation details to note here are that Location uses\u00a0geopy's\u00a0implementation of\u00a0Vincenty's formulae\u00a0for distance calculations and that we use a bounding box to reduce the number of Location objects that we need to retrieve from the database and hence the number of calculations to perform.

    "}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

    To make it easy to associate Page models with Locations, we have a Locatable mixin*:

    "}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://gist.github.com/mope/ed3715f0047b4775f265"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

    Inheriting from this mixin will give a page a\u00a0location_name\u00a0property and a couple of search functions, allowing you to search for pages that are within a specified geographical distance of the page and in a particular part of the page tree. We use the page tree to categorise locatable pages. For example, we could have two event indexes, one for picnics and the other for birthday parties, and use\u00a0search_children_locations()\u00a0to ensure that only events beneath those event indexes in the page tree appear on their respective maps.

    "}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
