Obviously, if you know the risks from the outset, you can plan well in advance for mitigating them.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Every project has constraints. Sometimes, they produce the most inspired solutions.\u00a0Do less\u00a0is the principle made famous by gov.uk that captures the benefits of quality over quantity. Prioritise what you\u2019re trying to do. That way, both sides can keep needle-sharp focus.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "#4 Plan long-term"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Digital work is changing. We\u2019re moving out of the era when organisations revamp their entire website every two to three years. Iterative web development is the way forward - and that means every piece of work is an opportunity to find a better, more timely solution.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Don\u2019t narrow your vision to the task\u00a0in\u00a0hand. Think future-proof.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "#5 Keep a loose grip"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One of the most fascinating parts of digital work is seeing how a collaboration of designers and developers with a problem to solve and a handful of ideas can result in truly excellent solutions.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Flexibility is just as important as clarity when it comes to innovation. We might start out with a path in mind, but sometimes a great idea is worth changing direction for.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Need help with your new, exciting project? If so, please get in touch. We'd love to hear from you.\u00a0

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

In the world of the web it\u2019s sometimes easy to get caught up in bleeding edge conversations about technology and technique. It\u2019s odd to think that one key theory on software development turns 40 this year.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In 1975, Fred Brooks published The Mythical Man-Month, a book to help understand how to undertake complex development projects. It remains as essential today, as when it was first published.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The central premise is a simple statement: A project that requires five team members to work for five months cannot be completed by a twenty-five person team in one month.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s a premise that elegantly articulates the fact that effort is not the same as progress. Brooks expanded on the rationale that a project that is late is likely to become later if you add more people to it. This became known as Brooks\u2019s Law.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Scaling stress"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The underlying concept behind Brooks\u2019s law is that as a project scales, the communication complexity involved increases. In other words; adding team members isn\u2019t without costs. As Brooks put it himself, \u2018When the schedule slips, the first response is to add manpower, like gasoline to a fire\u2019.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Brooks came up with a formula that communication channels are equal to the\u00a0triangular number\u00a0equation of n(n-1)/2.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "n(n-1)/2", "image": 525, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This means that though a small team of six creates 15 links between one another, a larger team of 12 will generate 66 links, and if the team\u00a0were\u00a0increased to 50 there would be no less that 1,225 communication links to manage.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

His argument follows that an increase in communication channels leads to an increase in complexity, which reduces the team\u2019s productivity and resilience to any problems they encounter.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The law has been challenged, notably from Linus Torvalds, the creator of Linux and Git. He argues that open-source projects offer an observable occasion where Brooks\u2019 law doesn\u2019t hold true.\u00a0Linux for example\u00a0has 1,000 kernel\u00a0contributors,\u00a0but has consistent growth of 10% per year.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Still, in the day-to-day world of development Brooks\u2019s law has entered into received wisdom. At Amazon, Jeff\u00a0Bezos,\u00a0instituted a\u00a0two pizza rule\u00a0on any team, if two pizzas couldn\u2019t comfortably feed the team then it was too big. At Spotify, Henrik\u00a0Kniberg,\u00a0created the concept of\u00a0squads,\u00a0tribes\u00a0and guilds\u00a0to create shippable components of the service. At gov.uk, the UK government\u2019s digital service, they\u2019ve adopted team sizes between 5 - 10 to\u00a0ensure project success.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Change is a feature not a bug"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Whilst\u00a0The Mythical Man-Month\u00a0is most famous for the eponymous chapter that gave rise Brooks\u2019s law, it also deserves attention for its other chapters.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The two chapters, \u2018Plan to throw one away\u2019 and \u00a0\u2018Hatching a catastrophe\u2019 make Frederick Brooks a good candidate as the godfather to agile development processes.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The language of \u2018Plan to throw one away\u2019 is entertainingly retro, with\u00a0jargon\u00a0of the 70s technology zeitgeist. Strip it back to the underlying meaning though and it\u2019s not far off from the\u00a0agile manifesto\u2628:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Plan to run a pilot and scale from there

  • Change is the only constant

  • Plan the system to accommodate these changes

  • Plan the organisation for these changes

  • Expect to take two steps forward and one step back

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

(\u2628Okay, I lied, it is a little way from the agile manifesto, but considering it predates it by 30 years it\u2019s a pretty impressive prototype of an agile development cycle nonetheless)

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Meanwhile the opening phrase for his final chapter \u2018Hatching a catastrophe\u2019 is: \"Question: How does a large software project get to be one year late? Answer: One day at a time!\" The chapter is insistent that the only way to meet deadlines was to ensure the project was split into smaller work with regular, small, individual milestones needing to be met.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How Torchbox avoids falling in the tar pit"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Mythical Man-Month\u00a0opens with Brooks talking about how software projects, like dinosaurs and other animals from prehistory, can easily sink into tar pits, regardless of the skill, strength or speed of the animal. At Torchbox we\u2019re fairly confident that falling in a tar pit is going to end badly, so we\u2019ve worked hard to take on board the lessons that Brooks set out.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We work carefully with each client to discover the needs of their\u00a0users,\u00a0and then work internally to ensure that we can come up with realistic estimates. We use a kanban system to track work and ensure the actual velocity matches our estimated progress. \u00a0We accept that change is inevitable and ensure regular iterative work is undertaken to ensure any project is always moving in the right direction.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The mythical man month is just that, mythical, and we know that a project can\u2019t be delivered in one month by 25 people when it should take five people five months!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you haven\u2019t read\u00a0The Mythical Man-Month\u00a0it\u2019s available on the Internet Archive.\u00a0If reading an entire book feels like too much work, here's an entertaining\u00a0edited version.

"}]

fields.intro: If you're preparing for an interview or putting your portfolio together with the aim of landing your first junior design job we've got some helpful advice for you.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

If you're preparing for an interview or putting your portfolio together with the aim of landing your first junior design job we've got some helpful advice for you.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Make design your passion"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you're looking for your first job in design you'll be up against designers that live and breathe design. If you're not one of these people employers will quickly work this out. It's unlikely that employers searching for a Junior Designer will expect their new junior employee to have the most refined skill sets or an expansive portfolio but they're looking for the people who will one day become great. This is only possible if you are motivated and passionate about design.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Great designers can't help but design. Well-executed and relevant personal projects can be a job-winning element of your portfolio. Equally, those that have put time and effort into designing their own cover letter, CV and portfolio show they can't help but think about the design of what they are creating.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Embed yourself in the design community"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Learn about who is doing the best work in your field of interest. Follow great designers and design agencies, read up on what they have to say, explore and analyse their work, then be prepared to talk about it. Read design-related publications and blogs such as\u00a0Offscreen\u00a0and\u00a0A List Apart. Surround yourself with good design and develop design heroines and heroes. You'll find this has an effect on the quality of your own work and you'll be able to talk confidently about the industry you're trying to break into.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Evidence everything"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When it comes to applying for jobs you need to back up everything with evidence. It's no good saying you're an effective team player, you need to give an example of when you've worked in a team and how you have worked effectively. Employers also want to see the process you've used to create work. How do you deal with the whys and hows whilst you're designing?\u00a0Equally,\u00a0if you say you can code don't just send flat design mock-ups or a portfolio based on an out-of-the-box WordPress template.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Be honest about your strengths and weaknesses"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you're replying to a job description and there is a skill set that you don't have don't simply ignore it. It's better to explain what little you do know about that subject and demonstrate a keen ability to learn new skills as and when you need them. Employers will want to see examples of where you've learnt a new skill to solve a problem. Skills can be learnt but if you don't show the ability and determination to learn this doesn't look good.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Be relevant"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you're applying for a digital position make sure digital work makes up the bulk of your portfolio. If your online portfolio is a mix of different disciplines create a second one or at least a PDF that focuses on the job you're applying for. If the first piece of work an employer sees isn't relevant to the work they do they will have alarm bells ringing. Employers need to see that you're doing the right type of thinking. If it's a digital position they'll be much more interested in how you shape a user interface or how you deal with design across different devices than how well you know the print process. A varied skill set can be useful but demonstrate it appropriately in the context of the position you're applying for.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "And finally..."}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The truth is good jobs are hard to get but spending your days practising your passion is worth the effort. Good luck! \u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Torchbox is recruiting"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you think you can demonstrate the qualities outlined above you might be just who we're looking for. Visit our\u00a0jobs\u00a0page for the latest information.\u00a0

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Hosted at the Queen Elizabeth II conference centre in London, SymfonyLive is a conference aimed at developers, engineers and other professionals who use the Symfony framework itself or technology related to it.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Symfony is designed to be modular in the form of components and Drupal 8 has been designed to be able to work with these components. As a result, this conference has suddenly become far more relevant for current or prospective Drupal developers.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Keynote"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The conference was opened with a keynote from\u00a0Seb Lee-Delisle. For those unfamiliar with his work, Seb describes himself as a digital artist who uses computers and technology to inspire and develop curiosity in people. He not only gave an amusing introduction to some simple canvas programming in Javascript (turns out everybody loves creating sparkly, moving things in canvas!) but also displayed some amazing projects such as\u00a0Lunar Lander,\u00a0PixelPyros\u00a0and, with some audience participation,\u00a0Clappy\u00a0Bird: a flappy bird clone where audience clapping volume determines the height of the bird; deceptively difficult to control!

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "'Symfonic' Architecture"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Richard Jones\u00a0from iKos delivered a summary of how Drupal is moving towards a more \u2018Symfonic\u2019 architecture and how that is being received in both the Drupal community and the wider PHP community. While it\u2019s easy to regard the change from Drupal\u2019s particular way of working to a more object oriented approach as a threat, it is clear that the majority of Drupal developers are welcoming the move. It\u2019s great to see Drupal contributing to and adopting standards from the\u00a0PHP FIG\u00a0(Framework Interop Group). Interestingly, Richard has been involved in putting together a book on Drupal 8 development - I look forward to reading it when it\u2019s ready.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "PSR-7"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

PSR-7:\u00a0Beau Simensen\u00a0delivered a great overview of what PSR-7 is and what to expect from it. For those unfamiliar, PSR stands for\u00a0PHP Standard Recommendation\u00a0and is a means for representatives from different PHP projects to put forward proposals on how to implement specific, standard approaches to common problems ranging from coding styles to the autoloading of classes. PSR-7 concerns itself with providing a simple, common approach to handling HTTP requests and responses. It also aims to remove the dreaded \u2019S word\u2019 from HTTP handling: State. APIs or web services that require state can be hard to test or debug. On the contrary, stateless equivalents are far more predictable and easier to work with. Projects such as\u00a0Guzzle\u00a0and Symfony implement PSR-7 and Drupal 8 is not far behind.\u00a0Stackphp\u00a0looks like a great piece of middleware for projects that do a lot of HTTP processing, such as an API.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Hexagonal Architecture"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Matthias Noback\u00a0provided an interesting overview of\u00a0Alistair Cockburn\u2019s Hexagonal Architecture\u00a0for designing Symfony projects. Large, complex applications typically maintain a separation of concerns between the layers of the application and using interfaces instead of using concrete classes provides the basis of a concept known as dependency injection.\u00a0Dependency injection\u00a0is not a new concept to software development, but they will be new to Drupal and they provide a far simpler manner for developers to test the code they write. Traditionally, unit testing of Drupal projects has been problematic as many system components rely on having access to the database, filesystem or other content or configuration, meaning often a\u00a0full\u00a0operational application is required to test even the smallest of changes. This makes automated testing slow and often impractical.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Messaging Technology"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Phil\u00a0Leggeter\u00a0is an expert in\u00a0real time\u00a0(or near\u00a0real time) communication or messaging technology. There are many tools and services around these days meaning you can build your own\u00a0PubSub\u00a0infrastructure or use a hosted service such as\u00a0Pusher. Phil demonstrated how you can use something like Redis\u2019\u00a0pubsub\u00a0feature to provide a means for a chat client to send and receive messages through. During his talk, I set up a Pusher account and took it for a spin - it was that simple to use. As it happens, Torchbox already\u00a0use\u00a0Pusher as part of the\u00a0iShamba project\u00a0for Kenyan\u00a0famers. The\u00a0take-away\u00a0message was that developers and project owners need to carefully weigh up the time required to build/maintain custom solutions against the subscription costs associated with services such as Pusher.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Closing Keynote"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The closing keynote was delivered by\u00a0Fabian Potencier\u00a0(the creator of Symfony) showing the roadmap for Symfony 3.0 and an overview of how they merge bugfixes into older, supported versions of Symfony. This is in contrast to Drupal whereby the community expects and plans for major core updates to break APIs and works around them, an aspect that may contribute to Drupal\u2019s occasional reputation problem - especially for those unfamiliar with the way the development community manages with this policy.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Blackfire"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Most exciting of all was the ability to speak with the developers behind my favourite tool this year:\u00a0Blackfire. Blackfire is a fantastic tool that allows developers to profile specific pages and even benchmark them over time. It\u2019s not restricted to a particular framework or product, so it works as well with Drupal 6 as it does with Silex.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tools such as New Relic offer something similar, but only on your production server. This is great for measuring overall trends and metrics over time, but if it is telling you that your site is too slow on production - it\u2019s telling you too late! That performance bottleneck could be costing you page impressions, user engagement or even online shopping revenue from abandoned transactions.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Blackfire solves\u00a0the headache\u00a0usually associated with setting up tools like XHProf and KCacheGrind to provide a visualisation of where the bottlenecks in a page might be. It works by installing a probe in the form of a simple Linux package on your host machine or server. There is a Chrome plugin that is then able to read data from that probe and a web interface to present the profile in a way that is easy to analyse. At its best, Blackfire is also able to tell you how much network traffic is taking place and specific SQL queries that are taking place at specific points in the call stack.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Symfony", "image": 1306, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In the past, getting this insight has required either some educated guesswork in conjunction with data from XHProf and usually the devel module. We expect to be making heavy use of Blackfire and can\u2019t wait to put it to good use on new and existing projects.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

SymfonyLive\u00a0was a great event to attend and I hope Torchbox will be able to share some insight of our first Drupal 8 projects in the wild next year.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

I was excited to learn that my first project at Torchbox would be a Drupal project\u2026 but with a twist.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As Ru explained in an earlier blog post, the project I would be working on was to be a headless Drupal build, using Silex for the front-end, and templating with Twig rather than with Drupal\u2019s own theming system. This presented a challenge but also an opportunity to expand my horizons and experience working in a different way than I was used to.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019d heard only good things about Twig from friends in the development community, and together with its adoption into Drupal 8, I was looking forward to getting stuck in.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It didn\u2019t take long to get my head around the two basic types of delimiter; evaluation tags {% \u2026 %} which are used to set variables, test conditions, loop through arrays, and output tags {{ \u2026 }} which are used for translating values into strings. Using each type of tag where needed allows Twig to flexibly accommodate almost any markup structure that you could wish for. With this knowledge, and the theory behind one of Twig\u2019s most powerful features, template inheritance, I was free to begin moulding the structure of the site to do what we needed it to.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For our project, we chose to work outwards from a base template containing all the blocks needed for the site. A block simply represents a region: a chunk of code contained within {% block [name] %} \u2026 {% endblock %} tags. You are not compelled to work in this way, but it worked well for us.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The majority of the project\u2019s templates inherit their markup structure from the aforementioned base, and will typically alter it by overriding one or more blocks. For example, the site\u2019s user dashboard, which contains relevant content from the site based on the information we have about them, overrides the content block with its own dashboard-related content. Listed on the dashboard are groups of articles called collections, which users of the site can create and populate if they wish to. Wherever we need to display a list of a user\u2019s collections, we simply include the collection template, passing it an array of values it needs to display. This clever inheritance system cuts down greatly on code duplication and speeds up development.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Earlier I mentioned Twig\u2019s evaluation tags, between which you can use test conditions and loop through arrays, among other things. Twig also provides themers with filters, which are kind of like encapsulated functions. They perform operations on a given value or series of values, providing you with a great deal of flexibility. From relatively simple usages, such as capitalising the first letter of a sentence (|capitalize), through to more complex operations such as merging two arrays together (|merge) or batching together groups of items within an array for output (|batch), Twig\u2019s filters are so useful and can save so much time. Check out the full list at Twig\u2019s documentation.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At first, it didn\u2019t sit quite right with me to be including \u201clogic\u201d in the template files, especially as naturally and liberally as you can with Twig. Surely this couldn\u2019t be right given the amount of times I\u2019d had it drilled into me that logic does not belong in template files. But why would these brilliant, useful tools even be a part of Twig if they weren\u2019t supposed to be used? I happened to mention this to another developer on the project, who went on to say something very wise, something I hadn\u2019t even considered before. He made the distinction between \u201cbusiness\u201d logic (for want of a better word), and \u201ctheming\u201d logic. Theming logic, relating purely to layout and the display of data, is perfectly allowed in your templates, so join me in making full use of Twig\u2019s built in functions and filters and don\u2019t ever feel bad about it.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As I spend more time using Twig, I\u2019m continually learning about new conveniences that Twig provides the themer. On one occasion I needed something to happen on the first iteration of a loop. Simple enough, right? Yes, but not the way I was doing it. I was testing on the key of the array, which is not ideal since it requires the keys to be both numeric and sequential, which mine weren\u2019t. No longer than five seconds after I was through making the necessary changes to my array, a colleague sent through an article entitled \u2018Where am I in the Twig Loop?\u2019 which outlines several dedicated loop variables provided by Twig \u2013 the exact solution to my problem! I could simply test on loop.first, and so I did there and then.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

All of this is not to say that there haven\u2019t been any bumps in the road using Twig for our project, but I am inclined to think that many, if not all, of them could be smoothed out on future projects. Take as a case in point the bloating of our templates directory. Having as we did no meaningful structure to the files living in said directory, nor any agreed-upon convention for file names, it was difficult to locate the correct file at times. This is something which could be rectified with a little forethought and some kind of plan.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Overall, I have been very impressed with Twig. After spending the best part of my career so far working with Drupal\u2019s theming system, which certainly has its own strengths, it was a pleasure to work with a tool that hands over so much of the responsibility over to you. Rather than overriding existing templates, there will be nothing in your site\u2019s markup that you didn\u2019t put there. Twig is a mature and robust templating language that I would not hesitate to recommend using it on a future project.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Resident podcasting expert Leon starts off this regular feature with a look at some of his favourites.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Guardian | Tech Weekly"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Tech Weekly\u00a0is a marvellous podcast that tackles topics tied to tech and new media and delivers insightful debate in an accessible format. Even the less techy among us can get into Tech Weekly.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To put this into context, why not start with the episode \u201cIs the writing on the wall for Reddit\u201d from the 16th July 2015.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Reddit is, at the time of typing these words, among the 10 most trafficked sites on the web, but recent turmoil lost Reddit a CEO. What is the role of social media culture on the web, or the role of social media in culture? And where is the line between free speech and blatant harassment?

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Interviews with people in the know, and who are sometimes at the core of the site that proclaims itself \u201cthe\u00a0front-page\u00a0of the internet\u201d, draw focus to different ways to improve or remove a slice of the internet where women\u2019s voices are undervalued. Overall, an incredibly interesting episode of an already fascinating podcast.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "TORCH | The Oxford Research Centre in the Humanities"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

All right, let\u2019s have a look at a podcast episode that may be very relevant to some of you \u2013 certainly to many of our clients. At Torchbox, we work with a lot of charities and organisations, part of whose online presence concerns fundraising.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I was already going to bring up\u00a0TORCH, the podcast of The Oxford Research Centre in the Humanities\u00a0for several reasons, but imagine my delight when on the 3rd August 2015 they released a lecture entitled \u201cFundraising through Digital\u201d.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In this lecture, Michael Docherty, Digital Director at Cancer Research UK, talks through some of the perils that charities face in the digital age, but also how best to scale those obstacles, or at the very least circumvent them. With a healthy application of hacktivism, clicktivism, slacktivism (!) and game design, they did some very innovative and\u00a0excited\u00a0work. Docherty also talks about identifying digital trends and riding the right waves.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Well worth a listen, we think! TORCH already had a seat reserved on this shortlist regardless, though. First off, I\u2019ll admit, as a member of an Oxfordshire digital agency and a resident of Oxford myself, I\u2019m naturally biased. Secondly, TORCH (the centre) does fascinating work and TORCH (the podcast) gives people who aren\u2019t able to attend their lectures in person an opportunity to listen in.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So whether you\u2019re interested in fundraising through digital, check out the link here below \u2013 you can sit back and watch the lectures yourself, and there\u2019s even an RSS feed for those of us who prefer subscribing to audio podcasts on iTunes.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "The WIRED.co.uk Podcast"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here\u2019s a podcast that a lot of you may already be familiar with. WIRED is a trusted source of tech news for a great amount of people.\u00a0The WIRED podcast\u00a0is no less worthy of mention.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As a show that reviews the past week\u2019s tech news, it\u2019s a podcast that\u2019s well-worth subscribing to, but episode-specific recommendations risk quickly dating this\u00a0blogpost\u00a0or losing their relevancy.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Whatever, say we. Here\u2019s an interesting one with which to introduce this podcast to your deeply appreciative ears.\u00a0Episode 230, which dropped on iTunes on the 14th August 2015, entitled \u201cSpace salad,\u00a0Alphabet\u00a0and RIP to LOL\u201d had some of us in stitches.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "BBC Radio 4 | Digital Human"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Count on the BBC to deliver.\u00a0Digital Human\u00a0is a great radio show on BBC Radio 4. And if you reject radio as a defunct technology, fret not \u2013\u00a0it\u2019s also available as a podcast.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I have to admit, this one\u2019s a bit of a personal favourite of mine. It covers both mankind\u2019s approach to technology and the impact of digital culture on what makes us human.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

No aspect of our regular, mortal lives is off-limits. Digital Human has tackled such diverse subjects as the environment and love, seduction and mischief.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Paradoxically, I find that the episodes of Digital Human that deal with the analogue are among the most interesting. Take the episode Language, for instance, from the 20th October 2014. In it, they discussed one of our oldest technologies, namely, language. They even interviewed people who invent and/or keep alive \u201cmade-up\u201d languages like Lojban,\u00a0Klingon\u00a0and Dothraki.\u00a0Mutce\u00a0cinri!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

(That\u2019s \u201cvery interesting\u201d in Lojban.)

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Having recently returned from Drupalcon Barcelona, I wanted to share my experience of the day after the final conference day - Friday, the sprints day.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019ve been to sprints before and always found them to leave me a little wanting. You wander into a quiet room of people coding, there are usually a few recognisable faces, although often well-known core contributors than friends.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "DrupalCon Barcelona Sprints"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The goal in Barcelona was to attend the sprint day working towards completing an issue and then see what was happening in the afternoon (not necessarily more sprinting!). What happened was something else entirely.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "DrupalCon Barcelona attendees", "image": 1058, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupalcon had three sprint rooms available: a first-time sprinters room, dedicated to helping people get builds set up, how to find issues to work on, create patches, etc.; a general sprint room that seemed to be made up of groups of people working on\u00a0contrib\u00a0modules; and a mentored core sprint room. Amazingly they were all filling up quickly, each housing somewhere in the region of 100-200 people!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It was the latter that I walked into and was immediately asked what sort of work I wanted to take on. The room had several yellow t-shirt wearing mentors available to hand out relevant issues to be worked on, rather than leaving sprinters to look for themselves.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The ticket that I looked into taking on was quite a large issue that had been around for a while. Before long, I was sitting at a table with others looking for things to do. I explained what the issue was and how we may go about tackling it. The work was quickly split four ways, lending itself to everyone\u2019s strengths: PHP, JS, CSS and research/testing.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As a team, we worked on this ticket until a break came around for lunch. The morning had been filled with several discussions about how we might tackle the ticket and ended up going through several iterations before settling on a solution.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Live Commits"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After lunch, work continued on this issue until an announcement was made that there would be live commits for those whose tickets had been accepted as ready. This really gave some impetus to the work being done, as having code\u00a0(you\u2019d just written) being committed to core live would be something that doesn\u2019t happen very often at all.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Glenn taking part in the DrupalCon Barcelona sprints", "image": 1056, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When the time came, everyone piled into the first-time\u00a0sprinters\u00a0room where Angie (AKA, 'webchick') was ready to present.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The mentors were all introduced with a round of applause, recognising the hard work that they\u2019d put into making the day such a success.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Unfortunately,\u00a0the issue that we were working on wasn\u2019t ready in time, but it was great to see some other work being committed live. Everyone had a chance to say who they were and what they had contributed to the ticket. It was very encouraging to see all pieces come together and be equally appreciated, whether it was initially raising the ticket, putting\u00a0code\u00a0together and creating patches, testing or reviewing.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Making Drupal 8 a Better Product"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Following the live commits, we got back to working on the issue that we\u2019d been given, although all too quickly 6pm came around and the warning came that the conference centre was closing.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Having had initial thoughts of how long we might stay sprinting, it was very surprising that everyone got so caught up in the atmosphere, working towards making Drupal 8 a better product.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Work continues on the issue, having been looked into by some of the more senior core contributors.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019d encourage anyone to get involved with code sprints, especially if you haven\u2019t before, as it appears that the barrier to entry is lowering. Getting commits RTBC\u2019d (Ready To Be Committed) is another matter entirely...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Special thanks to\u00a0Rachel\u00a0for mentoring and the team I worked with:\u00a0Adrian,\u00a0Jari\u00a0and\u00a0Darko.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

All in all, it was a great day, full of drive and enthusiasm.\u00a0Can\u2019t wait for the next one!

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

World Leaders have committed to 17 Global Goals to achieve by 2030 but if they are to stick to them, everyone needs to know about them. Here are the goals which are most important to some of our team.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Chris W, #16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Goal 16 (Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions) is the most important Global Goal to me. The arms trade,\u00a0war\u00a0and its after-effects are major causes of much of the world's problems. Without war, we would have more stable societies and families. Without war, we would have less poverty and hunger. Without war, we would have better sanitation and infrastructure so that economies could flourish. Without war, we would have more money to invest in education and health care. Without war, countries could co-operate to make the world kinder, fairer and more sustainable.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Goal #16", "image": 565, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Justine, #3 Good Health & Well-being"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When I was diagnosed with Crohn's disease, last year, medical professionals seemed happy enough to give me strong, expensive, drugs to prevent the symptoms and other drugs to ease the side effects the first drugs gave me. To me, this didn't seem right so I put more effort into looking after myself. Educating myself to be more aware of what my body and mind needs means that I don't need to take the medicines. I've found the triggers to my illness and I'm managing them using a better diet, meditation and relaxation techniques that cost me, and the government, next to nothing.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Goal #3", "image": 578, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Johan, #14 Life Below Water"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Partly because I think it's both generally overlooked and impossible to get decent results without continental or even global coordination. Oceanic health and fishery stocks are interconnected with everything else and I don't think it's reasonable for any country to temporarily or permanently absolve itself of responsibility in the interests of, say, retaining GDP over an arbitrary baseline.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Goal #14", "image": 579, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Rich, #15 Life on Land"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As the dominant species on the planet and architects of the forthcoming\u00a0sixth mass\u00a0extinction,\u00a0I believe we have a duty to protect and enhance the lives and habitats of every creature, not just our own.

Sadly we're not doing very well! :-(

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Goal #15", "image": 580, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Olly, #2 Zero Hunger"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I'm particularly motivated by the hunger goal because of my involvement with Valid Nutrition (VN), an Irish Charity\u00a0(of which I'm a founding member).\u00a0VN is led by my friend Dr.\u00a0Steve Collins\u00a0who has been the central figure behind the development and expansion of\u00a0CMAM\u00a0(Community-based Management of Acute Malnutrition) and is working to\u00a0address\u00a0the problem of chronic malnutrition too: over one-third of all children in developing countries globally experience chronic malnutrition \u2013 often referred to as \u201chidden hunger\u201d. Aside from the inherent suffering, the devastating longer-term consequences (both\u00a0developmentally\u00a0for the child and ultimately for their country) are often\u00a0not understood.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Goal #2", "image": 581, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Jason, #4 Quality Education"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Since the goals were announced, I must have changed my mind several times about which one is the most important to me. You can\u2019t end poverty unless you also tackle climate change and good health is not possible without clean water and sanitation.\u00a0In the end,\u00a0I feel quality education is the foundation of everything. Education supports a person to be independent and stand up against inequality. It's a well-used saying but I do believe\u00a0\u201cGive a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach a man to fish (responsibly) and you feed him for a lifetime.\u201d

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Ultimately these 17 Global Goals are a blueprint for the World we want to live in and hopefully by the year 2030 it will be a reality. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Global Goal #4", "image": 564, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "More information"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The new Global Goals replace the Millennium Development Goals which between 1990 - 2015 helped lift more than 1 billion people out of extreme poverty. If you want to remind yourself of these goals, here's some work we did for One.

"}]

fields.intro: We're working with Facebook and Praekelt Foundation to build a Wagtail-powered platform for the Free Basics project.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We've been fans of the\u00a0Praekelt Foundation\u00a0since we discovered their\u00a0Molo\u00a0app ('a set of tools for publishing\u00a0mobi\u00a0sites with a community focus')\u00a0earlier this year.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Soon after, we came across their excellent 'Ways of Working' document, which we are shamelessly reusing here at Torchbox. So we're delighted to announce a new partnership with Praekelt and Facebook on a Wagtail-powered platform for the Free Basics project, which is launching today.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Free Basics: Your Service Here", "image": 582, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Initially, the project will provide support and resources to 100 social change organisations, selected by an independent panel (sign up\u00a0here). Later in 2016, the tools developed for this incubator programme will be opened up to the public, allowing\u00a0thousands\u00a0more organisations to build and launch sites which create sustainable change and make their content freely available via low-end mobile devices.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We'll be working with\u00a0Praekelt Foundation and Facebook to develop and document the technical platform which will underpin the project. Based on\u00a0Wagtail, the toolkit will generate content which is optimised for Facebook's\u00a0Free Basics\u00a0distribution platform (\"free access to basic internet services to a billion people all over the world\"). It'll be simple to use and cheap to host. Because both projects are open source, the outputs of this work will be shared with the upstream Wagtail CMS. We can't wait to get started.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about the Free Basics platform, which will be powered by Wagtail, please get in touch. We'd love to hear from you.

"}]

fields.intro: After four years of development by 3,312 contributors from 90 countries, Drupal 8 is finally here.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Drupal 8\u00a0has just been released.\u00a0There have been release candidates for the past few months, and some brave souls accepted the risks of pre-release software and built new sites with it. But today is the day when the Drupal community has announced that Drupal 8 is ready for everyone.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "So what does this mean for you?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you\u2019re a developer, and you haven\u2019t had a look at the changes in Drupal 8 yet, now\u2019s the time to check it out. While everything is different under the hood, and there is much to learn, Drupal 8 still\u00a0feels\u00a0like Drupal.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Drupal 6"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you have a Drupal 6 site, the release of Drupal 8 comes with a deadline: support for Drupal 6 will now end on\u00a024 February 2016. If you haven't already started planning to replace your Drupal 6 site, the time to do so is now. Your site isn\u2019t going to stop working after 24 February 2016, but it will be more vulnerable to potential security issues.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "We celebrated the release of Drupal 8 with cake", "image": 598, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Drupal 7"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal 7 has still plenty of life left in\u00a0it\u00a0though. Drupal 8 may have arrived, but it will take time for Drupal\u2019s formidable suite of contributed modules, many of which are essential to building complex sites, to all be ported to Drupal 8. If you\u2019re planning a new site that depends on a contributed module that won\u2019t be ported to Drupal 8 for some time yet, building that site with 7 is still a solid choice, and Drupal 7 will be supported by the community for several years to come.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Head over to\u00a0drupal.org\u00a0for the latest news, or check out our previous posts on\u00a0what\u2019s new in Drupal 8.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And do get in touch\u00a0to have a chat about migrating from Drupal 6 or 7 to 8, or if you want to dive straight in with a new site on Drupal 8.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Many of the applications we've developed have been used for many years with the ongoing addition of features. So, it's important to keep them up to date with the latest that Django has to offer - new functionality, improvements to existing ones and, of course, continuing security updates.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "iShamba"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mediae\u2019s iShamba mobile service is helping Kenyan farmers be more independent by giving them the latest commodity prices, weather forecasts or tips such as when to harvest your crops and which pests and diseases to be on the lookout for - all via mobile. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Find out more about the project

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "A Kenyan farmer uses a mobile phone in the field", "image": 632, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "CIFF Grant Portfolio"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

CIFF (Children\u2019s Investment Fund Foundation) have embraced transparency by presenting their grant portfolio through visual graphs, which allows users to see exactly how money has been spent tackling issues including child nutrition, health and education.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Read the case study

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Each time a grant page is updated, added or removed by an editor, the totals are recalculated and the bar chart updates.", "image": 1268, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Upshot"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Upshot,\u00a0the Football Foundation\u2019s grant impact monitoring and evaluation system, started off as a project to make data collection easier. The system, which collects information on how grants are being used by community projects, has now grown into a service adopted by banks, local councils and other charities to monitor their own projects. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Read the case study

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Supporting community projects", "image": 633, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At Torchbox we want to be a part of the Data Revolution - we believe it will make the world a better place.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you have a Data for Development idea you\u2019re planning to bring to life, we would love to hear from you. Drop us an email at\u00a0hello@torchbox.com\u00a0or tweet your idea to\u00a0@torchbox\u00a0with the hashtag #D4D\u00a0\u00a0

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We are in the process of putting together a Guide To Google Ad Grants which we plan to launch at the ECF conference in Oxford in April.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you\u2019re new to Ad Grants, Google provides eligible charities with $10,000 a month to spend on AdWords, Google's pay-per-click advertising system. If you fulfil certain criteria, you can apply for Grantspro. If approved, that means $40,000 a month to spend.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Google Grants", "image": 734, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We regularly meet charities who either haven\u2019t got a Google Ad Grant or aren\u2019t spending the media spend they have at their disposal.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is backed up by reports from a few years ago that said the average Google Ad Grant recipient only spends $300 a month of the $10,000 available.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We work with charities to help them with their Ad Grants and we\u2019re running a survey to find out if charities have an Ad Grant and how they use it.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019ll do all we can to make the Ad Grants Guide as useful as it can be and it would be brilliant if you could spare ten minutes to fill out our survey!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019re going to put all those who complete the survey into a draw to win \u00a3500 for the charity of their choice.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019ll\u00a0also of course\u00a0give you the chance to receive the Ad Grants Guide which the survey findings will help us with.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Update: the survey was very successful and our best practice guide 'Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant' was launched at ECF.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

ECF was the first conference I went to after joining Torchbox six years ago and with Valentine\u2019s Day on Sunday I felt now would be a good time to explain why I love the event even though our first date back in 2010 didn\u2019t go totally smoothly - more on that later...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

ECF stands for eCampaigning Forum. As well as the\u00a0outstanding mailing list\u00a0that discusses all things campaigning and digital, Duane and the team also organise\u00a0training events\u00a0(there are some top ones in February) and the annual ECF Conference in Oxford\u00a0which will take place this year from 13 to 14 April.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "There's much to discuss at ECF", "image": 740, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Campaigning and digital folk from charities around the world flock to the event to discuss how digital can help them achieve their objectives.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I guess this sounds like any other digital conference - but I think ECF stands out from other events because of the format of the event and the people who attend.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The format requires participants to set the agenda for a big part of the event. You can put forward the burning issue you want to talk about, more often than not you\u2019ll find other people also want to talk about it so you form a session and share thoughts and experiences. In addition, there are also some outstanding guest speakers.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

And then\u00a0there\u2019s\u00a0the people - like-minded individuals with a great deal of experience of what works (and what doesn\u2019t) who are striving to make the world a better place. When ECF people get together, good things tend to happen.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To top it all off, the setting of Keble College is as near to a Harry Potter setting as you are likely to get. Stunning.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As I mentioned, our first date didn\u2019t go that smoothly. Back in 2010, I was extremely passionate about the power of broadcasting live from your mobile. I was on stage trying to convince delegates of just how easy it was and decided to do a demo. \u2018Let me show you just how easy it is,\u2019 said I just as my phone packed up. My face was redder than the reddest of roses which will be given out on Sunday...

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Hey ho, it\u2019s been upwards and onwards since then and if you\u2019re passionate about digital and making the world a better place please\u00a0do come along to ECF.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Torchbox are an ECF sponsor once again this year and we\u2019ll be launching a Google Ad Grants guide at the event - hope to see you there.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Find out more about the ever-so-ace\u00a0ECF conference in Oxford\u00a0from 13 to 14 April as well as their other events and mailing list.

"}]

fields.intro: The layout of Google search results pages is changing. Ads have disappeared from the right-hand side. Find out how this affects charities with Google Ad Grants.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

The layout of Google search results pages is changing. Over the past two weeks, Google has stopped showing ads in the right-hand column on desktop searches. There are now up to four ad slots above the search results and up to three below. How will this impact charities with Google Ad Grants?

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My first reaction is that it\u2019s good news. Ads above the search results receive a much higher clickthrough rate than ads to the right of or below the organic results. Google users have developed a blind spot on the right-hand side and rarely click those ads. Top ads look more like organic search results and stand out \u2014 especially if they have ad extensions such as sitelinks, callouts, structured snippets and a phone number.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "An optimized Google Ad Grants ad with sitelinks and callout ad extensions.", "image": 792, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We examined data from 27 Google Ad Grants accounts dating back a number of years. We found that top ads have a clickthrough rate of 6.38% compared to 0.28% for ads in the other positions on the right and below the organic results. Top ads also generated 95% of the clicks in our large dataset of over 16 million clicks. We\u2019re hardly going to notice losing the clicks from side ads with these layout changes by Google.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Most of our clients\u2019 Google Ad Grants accounts have an average ad position between 1 and 3. This means the majority of their ads appear above the results. These accounts are well structured with tightly-themed ad groups, optimized ad copy and relevant landing pages. We use ad extensions whenever possible. We also try to end description line 1 of the ad with a punctuation mark. This makes the ads more likely to appear in the top positions and increases the chances that description line 1 will be promoted next to the headline to take up more horizontal space.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Note how the Google Ad Grants ad for the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust has an extended headline with description line 1 promoted to the headline. This takes up more horizontal space and helps the ad to stand out. It also signals to Google that the ad is optimized and can be shown in the top positions.", "image": 793, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you\u2019ve taken good care of your Google Ad Grants account and followed Google\u2019s best practice guidelines for AdWords, you shouldn\u2019t have too much to worry about.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

But if your average ad position is 4 or worse, or you\u2019re in a particularly competitive keyword territory, then you\u2019ve got some work to do to get your account into shape!

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What changes can you expect to see?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I expect to see higher clickthrough rates as fewer impressions are wasted on side ads. I also anticipate fewer impressions because there are fewer ad spots available for each search query. Before the change, the maximum was 11 ads (3 top + 8 side). Now there\u2019s a maximum of 7 (4 top + 3 bottom).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This might mean that for more competitive search queries your ads won\u2019t show as often as they did before. But when your ads do show, and they appear above the results, you\u2019re more likely to get clicks.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"With the new layout changes, you can expect to get more clicks, higher CTRs and lower CPCs in your Google Ad Grants account.\"", "attribution": "Christopher Whalen, Search and Analytics Consultant, Torchbox"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What does the early data show?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These predictions are confirmed by the data we\u2019re seeing in our accounts since Google started rolling out the layout changes on 18 February 2016. We\u2019re getting 11% more clicks in our Google Ad Grants accounts. Impressions are down by 6% and clickthrough rate has improved from 3.80% to 4.48% (that\u2019s an 18% bump). Average cost per click is down 4% and average position is 19% higher. All of these are positive outcomes. The loss of impressions doesn\u2019t matter if you\u2019re getting more clicks and a higher clickthrough rate.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We are also seeing a higher proportion of impressions coming from the top ads. Before the change, 46% of Google Ad Grants impressions occurred in the top positions. Since 18 February, we\u2019ve seen 64% of impressions come from the top ads. So although charities with Google Ad Grants can expect to get fewer impressions, when their ads do appear they will be in the more visible and impactful top positions.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "The single-column layout of Google mobile searches is coming to desktop.", "image": 795, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Why is Google changing the desktop layout?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Removing the side ads is consistent with Google\u2019s emphasis on improving the user experience. If users aren\u2019t clicking on side ads, this suggests they\u2019re not working. Why waste the real estate? Google isn\u2019t earning revenue from side ads. Users aren\u2019t finding useful results. Advertisers aren\u2019t getting quality clicks. It makes sense to scrap them.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It also brings the desktop experience closer to the single-column layout of mobile searches, where top and bottom ads are the norm.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Average ad position will also become a more meaningful metric. Previously position 1 could mean the top ad above the results, the top ad in the right column if there aren\u2019t any top ads for that query or the first ad below the results if there are neither top or side ads. This was confusing! Now position 1 will more often than not mean the top ad above the results.

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\"Google isn\u2019t earning revenue from side ads. Users aren\u2019t finding useful results. Advertisers aren\u2019t getting quality clicks. It makes sense to scrap them.\"", "attribution": "Christopher Whalen, Search and Analytics Consultant, Torchbox"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s too soon to know if these trends will hold, but I\u2019m confident that if you have a well-maintained Google Ad Grants account, you don\u2019t have much to worry about with the new desktop layout for Google searches. In fact, you should start to see better results: more quality clicks at a lower cost. What\u2019s not to like?

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Have you noticed any impact on your Google Ad Grants account yet? If so, let me know @domeheid\u00a0on Twitter.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Three of us just spent a week in Cape Town, as guests of the Praekelt Foundation, who hosted a Wagtail CMS sprint involving their team and two of the other Wagtail core developers from Australia and New Zealand. We made some good friends and fantastic progress on the open source project - see my post on the Wagtail blog for all the details.

"}]

fields.intro: Learn how to link AdWords to Google Analytics, import Google Analytics goals as conversions in AdWords and show Google Analytics traffic quality data such as bounce rate and pages/session in AdWords reports.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Learn how to link AdWords to Google Analytics, import Google Analytics goals as conversions in AdWords and show Google Analytics traffic quality data such as bounce rate and pages/session in AdWords reports.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Linking your Google Analytics account to AdWords will help you understand what happens after someone clicks on your ads. You should want to know whether your ad campaigns are helping you achieve your organizational objectives.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With linked accounts you will get more detailed data about your AdWords campaigns in Google Analytics, you will be able to import your goals and\u00a0ecommerce\u00a0transactions into AdWords as conversions and you will be able to see traffic quality data such as bounce rate, pages per session and average session duration for campaigns, ad groups and keywords within AdWords. This will give you the data you need to optimize your account for conversions and better quality traffic. It will also help you fulfil one of the criteria to qualify for Grantspro.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To link Google Analytics to AdWords you will need to use a Google account login that has administrative access to AdWords and edit permission for Analytics. Then follow this process:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

1) Sign\u00a0in to\u00a0your Google Analytics\u00a0account\u00a0at\u00a0www.google.com/analytics.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

2) Click the\u00a0Admin\u00a0tab at the top of the page.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Screenshot of Google Analytics admin.", "image": 1332, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

3) In the Account column, select the Analytics account that contains the property you want to link with your Google Ad Grants account. We recommend using a property that tracks all of the sites you want to promote with your ads. Some organizations call this their roll-up tracker.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

4) In the Property column, select the Analytics property you want to link, and click\u00a0AdWords Linking.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

5) Select your Google Ad Grants AdWords account to link it with your Analytics property. You may want to check the customer ID number if you have more than one AdWords account. We recommend linking your paid AdWords account in the same way so that you can distinguish in Google Analytics between Google Ad Grants and paid AdWords campaigns.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

6) Click the\u00a0Continue\u00a0button.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

7) In the Link configuration section, enter a link group title (e.g. Google Ad Grants) to identify your linked AdWords account.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

8) Select the Analytics views in which you want the AdWords data to be available. We recommend selecting all views.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

9) The account linking process will enable auto-tagging for your linked Google Ad Grants AdWords account. You can check this in AdWords under Account settings / Preferences / Tracking. Auto-tagging should be enabled.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

10) Click the\u00a0Link accounts\u00a0button.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Now that your accounts are linked, you can import Analytics goals and transactions into AdWords Conversion Tracking and add Google Analytics data such as bounce rate, pages per session and average session duration to AdWords reports.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Import Analytics goals and transactions into AdWords Conversion Tracking"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

First of all, we hope you are already tracking meaningful goals in Google Analytics! These could be donations, event registrations, file downloads, email sign-ups or form completions\u2014whatever it is you are trying to get users to do on your website.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you don\u2019t have any goals, get on it! A quick one to get you started is Smart Goals, which was designed exactly for people like you. See this post in our Google Ad Grants blog series for details about\u00a0Smart Goals.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To import your goals and\u00a0ecommerce\u00a0transactions from Analytics into AdWords Conversion Tracking, the following conditions must apply:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Your Analytics and Google Ad Grants accounts are linked.
  • You\u2019ve enabled auto-tagging in your Google Ad Grants account.
  • On a per-type basis, your Analytics goal or transaction has received active traffic from a Google Ad Grants ad at some point.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To import your goals:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

1) After you've linked your Google Ad Grants and Analytics accounts, wait 30 minutes for the imports to be ready (go and have a cup of tea and a slice of cake\u2014you deserve it!). Then, sign\u00a0in to\u00a0your Google Ad Grants account, click the\u00a0Tools\u00a0tab,\u00a0and select\u00a0Conversions.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

2) Click\u00a0Analytics\u00a0in the left-hand menu.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

3) Check the boxes next to the goals or transactions you want to import. Click\u00a0Continue.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

4) On the next page, you'll see settings that will apply to all of the goals or transactions you selected. The categories (Other, Purchase/Sale, Sign up, Lead and View of a key page) will appear\u00a0under\u00a0the \"Conversion category\" segment that you can apply to your AdWords reports. The conversion window (choose between 7-90 days; the default is 30 days) is the period of time after someone clicks your ad during which a conversion is recorded in AdWords. Unless you have a logical reason to change it, stick to 30 days. Make your choices, then click\u00a0Import goals.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

5) Click\u00a0Close, or to import more goals, click\u00a0Import more.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

AdWords Conversion Tracking starts importing the data from your Analytics account starting from the day you clicked\u00a0Import. You should see it within two days. But you won\u2019t see historical conversion data.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you want to change the name of an imported goal, you need to make the change in Analytics.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Add Google Analytics data to AdWords reports"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Before you can add Google Analytics data to your AdWords reports, you\u2019ll need to do the following:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Enable auto-tagging in your Google Ad Grants account.
  • Link your Google Ad Grants and Google Analytics accounts. Make sure you import site metrics for the view you want to see in your Google Ad Grants account. We recommend using your default view that covers all the sites you are sending traffic to from your ads.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To see your Google Analytics data in AdWords, follow the instructions below to add Google Analytics reporting columns to your AdWords reports:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

1) Sign\u00a0into\u00a0your Google Ad Grants account.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

2) Click\u00a0Campaigns\u00a0at the top of the screen.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

3) Click the tab you want to add Google Analytics columns\u00a0to:\u00a0Campaigns,\u00a0Ad groups,\u00a0Ads,\u00a0or\u00a0Keywords.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

4) Click the\u00a0Columns\u00a0menu and select\u00a0Modify columns\u00a0from the drop-down.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

5) Under \u201cSelect metrics\u201d, click\u00a0Google Analytics.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Screenshot of modifying Google AdWords columns.", "image": 860, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

6) To select your columns, click the arrow icon next to each column you\u2019d like to add. We recommend including Bounce rate, Pages per session and Avg. session duration (seconds) and saving the set of columns so that you can switch back to it easily.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

7) Click\u00a0Apply.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Now when you are assessing the performance of a keyword or ad, you will have some extra data points about traffic quality. For example, if your ad has a high bounce rate, try a different landing page!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Further Reading"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Google Ad Grants: Use Ad Extensions
  • Google Ad Grants: Dynamic Keyword Insertion
  • Google Ad Grants: Remove Duplicate Keywords
  • Google Ad Grants: Create a Shared Budget for All Campaigns\u00a0
  • Google Ad Grants: Improve CTR with Automated Rules
"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

One of the requirements for Grantspro is an account-wide clickthrough rate (CTR) of 1% over the past six months.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

CTR is also a fundamental metric for the health of your Google Ad Grants account. CTR is an important factor in Quality Score, so the higher your CTR, the healthier your account will be, the higher your ads will appear and the less you\u2019ll have to pay for your clicks. Cheaper clicks also\u00a0means\u00a0more clicks for your $10,000 a month.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You should be aiming to get a CTR of at least 1%. It\u2019s weird to fail 99 times out of 100 and still call it a success!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If an ad or keyword\u2019s CTR is below that 1% threshold and it\u2019s had a fair amount of traffic (at least 200 impressions) or it\u2019s been running for 30 days, it\u2019s time to do something about it.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our favourite tactic for keeping your CTR in good shape is to create an automated rule that runs every day at 23:00 and pauses any keywords with more than 200 impressions and less than 1% CTR all-time. This ensures that any high-volume keywords (especially broad matches) that get lots of impressions but few clicks don\u2019t ruin your account-wide CTR and Quality Score.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our Google Ad Grants survey showed that only 7% of charities use automated rules, so here\u2019s a quick way to get ahead of your competition and set up your account to optimize itself.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

1) Sign\u00a0in to\u00a0your Google Ad Grants account.
2) Click\u00a0Campaigns\u00a0at the top of the screen.
3) Click the\u00a0Keywords\u00a0tab.
4) Click the\u00a0Automate\u00a0button and select\u00a0Pause keywords\u00a0when.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Screenshot of how to create an automated rule in Google AdWords.", "image": 861, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

5) Configure the rule as follows:

  • Apply to\u00a0All but removed keywords in all campaigns
  • Requirements:\u00a0CTR < 1% (less than 1%) and\u00a0Impressions >= 200 (more than or equal to 200)
  • Frequency: Daily 23 (i.e. 23:00) using data from\u00a0All time
  • Give the rule a name such as \u201cPause keywords with low CTR\u201d
  • You may wish to receive an email every time this automated rule runs for the first few days, but this will soon become white noise in your inbox, so we usually disable emails.
"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Screenshot of automated rule settings to pause keywords in low CTR in Google AdWords.", "image": 862, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

6) Click\u00a0Preview results\u00a0to see how it will impact your account.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

7) Click\u00a0Save.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As a regular maintenance task, we recommend reviewing paused keywords in your account. Check the search terms report for these keywords to see if you can harvest any of the search terms as exact match keywords and add them to your account.\u00a0Also\u00a0look out for negative keyword ideas. Then delete the paused keywords to keep your account uncluttered.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you need to modify your automated rule later, you will find it under Bulk operations / Automated rules in the left-hand menu.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Further Reading"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Google Ad Grants: Use Ad Extensions
  • Google Ad Grants: Dynamic Keyword Insertion
  • Google Ad Grants: Remove Duplicate Keywords
  • Google Ad Grants: Link Your Google Analytics Account to AdWords
  • Google Ad Grants: Create a Shared Budget for All Campaigns\u00a0
"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

One of the requirements for Grantspro is\u00a0spending at least\u00a0$9,900 in two of the past six months. This is much easier if, instead of setting budgets at the campaign level, you create a shared budget for all campaigns in your account.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our thinking behind this is that sometimes a campaign has the potential to spend more than the budget you set for it. If other campaigns spend under their budget limit then there\u2019s a risk you\u2019ll leave some of your daily budget of $329 unspent. Sharing the daily budget between all campaigns solves this problem.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It does give you less control over how much each campaign spends, but it\u2019s a small price to pay if it helps you qualify for\u00a0Grantspro,\u00a0when you\u2019ll have four times as much budget to play with in future.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our survey found that only 5% of charities are using shared budgets, so this appears to be a little-known technique to help you maximize how much you are spending.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Here\u2019s how to set a shared budget:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  1. Sign\u00a0in to\u00a0your Google Ad Grants account.
  2. Click\u00a0Campaigns\u00a0at the top of the screen.
  3. Click\u00a0Shared library\u00a0from the left-hand menu.
  4. Click\u00a0Budgets.
  5. Click the red\u00a0+ Budget\u00a0button.
  6. Give it a name such as \u201cShared budget\u201d.
  7. Select all campaigns. There\u2019s a double caret next to \u201cExisting campaigns\u201d, which adds all campaigns at once.
  8. Set the budget amount to $330 per day. Google states that the daily budget limit is $329 ($10,000 / 30.4, which is the average number of days per month) but in our experience, Google Ad Grants tend to max out closer to $330.
  9. Set the delivery method to\u00a0Accelerated\u00a0if you are trying to reach Grantspro and you think you might struggle to max out your budget. Otherwise, if you have a high-volume account and you want to ensure your ads run throughout more of the day, select\u00a0Standard.
  10. Click\u00a0Save.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Further Reading"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Google Ad Grants: Use Ad Extensions
  • Google Ad Grants: Dynamic Keyword Insertion
  • Google Ad Grants: Remove Duplicate Keywords
  • Google Ad Grants: Link Your Google Analytics Account to AdWords
"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

A great feature of Google AdWords Editor that isn\u2019t available in the AdWords web interface, is the\u00a0ability\u00a0to find and remove duplicate keywords. It\u2019s best practice to avoid duplicate keywords in your account, but it\u2019s something we often see when we start working on a charity\u2019s account.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Duplicate keywords compete against each other. They also prevent you controlling which ad appears for the keyword.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To remove them with\u00a0AdWords Editor, click\u00a0Tools\u00a0in the top menu and select\u00a0Find duplicate keywords. We recommend the following settings:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Select all campaigns
  • Select\u00a0Strict word order
  • For match types, select\u00a0Duplicates must have the same match type
  • For\u00a0location\u00a0of duplicates, select\u00a0Across selected campaigns.
  • We also recommend hiding duplicates in removed and ended campaigns and ad groups, and in paused campaigns and ad groups.
"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Screenshot of duplicate keyword tool settings in Google AdWords Editor.", "image": 855, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When you click the\u00a0Find duplicate keywords\u00a0button, you will be presented with a list of duplicate keywords. Go through the list and pause or delete keywords so that you only have one version of the keyword running. We recommend enabling the keyword in the highest-priority campaign or with the best performance (highest Quality Score, best CTR and conversion rate).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you have lots of duplicate campaigns with different location targeting settings, we recommend excluding these from your duplicate keyword search.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Keyword insertion automatically inserts the matched keyword into your ad copy. This makes your ads look more relevant, helps them stand out and increases clickthrough rate (CTR).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
