However, if you're going to use\u00a0keyword insertion, make sure you\u2019re happy for all the keywords in that ad group to be inserted. We name our ad groups clearly to indicate if they are suitable for keyword insertion or not.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We find the best place to use keyword insertion is in the headline. It\u2019s too difficult grammatically to use keyword insertion in the description lines.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are different formulas for keyword insertion but the one we recommend is:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

{KeyWord:Default Headline Here}

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This will capitalize the first letter of each keyword.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Keyword insertion is a great way to improve CTR\u2014particularly in the early days of an account\u2014but make sure you implement it carefully. You don\u2019t want to include typos or misspellings in your ad text.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We use it sparingly\u00a0in appropriate\u00a0ad groups that are carefully structured.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One thing to note that sometimes confuses people is that it\u2019s the matching\u00a0keyword\u00a0that is inserted, not the\u00a0search term\u00a0the user has typed into Google.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}]

fields.intro: Learn how to use ad extensions to give additional information below your Google Ad Grants ads. Improve CTR and Quality Score and make your ads stand out.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Ad extensions allow you to provide additional information below your basic ad copy. They take up more space, help your ads stand out and improve clickthrough rate (CTR) and Quality Score.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Sitelinks"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For example, with\u00a0sitelinks\u00a0you can add links to up to four additional pages below your ad. We use this to promote related content and events. Unlike organic\u00a0sitelinks, over which you have little control, AdWords\u00a0sitelinks\u00a0are fully customizable. Sitelinks are particularly good for your brand campaign because the expanded version with two lines of description\u00a0are\u00a0sometimes displayed.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Callout Extensions"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We also recommend using callout extensions, structured snippets and call extensions (if you have a phone number).\u00a0Callout extensions\u00a0are plain text. Unlike\u00a0sitelinks, they\u2019re not links. Google recommends writing callout extensions in sentence case. They are a great way to include more detail that you couldn\u2019t fit into the main ad text, such as the date and location of an event, the types of services your charity offers or calls to action. We aim to have 4-6 callouts per\u00a0campaign,\u00a0but note that not all of them will be displayed at once.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Structured Snippets"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Structured snippets\u00a0are similar to callout extensions, but give you the freedom to list more items in a group. Most of the structured snippets are aimed at more commercial advertisers, but you can use the \u201cTypes\u201d category to list related terms. For example, you could list the different types of rooms you have available for hire.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Call Extensions"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Call extensions\u00a0display your phone number. Mobile users will be able to click on this number and call you directly from the ad. This can be useful if your charity offers an advice hotline service or if you receive donations over the phone. If you are planning to use this feature, we recommend warning whoever will be answering the number to check if they have the capacity to deal with an increased number of calls.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "More Information"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Further Reading"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Google Ad Grants: Dynamic Keyword Insertion
  • Google Ad Grants: Remove Duplicate Keywords
  • Google Ad Grants: Link Your Google Analytics Account to AdWords
  • Google Ad Grants: Create a Shared Budget for All Campaigns
  • Google Ad Grants: Smart Goals\u00a0in Google Analytics
"}]

fields.intro: Learn how to use Smart Goals in Google Analytics. Smart Goals use machine learning to examine dozens of signals about your website visits to determine which of those are most likely to result in a conversion.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Smart Goals are an easy way to use your best visits as conversions. Smart Goals use machine learning to examine dozens of signals about your website visits to determine which of those are most likely to result in a conversion.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Each visit is assigned a score, with the \u201cbest\u201d visits being translated into\u00a0Smart Goals. Some examples of the signals included in the Smart Goals model are session duration, pages per session, location,\u00a0device\u00a0and browser.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We recommend creating a Smart Goal and importing it into your Google Ad Grants account as a conversion. You can then optimize your Google Ad Grants account for your best quality traffic. Smart Goals are especially useful if you aren\u2019t currently tracking any other meaningful goals in Google Analytics.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To use Smart Goals, your Google Ad Grants and Google Analytics accounts must be linked. You also need to have had at least 500 clicks in the past 30 days. You also need to enable data sharing with \u201cWith other Google products only\u201d in your Google Analytics account settings.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  1. Sign\u00a0in to\u00a0your Google Analytics\u00a0account.
  2. Select the\u00a0Admin\u00a0tab and navigate to the desired view.
  3. In the\u00a0VIEW\u00a0column, click\u00a0Goals.
  4. Click\u00a0+ NEW GOAL.
  5. Select Smart Goal (if available). If this option is greyed out, it means you have not sent 500 clicks to this view in the past 30 days.
  6. Give your Smart Goal a name (e.g. \u201cSmart Goal\u201d) and click\u00a0Save.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

You can then\u00a0import your Smart Goal as a conversion in your Google Ad Grants account\u00a0as described in a previous blog post.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Further Reading"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Google Ad Grants: Use Ad Extensions
  • Google Ad Grants: Dynamic Keyword Insertion
  • Google Ad Grants: Remove Duplicate Keywords
  • Google Ad Grants: Link Your Google Analytics Account to AdWords
  • Google Ad Grants: Create a Shared Budget for All Campaigns\u00a0
"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

With a standard Google Ad Grant, the priority is often to increase traffic volume in order to meet the spending requirement for Grantspro. But if you\u2019ve got the luxury of Grantspro, you can start to optimize for quality as well as quantity.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Don\u2019t worry about maxing out your Grantspro budget straight away. That will come with time as you build more campaigns. Remember all you have to do to maintain your Grantspro eligibility from a spending point of view is spend $9,900 in two of the past six months. Focus now on quality.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How to optimize keywords"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Go through each of your ad groups in turn and review the search terms report showing all-time data. If a search term has more than 200 impressions, better than 1% clickthrough rate (CTR) and is converting, add it as an exact match keyword. You can apply filters to the search term report and sort the columns in descending order to make your job easier.

Here\u2019s how you can configure the filters to show you new potential keywords:

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Screenshot of search terms report filter to identify new exact match keywords.", "image": 1328, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As you\u2019re reviewing the search terms report, we also recommend looking out for potential negative keywords. Either add them directly from the search terms report or keep a text file list of negative keywords that you can then add in bulk to your campaigns or negative keyword list later.

You should also review the traffic quality of the keywords. If an individual keyword has a conversion rate well below the account average (benchmarks will vary for each account), consider deleting it or moving it to its own ad group with more targeted ads and landing pages. If it\u2019s relatively low volume, you can safely delete it. If it\u2019s high volume, dig into the search terms report for that individual keyword to see if you could replace it with a few exact match keywords to exclude the less relevant traffic.

You can also optimize your keyword lists by adding traffic quality metrics from Google Analytics to your reports to show bounce rate, pages per session and average session duration. If the traffic quality is poor, consider deleting the keyword. You can always make up for the lost volume with a better keyword elsewhere.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Ad optimization"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Each of your ad groups should have three ads. When each ad has had at least 200 impressions or it\u2019s been active for 30 days, you can start to optimize. Decide what the best and worst performing ads are in terms of conversion rate, CTR and traffic quality. Delete the worst ad. Create a copy of the best ad and tweak it slightly to create a new variation. You may change the call to action, the headline or ad text. Try to change only one thing so that you can compare the performance against the best ad.

If you do this regularly, your success metrics will start to move in the right direction: traffic quality will improve, you\u2019ll get more conversions, CTR will increase, which in turn might give you a higher Quality Score, better ad positions and a lower cost per click.

The idea is to find out what works and do more of it. Weed out what doesn\u2019t work and eradicate it from your account.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more advice on getting the most from your Google Ad Grant, get your free copy of our best practice guide, \u2018Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u2019.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Further Reading"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Google Ad Grants: Use Ad Extensions
  • Google Ad Grants: Dynamic Keyword Insertion
  • Google Ad Grants: Remove Duplicate Keywords
  • Google Ad Grants: Link Your Google Analytics Account to AdWords
  • Google Ad Grants: Create a Shared Budget for All Campaigns\u00a0
  • Google Ad Grants: Improve CTR with Automated Rules
"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

British Swimming is the governing body for swimming, diving, synchronised swimming, water polo, and open water swimming in Great Britain, responsible for elite performance and competitive swimming to international level.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Its aim is to support British athletes to win gold medals at the major championships: the World Championships; the Commonwealth Games; and, this year in Rio, the Olympics and Paralympics.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At the end of March 2016 we launched the new British Swimming website on Wagtail. Sporting a modern responsive design, the new website showcases the depth and breadth of British talent across the different disciplines with athlete profiles like those of triple world champion, Adam Peaty,\u00a0and quadruple world para-swimming champion, Tully Kearney.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "New British Swimming homepage", "image": 1326, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Many of these world-class athletes are competing in the British Swimming Championships 2016 which started today at the Tollcross International Swimming Centre in Glasgow where \u2013 in addition to national titles \u2013 qualification for the Olympic, Paralympic, European and European Junior teams is at stake.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019re proud to play a role in supporting our elite athletes and the important work of British Swimming and, like many other fans of the sport, we\u2019ll be following all the action from the Championships this week on the live stream.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about the new British Swimming website, or want to discuss your upcoming project, please get in touch. We'd love to hear from you.\u00a0

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Yesterday, we released our latest piece of research titled\u00a0Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u00a0at the\u00a0eCampaigning Forum\u00a0(ECF) in Oxford, which saw more than 150 non-profit digital campaigners and marketers attend.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our 28-page guide provides insights into the current state of charities\u2019 Google Ad Grants efforts and highlights success stories from Gingerbread, Samaritans and Terrence Higgins Trust, who are making the most of their Google Ad Grants.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

According to our survey\u2019s results, only 53% of the 115 charities surveyed saw Ad Grants as an important part of their digital marketing efforts.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Furthermore, 27% of charities stated that they don\u2019t pay much attention to the results Google Ad Grants deliver and, even more surprisingly, 21% confessed to not having a Google Ad Grant.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When we asked charities why they weren\u2019t making the most of having a Google Ad Grant, responses included: lack of time (34%), lack of expertise (30%), lack of resource (27%) and other (9%).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our survey\u00a0did however\u00a0reveal that a sizeable percentage of charities are taking advantage of Google Ad Grants. 56% of the charities stated that they have an Ad Grants strategy in place, 62% declared that they get more traffic from their Ad Grants than their email campaigns, and 46% shared that Ad Grants was one of their top three sources of web traffic.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

With eligible charities receiving up to $40,000 per month to spend on AdWords, Google Ad Grants is an invaluable resource which charities should be making the most of.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Get your free copy of\u00a0Unleashing Your Google Ad Grant\u00a0here.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Alternatively, if you would like to find out more information, please\u00a0contact us\u00a0and one of our experts will answer any questions you may have.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

For the last few\u00a0months\u00a0we\u2019ve been working on an exciting visual design project for the\u00a0Museum of London\u00a0\u2013 the only museum dedicated to London and its rich history.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s an important time for the Museum, with a major relocation\u00a0planned in the next couple of years\u00a0from the current site at the Barbican to Smithfield. In parallel with the move, they\u2019ve undertaken a major digital initiative to reimagine their website as a destination in its own right,\u00a0as well as highlighting their fantastic permanent collections and driving more visits to both physical locations.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Torchbox led an extensive creative and visual design process for the new website, building on a body of UX research carried out by Webcredible in 2015. Our brief was to reinterpret the Museum of London brand for the contemporary digital space: embracing its inclusivity and appeal to families, while better representing its sophistication, irreverence, and relevance to the city's cultural dialogue. For maximum visual impact, we made the Museum's fabulous collections the centrepiece of our design.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "New Museum of London homepage", "image": 1235, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our design was implemented in the Museum's CMS by their internal development team, and the new website was launched in mid-April. We\u2019re proud to have played a major part in shaping the end result:\u00a0a vibrant, fully responsive website that showcases the breadth of the galleries, exhibits and events on offer. We worked hard to strike the right balance between elegance and fun, making the website engaging and easy to explore for users of any age or background. We also put together a library of design components to provide a visual framework for the website to grow and scale with the Museum\u2019s ambitions.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Fortunately \u2013 or unfortunately?! \u2013 our on-site user testing coincided with their\u00a0Crime Museum Uncovered exhibition, so were able to \u2018relax' between testing sessions by admiring a chilling selection of hangman\u2019s ropes, murder weapons and, of course,\u00a0Dr Crippen\u2019s spade.

We\u2019re looking forward to checking out the\u00a0forthcoming Great Fire of London exhibition in July!

"}]

fields.intro: We are delighted to announce that Torchbox has been awarded a place on the new pan-Government framework, Digital Outcomes and Specialists.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We are delighted to announce that Torchbox has been awarded a place by the Crown Commercial Service (CCS) on the new pan-Government framework, Digital Outcomes and Specialists, which has opened for business on the Digital Marketplace this week.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Torchbox is listed as a \u2018Digital Outcomes\u2019 supplier, offering a range of services and capabilities \u2013 including user research, ux, design, software development, content management systems, testing, project management and more \u2013 to deliver digital projects in accordance with the Government\u2019s Service Design Manual and Technology Code of Practice.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Now that the framework is live, we're looking forward to seeing some interesting opportunities to get involved with transforming public sector digital services.

"}]

fields.intro: To give our readers an idea of what life at Torchbox is like, we've started a new blog series which focuses on what our talented employees get up to inside and outside of work.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Based in our Bristol office,\u00a0Ben Enright\u00a0is Torchbox's\u00a0longest-serving Lead Designer, responsible for some of our standout creative work.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Originally\u00a0from Hook Norton in Oxfordshire, Ben used to play for Great Britain's Under-16 Ice Hockey team.\u00a0Nowadays, Ben has acquired a fine-tuned taste for brewing beer and has almost perfected his thrice-hopped pale ale.\u00a0Of all the facts Ben\u00a0shared with us, our favourite has to be that the ring bearer at his wedding was an alpaca (you're welcome).

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Ben Enright", "image": 888, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "When did you start working at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

September 2004 (but I've had a few breaks for travelling since then).

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How did you get your job at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I saw a job\u00a0advertised\u00a0on Oxford's legendary \u2018Daily Info\u2019 and applied. I was living in Oxford at the time, which is pretty close to Torchbox's Charlbury office.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How did you find the interview process?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Friendly and informal. I was asked to critique the old Breakthrough Breast Cancer website. Following the interview, I think I was challenged to a game of table football by one of\u00a0the\u00a0owners,\u00a0Olly. I don't remember winning, but\u00a0happy to say that I still got the job.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you enjoy most about working at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There\u2019s a great variety of friendly characters in the office, which makes\u00a0everyday\u00a0entertaining. A good proportion\u00a0enjoy\u00a0a beer or two after work as well, which is nice.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What kind of skills do you need to be effective in your role?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Creative thinking,\u00a0wireframing,\u00a0design prototyping,\u00a0front-end coding,\u00a0managing junior designers,\u00a0running design workshops with clients, and pitching.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Which clients have you worked with?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Over the years I've worked on a large number of client projects. I'm always up for a new challenge, so it\u2019s great to have fresh and varied projects continuously coming in. Recent clients include the\u00a0Royal Agricultural University,\u00a0Global\u00a0Witness\u00a0and\u00a0The Roman Baths.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What have you achieved at Torchbox that you are most proud of?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Being the first Bristol team member and watching the Torchbox Bristol set-up grow and evolve.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What\u2019s the coolest thing you\u2019ve done in your job recently?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Designing the new\u00a0Museum of London\u00a0website.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "New Museum of London homepage", "image": 1235, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you get up to during your lunch breaks?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As the Bristol office is based right in the city centre, we\u2019re spoilt for choice when it comes to lunch options... I generally like perusing the street food stalls at St Nicholas' market.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you get up to after work?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I pootle home with my Jack\u00a0Russell, Jack, who comes to work with me\u00a0everyday. Once home, I can usually be found\u00a0rustling up a meal in the kitchen \u2013 I love cooking. On Wednesday nights I\u00a0play five-a-side\u00a0football.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Ben & Jack", "image": 893, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What advice would you give to someone looking to join the Torchbox team?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you're applying to join our design team:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Show passion and enthusiasm for digital design
  • Have great examples of your own work
  • Be prepared to prove you have the skills you say you have (so be honest)
  • Ask lots of questions

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more information, check out our recent blog post,\u00a0How to get your first design job.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Want to join the team?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're always on the lookout for talented digital designers to join our team. If you want to work for a digital agency with a difference, then take a look at our\u00a0current job openings\u00a0or email your CV and a covering letter to\u00a0hello@torchbox.com.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Torchbox Ski Trip", "image": 1024, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}]

fields.intro: A little birdy has told the world that within the next 'couple of weeks' Twitter will at long last exclude multimedia (photos, links and videos) from its infamous 140 character count. This 'little birdy' just happens to be Bloomberg.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

A little birdy has told the world that within the next 'couple of weeks' Twitter will at\u00a0long last\u00a0exclude multimedia (photos, links and videos) from its infamous 140 character count. This 'little birdy' just happens to be\u00a0Bloomberg.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Find Your Limit"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Twitter\u2019s 140 character limit is a feature which the world has adopted and grown to love. It has been present since Twitter launched in 2006 and was introduced to allow tweets to fit into text messages (Nokia 3310 anyone?).\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Twitter founder, Jack Dorsey, has previously described the 140 character limit as a \"beautiful constraint\" that \"inspires creativity and brevity\".\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

So news of the extended character limit has come as a surprise to some. Or has it?\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Earlier this year, Twitter were said to be upping the character limit to 10,000 characters. This caused a lot of ripples within the Twitter community, with many turning to Twitter to air their concerns.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Tweet from @staychad", "image": 1329, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Tweet from @GMPaiella", "image": 1330, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Even though this feature never came into play, the latest announcement has been warmly welcomed by Twitter users, implying that Twitter has got the right approach this time around.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Tweet from @mrjakehumphrey", "image": 1331, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Considering URLs eat up to 23 Twitter characters, I personally welcome this new feature with open arms. At the end of the day, it\u2019s 23 more characters to inspire creativity and brevity.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "More to Come"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Twitter are likely to be announcing a series of tweaks over the coming weeks as the company seeks to boost its community engagement amidst their widely reported struggle to attract new users.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

What these changes could be is anyone's guess. An \u2018Edit\u2019 button perhaps? I wouldn't hold your breath.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Since joining Torchbox in 2012, Justine Pocock has led some of our most exciting front-end development projects.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Based in our Charlbury office, Justine plays a big part in the Drupal community and is responsible for organising Drupal\u2019s Frontend United conference, as well as Torchbox\u2019s very own Oxford Geek Nights. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Justine Pocock", "image": 975, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To give potential candidates an idea of what Torchbox life is like, I sat down with Justine to find out what she gets up to inside and outside of work.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Tell us five random facts about yourself:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • I\u2019m an Elite Status Younique Presenter, selling makeup and empowering women as I do so.
  • I ran a marathon and jumped out of a plane because I was told I couldn\u2019t do it\u2026
  • I was meant to be the second member of the Bristol team, but I haven\u2019t got around to moving yet.
  • I want to have my own smallholding so that I can grow everything I eat.
  • I\u2019ve organised three Frontend United conferences.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How did you get your job at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I met one of Torchbox\u2019s Drupal Developers at a London meetup. I wasn\u2019t looking for a job at the time, but I was really impressed\u00a0from\u00a0what I heard. The rest is history!

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How did you find the interview process?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Relaxed. It was just a long chat with different team members. I thought I had waffled on too much about my out-of-work interests, but I arrived home to an offer to start as soon as possible.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Why did you choose to work for Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

After my\u00a0interview,\u00a0it was pretty clear that I\u2019d be joining a family.\u00a0I liked that Torchbox had an ethical approach. The thought of coming home after work with a done-good feeling was appealing.\u00a0\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you enjoy most about working at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The people! We\u2019re an eclectic bunch who have come from the far corners of the world. It\u2019s been interesting to learn about different cultures and delicacies (Chinese gyoza anyone?).

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Torchbox Skip Trip 2016", "image": 979, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Which clients have you worked with?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Chatham House,\u00a0Recycle Now\u00a0and\u00a0CLIC Sargent\u00a0to name a few.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What kind of skills do you need to be effective in your role?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

An eye for detail, front-end development, UX and design principles, an understanding of Drupal\u2019s theme layer and the ability to host client demos.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What have you achieved at Torchbox that you are most proud of?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The project we undertook for Chatham House was really challenging. We had to achieve a lot within a short space to time. I'm really proud of how we all pulled together as a team to deliver\u00a0a really good site.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What\u2019s the coolest thing you\u2019ve done in your job recently?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s a toss up between implementing what I\u2019ve learnt at Drupalcon Barcelona and getting\u00a0Dr.\u00a0Sue Black to present at Oxford Geek Nights.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Justine at Oxford Geek Nights", "image": 976, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you get up to during your lunch breaks?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019m based in Torchbox\u2019s Charlbury office, which is located in the gorgeous surroundings of Cornbury Estate. During my lunch\u00a0breaks\u00a0I go for a wander around the grounds, grab an ice cream from the local village or get involved in one of the company\u2019s\u00a0lunch time\u00a0barbeques.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you get up to after work?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019m currently trying to get my garden blooming again. When the sun's not shining, I can be found in the kitchen making chutneys and cheeses, trying a new kind of hedgerow wine and checking if the cider I made in the Autumn is ready yet.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What advice would you give to someone looking to join the Torchbox team?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Be yourself.
  • Be prepared to jump in on lots of fast paced projects.
  • Be excited about front-end development and where it\u2019s going next, especially Drupal 8 front-end theming.
  • Have examples of work you\u2019ve done and are proud of.
  • Be part of the Drupal community, go to user groups, contribute to modules, hang out at IRC.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Want to join the team?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're always on the lookout for talented developers to join our team. If you want to work for a digital agency with a difference, then take a look at our\u00a0current job openings\u00a0or email your CV and a covering letter to\u00a0hello@torchbox.com.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

There are few rights and lots of wrongs when it comes to developing effective website navigation labels. Here are a few guidelines to help get you on the right path:

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "1. Focus on Top User Tasks"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Your website's navigation should focus on the most important tasks that users undertake.\u00a0As Gerry McGovern, creator of Top Tasks Management says, \"top tasks are the small set of tasks (usually less that ten, often less than five) that matter most to your customers.\" The\u00a0University of\u00a0Oxford\u00a0for example, features its most visited pages within its top navigation level. If you\u2019re not 100% sure what your key user tasks are, delve into your website\u2019s analytics and conduct user research to find out more.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "University of Oxford homepage banner", "image": 996, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "2. Simplicity"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Navigation labels should be reduced to their shortest, clearest form and drop down menus simplified to the least number of options possible. For example,\u00a0Plan International\u00a0only has four top-level navigation labels to ensure users can easily access the information they\u2019re looking for. We recommend having no more than five navigation labels (if possible), as it generally makes for easy scanning and clear information scent.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Plan International homepage banner", "image": 1004, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "3. Consistent Labelling Style"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Try to keep navigation labels of a similar length and grammatical nature, e.g.: 'News & Blog, Research & Insights, What\u2019s On & Events\u2019 rather than 'News, What's On & Events, Research, Insights, Blog\u2019. Try to avoid extraneous terms like 'our' too (i.e.: Our Team), or before you know it - they'll be everywhere.\u00a0Carers Trust\u2019s new website follows this approach. Its three main navigation labels are all of a similar length and word count.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Carers Trust homepage banner", "image": 998, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "4. Clear Labels With No Ambiguity"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Labels like 'information' and 'resources' are ambiguous. Ensure your website\u2019s labels provide as much information as possible. They don't need to map to key user tasks faithfully, but they do need to give visitors a good idea of the content they're about to click through to.\u00a0British Swimming\u00a0has got this approach right.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "British Swimming homepage", "image": 999, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "5. Order Matters"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

According to the Primacy vs Recency Effect, items at the beginning of a list are considered by users to be the most important. Keep this in mind when structuring your top navigation level. Put the tasks which are most important to users first. By doing this, you\u2019ll ensure that users are able to access the information they want quickly, and easily, reducing your site\u2019s overall bounce rate. For example,\u00a0Shakespeare Birthplace Trust\u00a0has listed \u2018Visit\u2019 first, as it understands that visitors are most interested in finding out about its attractions.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Shakespeare Birthplace Trust homepage", "image": 1000, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "6. Give a Sense of Your Organisation"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Last and by no means least, ensure that your navigation labels give a sense of what your organisation is about. It\u2019s easy to use generic labels such as \u2018What We Do\u2019 and \u2018Who We Are\u2019, but these give visitors\u00a0little\u00a0insight into what your organisation actually does. Instead, focus on providing users with as much information as possible. The\u00a0Royal Agricultural University\u2019s website has achieved this. Its top navigation labels effectively communicate what the University is all about: study, culture and research.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal Agricultural University homepage banner", "image": 1001, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Keen to learn more?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you've got any questions about your website\u2019s navigation labels or if you\u2019d like to find out more, please get in touch\u00a0and one of our experts will\u00a0get back to you.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Tom Saunders is Torchbox's User\u00a0Experience\u00a0Architect, championing UX across the agency.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Hailing from the South West countryside, Tom has spent the past 12 years working in design, development and communications for charities and non-profit organisations. When not helping the good guys, Tom can be found heading for the hills in search of a new cycling route.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Tom Saunders", "image": 557, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To give potential candidates an idea of what life at Torchbox is like, I sat down with Tom to find out what he gets up to inside and outside of work.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Tell us a few random facts about yourself:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • My favourite film is Ghostbusters.
  • I designed my first website (for a local band) at the age of 14 using Macromedia Flash...
  • I used to have an Apple Macintosh Performa (way before Apple was cool).
  • As a teenager, I got fired from a job working in a kitchen because my trousers were too baggy.
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Why did you choose to work for Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Torchbox's 'working for the good guys' ethos was a major draw for me. I\u2019ve always worked for charities and nonprofits. Working for Torchbox, I get the best of both worlds. I can gain experience in a fast-paced and diverse agency environment, whilst still doing work that feels like it\u2019s contributing to something positive.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Torchbox Bristol", "image": 1018, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you enjoy most about working at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

My favourite part of the job is talking with the people who use the sites, services and products we work on. It\u2019s always great to hear from users that a particular idea or improvement is going to make a positive impact on someone\u2019s life.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I also love that I get to learn about so much. I can tell you about local authority provision for youth homelessness, the experiences of people living with various different medical, health and social needs, the history of the Roman Baths and what an Olympic swimming coach gets up to on an average day. As a self-described lifelong learner, having the opportunity to learn about so many different topics is massively rewarding.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What\u2019s the coolest thing you\u2019ve done in your job recently?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I went to Philadelphia to work with a client, which was a great experience. It\u2019s a fantastic city. Equally, I\u2019ve spent the last couple of months working on a project for a charity which I\u2019ve always respected and supported.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Tom working in Philidelphia", "image": 1021, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What kind of skills do you need to be effective in your role?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

User Experience (UX) practitioners tend to have really diverse skillsets, which range from data analysis through to front-end development.\u00a0Overall\u00a0though, I\u2019d say that UX practitioners share common soft skills and character traits. These include being open-minded, empathetic, clear and thoughtful. If you\u2019re the type that enjoys understanding the mechanics of how things work and how they can be improved for the end user, then UX may be the career path for you.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you get up to during your lunch breaks?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Taking time out at lunch is really important for me. A large part of what I do is\u00a0problem solving. Walking away from whatever I\u2019m working on and coming back to it from a different angle, is immensely valuable. It gives me a chance to sanity check my own work before putting it in front of users.\u00a0When the sun's out, I try to go for a run or a cycle,\u00a0otherwise\u00a0I head over to my favourite coffee shop (Full Court Press) and grab some food from St Nick\u2019s Market.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "St Nick's Market in Bristol", "image": 1019, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you get up to after work?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019ve always been into cycling, in one form or another. In Bristol, we\u2019re lucky to have lots of fantastic roads and mountain bike trails right on our doorstep. After work, I try and take advantage of these, some are only a 10-minute ride away from the office.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What advice would you give to someone looking to join the Torchbox team?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I think everyone here brings something pretty special to the agency, both in terms of skillset and personality. I like seeing people who are keen to get stuck in and do some great work. Be active, engaged and passionate.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Want to join the team?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're always on the lookout for talented UX\u00a0pracitioners\u00a0to join our team. If you want to work for a digital agency with a difference, then take a look at our\u00a0current job openings\u00a0or email your CV and a covering letter to\u00a0hello@torchbox.com.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Torchbox Ski Trip", "image": 1141, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Further Reading"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Read more blogs from our Life at Torchbox series:\u00a0

  • Life as a Drupal Developer - Justine Pocock
  • Life as a Lead Designer - Ben Enright\u00a0
"}]

fields.intro: When asked “can Drupal be used to build this?”, the answer is almost always “yes”!
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

There are many\u00a0Content Management Systems\u00a0(CMS) available nowadays. Along my journey as a developer, I\u2019ve tested my fair share. I'm now fortunate to work for an agency which uses\u00a0Drupal\u00a0as one of its main tools of choice. To give readers an idea of why Drupal is such a popular CMS, I've outlined five reasons below.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "1. It\u2019s an Open Source Platform"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are thousands of people ensuring that bugs are found and fixed quickly, which means you'll always be running an up-to-date, secure platform. While Drupal 7 had approximately 1,000 people contributing their time to update the core code, the new version, Drupal 8, has 3.5 times as many (and counting)!

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Core sprints at DrupalCon", "image": 1056, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "2. Ease of Use"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Content management systems allow you, the end user, to control the content on your site with the minimum of effort. Whether you're a small site with occasional updates or a large, international charity with multiple levels of access and editorial rights, you're likely to find a good fit with Drupal.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal 8 brings with it a built-in\u00a0WYSIWYG\u00a0(What You See Is What You Get) editor. The optimised editor is\u00a0easy-to-use,\u00a0and allows for a smoother workflow.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "WYSIWYG editor", "image": 1061, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "3. Trusted Platform"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal is used to power some of the world\u2019s largest sites, including the\u00a0White House,\u00a0MTV,\u00a0The Economist\u00a0,\u00a0Royal Mail,\u00a0Men's Health,\u00a0Greenpeace,\u00a0Harvard\u00a0and the\u00a0University of Oxford.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Not only do these organisations use Drupal as an editorial and delivery tool, they actively work towards making Drupal a better product by contributing new modules and features to the community.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Companies using Drupal", "image": 1059, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "4. Scalable, flexible, powerful"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When asked \u201ccan Drupal be used to build this?\u201d, the answer is almost always \u201cyes\u201d!

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal is a developer\u2019s tool. While there is an awful lot that can be done using just a basic installation, the real power of Drupal only comes to the fore when in the hands of a developer. Multi-domain, multi-lingual sites are commonplace, alongside all manner of applications from\u00a0ecommerce\u00a0to education and everything in between.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "5. The Community"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There\u2019s an old saying, \u201ccome for the code, stay for the community\u201d. The code is certainly improving with the release of each new version of Drupal (Drupal 8 is now built on a solid\u00a0Symfony\u00a0foundation),\u00a0however\u00a0the community is the main draw for a lot of people.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal has always been tarred with a steep learning curve, due to it being more of a developer\u2019s tool than a home user\u2019s website-in-a-box. Thankfully there are a large group of people that are happy and willing to give up their time to help others along. This happens in both online forums as well as at events.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Drupal Learning Curve", "image": 1063, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019ve not only learnt a lot through the Drupal community, but I've also made some good friends along the way. I\u2019m now also helping to organise\u00a0DrupalCamp Bristol!

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Drupalcon Barcelona: Can you see me and Justine at the back?", "image": 1058, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Conclusion"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s fairly easy to see how powerful Drupal can be.\u00a0I\u2019m fortunate to work alongside some very talented developers who are happy to share their knowledge and\u00a0expertise,\u00a0while building websites for organisations that are helping to make the world a better place.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you have any questions about Drupal, please feel free to\u00a0drop me a line. I'd be more than happy to answer any questions you may have.\u00a0

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Drupal\u2019s Security Team have announced that at 17:00 BST today, they will be releasing security updates to several contributed modules for Drupal. Full details can be seen in the\u00a0security announcement.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These updates have been marked as\u00a0Highly Critical, so should be taken very seriously, with an expected\u00a0risk score\u00a0of up to 22/25.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

While this doesn\u2019t happen all that often with Drupal sites, it is worth making sure you\u2019re clear about the potential risks and the action that you need to take. Attending to this for our clients is a top priority for Torchbox today (if we manage your Drupal website, then please see below for information about the action we\u2019re taking).

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What this means for you"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Depending on which modules are installed, there is a chance that your site may be at risk from remote code execution (the ability for an attacker to trigger arbitrary code execution on a vulnerable, remote Drupal installation). The affected modules are used on somewhere between 1,000 and 10,000 sites.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If the at-risk modules are not updated immediately after the upcoming security announcement, there is a chance that your site, and possibly the entire server that your site is hosted on, could be compromised, possibly resulting in your data being accessed, a loss of data, or downtime.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What you should be doing about it:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Ensure you have an up-to-date backup of your site - both codebase and database.
  • Watch for the upcoming announcement to know which modules need updating to which version - Drupal core is not affected. This announcement will be made at 17:00 BST today (13th July). It will be worth keeping an eye on the\u00a0contributed module security advisories list.
  • Patch/update your modules after the announcement as soon as possible.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If your site stores sensitive data, it may be best to patch your site in isolation so that it isn\u2019t exposed to this risk at all - i.e. update an offline copy of your site and overwrite your live site with it.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "If you\u2019re a Torchbox client then be assured that we\u2019re:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Auditing all sites that may be vulnerable to this security risk.
  • Gathering as much information as possible about what these threats are likely to be, ahead of the official release.
  • Ensuring we have developers available to cover updates as soon as possible after the announcement.
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s well worth subscribing to the Drupal Security Team\u2019s email announcements as they\u2019re an invaluable way of keeping up to date with any potential threats. This can be found from your drupal.org profile page by visiting Edit > My newsletters.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Drupal 6"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s unknown whether these updates will affect Drupal 6, so it will be worth keeping an eye on\u00a0https://www.drupal.org/project/d6lts\u00a0as they\u2019re likely to release information regarding this.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Two days on from Wednesday\u2019s security announcement, there has been some debate in the community that perhaps the Drupal Security Team overstated this security release.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

While the number of vulnerabilities ultimately turned out to\u00a0be low, we believe that the manner in which this was handled by the team was correct. A remote code execution exploit can be every bit as severe as\u00a0a SQL\u00a0Injection exploit.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Please note, your site is at risk and may have been compromised already if you haven\u2019t taken steps to update or remove the affected modules.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Bearing in mind that\u00a0Open Atrium, a very popular Drupal distribution, includes\u00a0Coder\u00a0(one of the affected modules) in its suite of modules, there\u2019s no doubt that this was a very far-reaching issue.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're pleased to report that Torchbox were well prepared for the security updates that were released (and our blog post seems to have helped many others).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Following our own advice, our preparation included:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • ensuring all potentially affected sites were audited to help us quickly cover any eventuality from the security release
  • developers were assigned sites to ensure an even workload and a timely response
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019re proud to say that all of our affected sites were patched and deployed by 16:30 UTC, just half an hour after the security release,\u00a0many\u00a0much quicker than this.

"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're very pleased to be sponsoring\u00a0DjangoCon US, not least because this year it's happening in Philadelphia, our recently adopted US hometown; more specifically on the campus of our lovely clients the\u00a0Wharton School.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "DjangoCon US 2016", "image": 1305, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There's a wonderfully diverse line-up, including a session on\u00a0Atomic Wagtail\u00a0by Kurt Wall. Tom, Olly and Alex are all coming to the conference - if you'd like to speak to us about Wagtail, Django, the Tour de France or anything else, then look out for our name badges or book a session with us on\u00a0Calendly.djano.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Now in its fifth year, the\u00a0Wirehive 100\u00a0awards\u00a0showcases\u00a0the best of digital; recognising outstanding work and exceptional individuals from agencies across the region.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Following the nominations which were released earlier today via\u00a0Wirehive 100\u2019s Twitter channel, we are delighted to announce that Torchbox has been shortlisted for two awards: Best Content Creation (Africa Progress Panel) and Consumer Site of the Year (Royal Agricultural University).\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Wirehive 100 Awards Ceremony", "image": 1110, "attribution": "The Drum", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019re thrilled with our nominations and would like to extend our congratulations to all Wirehive 100 nominees.\u00a0To find out more about our shortlisted work, please take a look below or alternatively visit the\u00a0Wirehive 100 website\u00a0to view the full shortlist.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Africa Progress Panel"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shortlisted for: Best Content Creation\u00a0

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/giRe0EMROVk"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To promote Africa Progress Panel\u2019s report on global warming and its effects on Africa, we launched a social video campaign to raise awareness and drive report downloads. Our campaign not only achieved its objectives, it completely smashed them.\u00a0Since launch the campaign has amassed more than 242,000 video views, driving 17,951 report downloads.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

View the Africa Progress Panel case study

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Royal Agricultural University"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shortlisted for: Consumer Site of the Year\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal Agricultural University Website", "image": 1109, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

\"The Royal Agricultural University required a brand new website, to effectively compete in the global Higher Education market. We wanted a responsive, easy to navigate, beautifully designed website, with the opportunity to showcase enhanced content relating to our unique specialist university. Torchbox created such a site through their \u2018user first\u2019 approach, which involved an impressive amount of scoping with our stakeholders in order to understand our core audience. Armed with this research, they have created a website which engages our users and provides them with the best possible experience.\"\u00a0- Jessica Taylor, Head of Marketing and Student Recruitment at Royal Agricultural University

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

View the Royal Agricultural University case study

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about our award-nominated campaigns, or how we can help you to achieve success - please get in touch and one of our team will get back to you.\u00a0

"}]

fields.intro: Over the past year, we have been working on a new internal REST API to power Wagtail's admin interface. Now that the initial version has landed on master, here's a summary of what this new API will bring to Wagtail.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Over the past year, we have been working on a new internal REST API to power Wagtail's admin interface. Now that the initial version has landed on\u00a0master, here's a summary of what this new API will bring to Wagtail.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Admin API makes it possible for Wagtail's client-side code to fetch content in the background and display it without having to reload the page. This brings more possibilities for improving the UI, as well as improving the developer experience for Wagtail's contributors.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Faster UI"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Replacing janky page loads with fluid, animated transitions is a recent trend in web development and we hope to introduce some into Wagtail over the next year. This will be made possible by loading content in the background with the API, before rendering it in the browser without reloading the page.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The first UI feature you can expect to see rebuilt on the Admin API is a new explorer widget - see the video below. We hope to convert more actions (such as page locking) and interfaces (revisions,\u00a0choosers) to the Admin API soon.

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/0kl9G1pqpAs"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Cleaner code"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We aim to make the Wagtail codebase as approachable to new contributors as possible. There are a few parts of the codebase where we can do better.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

One example is\u00a0chooser\u00a0models. Here, the front-end, written in JavaScript, sends AJAX requests to the back-end, written in Python, which renders\u00a0a HTML\u00a0and JavaScript fragment. The HTML is processed and displayed in the\u00a0modal\u00a0and the JavaScript is executed using eval(), which performs actions in the browser such as closing the modal or executing a callback function.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Ideally, these\u00a0chooser\u00a0modals\u00a0would be implemented entirely in JavaScript and use the front-end tooling that we set up at the\u00a0Cape Town sprint. The data should be fetched from the API so it wouldn't need any custom backend code.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Another benefit to using the Admin API in this way is that individual components do not need to be concerned about business rules (custom permission model, multi-tenancy) as these would be implemented in the API.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Why a new API?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Wagtail already has an API (introduced in Wagtail 1.0) that can be optionally enabled, but which is focused on serving content to public browsers; only live, public content is available.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Admin API gives access to all content that the logged-in user has permission to see. It also gives access to additional metadata, such as page status and updated times.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How is it implemented?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It is based on Wagtail's existing public API and built using the\u00a0Django REST Framework.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Demo"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Try out the API yourself at the following links: \u00a0pages\u00a0/\u00a0images\u00a0/\u00a0documents\u00a0(username/password are both \"admin\").

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Yesterday, I attended\u00a0DrupalCamp Bristol\u2019s\u00a0sprint day which took place at Torchbox\u2019s new Bristol office. More than 15 people attended the event, including\u00a0seasoned contributors\u00a0Lewis Nyman\u00a0and\u00a0Emma Karayiannis.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Several novices attended the event too, eager to find out how they could become Drupal contributors.\u00a0It's always great to see people getting involved in the Drupal community. If you too are considering helping\u00a0out,\u00a0but are not sure where to begin, I've outlined a few steps below to get you started.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "DrupalCamp Bristol Sprint attendees", "image": 1115, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Contributing to Drupal"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Drupal has a fantastic community of contributors. People help with everything, from coding tasks to checking\u00a0documentation\u00a0and triaging issue queues on\u00a0drupal.org.\u00a0With a community as large and diverse as Drupal's, it should come as little surprise that contributors range from\u00a0full-time, sponsored maintainers to casual hobbyists who choose to dedicate a few hours a week to improving something they use and care about.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Getting started"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For people looking to get started with contributing, it can be a bit difficult to work out where to begin. A good place to start is\u00a0drupal.org's own overview\u00a0on\u00a0contributions. This page links through to a really helpful\u00a0contributor task page\u00a0which explains the many ways that the technical, and non-technical, can get started.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A common misconception is that you need to be an experienced software developer to make improvements to Drupal. Whilst there is often no shortage of technically demanding issues, there are a large number of simpler, smaller tasks which are just as important.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A very quick way of accessing this information is to (ironically, perhaps?) use the\u00a0advanced search\u00a0on the core Drupal issue queue. All of the tasks listed here have been tagged with \u2018novice\u2019 and should provide easy pickings for most people. For example, to find Drupal core's issue queue you would go to\u00a0https://drupal.org/project/drupal,\u00a0then find the 'all issues'\u00a0link in the sidebar and follow the 'advanced search'\u00a0link near the page title.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Issues for Drupal Core page", "image": 1113, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In my opinion, the best way to get started with contributing to Drupal is to attend a sprint day or local developer\u00a0event,\u00a0and find a friendly mentor who can offer you some support to avoid the dreaded feeling of getting stuck, bored and disheartened.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you're a developer with a reasonable understanding of PHP frameworks, have a go at writing and submitting a patch. There are usually front end tasks and ticket triaging; almost anyone can check whether steps to reproduce a bug still work. Even if your first ever contribution is to read an issue's summary and leave a comment saying \u201cit's actually far more complex than first estimated\u201d - this is a very useful first step. Every little contribution makes a difference.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Contributions by Torchbox"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our team's contributions are summarised on\u00a0our drupal.org organisation page. A lot of our developers' efforts go towards writing patches for existing/ new bugs on contributed modules. We also think it's really important that the projects we're most proud of are written up as drupal.org case studies. Not only does this promote our best work, but it also raises the profile of Drupal as a product that can deliver success for a huge variety of organisations and individuals across the globe. Many of our developers are also active in the\u00a0#drupal-uk IRC channel: a public chat room inhabited by friendly Drupal community members in the UK.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

For the past two weeks, we\u2019ve been lucky to have Darren Tweed join us for a work experience placement.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Darren recently graduated from Ulster University and has since worked for a multi-national company in the security sector, as part of his industry placement year. Eager to gain experience in a different sector, Darren joined our development team to improve upon the computing skills he learnt at university.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Darren Tweed", "image": 1118, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To give potential interns an idea of what life at Torchbox is like, I sat down with Darren to find out what he got up to.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Tell us five random facts about yourself:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • I'm a bit of a coffee\u00a0fan,\u00a0and am particularly partial to a nice Los Jocotales from Guatemala.
  • I live in Northern Ireland.
  • I've seen Africa\u2019s Big Five on safari.
  • I received a Gold Duke of Edinburgh Award from Prince Edward.
  • I love travelling - I\u2019ve been to places like Japan,\u00a0Sweden\u00a0and South Africa. This year it\u2019s Costa Rica!
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Which university did you go to and what degrees did you major with?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

BSc Computing with Honours and a Diploma in Professional Practice from Ulster University in Coleraine.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What\u2019s your dream job?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To become a web developer or project manager for a growing company. I wanted to be a zoologist for a long time, but that\u2019s off the cards now.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Why take a work experience placement with Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019ve always heard positive stories about Torchbox, so when the opportunity to take part in a work experience placement came along, I grabbed it with both hands. Having previously worked for a large, multi-national company building security products, this experience has allowed me to see a different side to web development in a smaller organisation.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Torchbox Ski Trip", "image": 1024, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What have you been up to at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I\u2019ve worked through several tutorials to learn new development skills and best practice procedures. I was taught the fundamentals of different programming languages at university, but the tutorials here have taught me so much more. I\u2019ve been able to apply what I\u2019ve learnt too, helping to make improvements to a global, high profile website like\u00a0Chatham House.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Chatham House homepage", "image": 1251, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How will this work experience help you achieve your career goals?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This experience has boosted my confidence and enhanced my people skills. It's taught me a lot about working in a fast-paced workplace and the importance of completing work in a timely and efficient manner. The practical work experience I\u2019ve gained at Torchbox is going to look great on my CV and will be really useful when applying for permanent work.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What\u2019s the most interesting thing you\u2019ve learned here?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The most interesting thing has to be the workflow of the company. It\u2019s\u00a0fast,\u00a0but strict. Nothing gets to the next stage without several approvals, so you always know what you are working on is a high quality.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What has been the highlight of your work experience placement?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The people! Meeting so many people from different backgrounds, with different personalities has been great. Personally, I\u2019m a talker, so all of the interaction I\u2019ve had in my two weeks here has been great! I didn\u2019t think I\u2019d get to deploy my own work on Chatham House - \u00a0so that was really cool! And I mean, the team lunch here is pretty good too!

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What advice would you give to other people taking part in work experience placements?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Just be yourself.
  • Talk to as many people as you can.
  • Be prepared to work, and if you\u2019re stuck, attempt to learn. Try everything offered to you and really make the most of your time with the agency.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Interested in taking a work experience placement at Torchbox?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We're always keen to hear from enthusiastic and talented graduates who are looking for work experience opportunities. If you're interested, please email your CV and a covering letter to\u00a0hello@torchbox.com.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/DOXCHAM_xVI"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Git\u00a0is the version control system of choice at Torchbox. It is powerful, fast, efficient and can be used on both small and very large projects.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A rule of thumb for any repository is to keep uploaded media, large files and sensitive information out. Saying this, accidents do happen. Due to an accidental commit, our website repository size recently increased by 8x to a staggering 700MB.\u00a0These are the steps we took to clean it up.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

When it happened, Nick helpfully suggested the following radical approach:

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Nick's radical suggestion", "image": 1157, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These are the actual steps we took to clean it up:

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Revert and rebase"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

First,\u00a0we tried the simplest approach: revert and rebase the branch.

"}, {"type": "raw_html", "value": ""}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This would have been an ideal solution, were it not for Git\u2019s guarantee of 'what goes in, will come out'. In simple terms, each commit id depends on all of the commits that came before it. To change a commit, you need to go through all of its history - from oldest to newest. Git rebase will rewrite the history, but to delete a file for good you'll need to remove all copies from the entire tree.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Git filter-branch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To apply filters, such as removing a file when rewriting the commit history, you must use\u00a0Git filter-branch. It's the default go-to method for repository cleanups.

"}, {"type": "raw_html", "value": ""}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Git filter-branch runs a filter that removes the unnecessary files. You can then manually remove all original references, expire all the records in the Git replay log and run the garbage collector to the tainted data.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

While it is a powerful tool, filter-branch\u00a0takes a\u00a0very\u00a0long time on repositories with many commits, as it steps through every commit in your repository. It can also be fiddly.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "BFG Repo cleaner"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Enter BFG.\u00a0The BFG\u00a0is an alternative to the Git filter-branch method. It is written in Scala and can be anywhere from 10 to 50 times faster (it's simpler to use too). You can remove files, directories, anything larger than a certain size and even run text replacement in files.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The typical workflow is:

"}, {"type": "raw_html", "value": ""}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This creates a mirror of the culprit repository, runs BFG to strip out anything larger than 100MB, expires old records and runs the Git garbage collector to strip the unwanted dirty data.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In our case, we ran:

"}, {"type": "raw_html", "value": ""}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

See the full log

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The above removed the media.old directory and files, but protected anything that was in the master branch which we knew to be clean.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As a result, the repository went from 696MB back down to 85MB. Not a bad result at all.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Post-cleanup"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Once the repository was clean again, we had to ensure everyone else\u2019s copy was fixed too.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To do this, we deleted the old repository and\u00a0cloned\u00a0it again.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It is important to keep in mind that if any team members have work in progress, it is best to\u00a0rebase\u00a0any branches they created off the old repository. A single push or a merge can pollute the history and undo the cleanup.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What can you do to prevent this from happening"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Avoid the catch-all commands git add . and git commit -a on\u00a0the command line. Instead, use git add the_filename.ext, git rm the_filename.ext to individually stage files.\u00a0If you are uncomfortable with the command line, use a visual tool such as Tower, GitHub Desktop or GitKraken and check exactly what will be committed.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Useful resources"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Finally, here is a list of useful articles and tools:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • The BFG\u00a0Repo Cleaner
  • The GitHub\u00a0guide\u00a0to remove sensitive data
  • A handy Python\u00a0script\u00a0to find the top largest files
  • A simple filter-branch\u00a0wrapper script
  • The\u00a0Pro Git\u00a0book by Scott Chacon and Ben Straub\u00a0
"}]

fields.intro: Good news! Twitter users are now able to verify their accounts. This not only applies to personal accounts, but to business accounts too.
fields.streamfield:
[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Good news! Twitter users are now able to verify their accounts. This not only applies to personal accounts, but to business accounts too.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "About Twitter Verification"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Twitter\u2019s verified blue tick has long been associated with celebrities and\u00a0world\u00a0famous brands. After seven years, the social media giant has made the\u00a0decision\u00a0to open up accreditation to Twitter users.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Verified Twitter Accounts", "image": 1127, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Originally introduced in 2009, Twitter verification provides users with a means to distinguish between real and fake accounts. \u00a0@NASAArmstrong,\u00a0@KimKardashian,\u00a0@Oprah,\u00a0@MilwaukeePolice\u00a0and\u00a0@TonyHawk\u00a0are a few of the accounts which first became verified.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Today, there are reportedly more than 310 million active Twitter users, 520% more than in 2009.\u00a0With the number of users on the rise, Twitter has made the decision to open up the verification process,\u00a0however\u00a0there are parameters within which users can apply.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What types of accounts can be verified?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

According to Twitter:\u00a0\u201cAn account may be verified if it is determined to be an account of public interest. Typically this includes accounts maintained by users in music, acting, fashion, government, politics, religion, journalism, media, sports, business, and other key interest areas.\u201d

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Why should I verify my Twitter account?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Twitter verification will let followers know that your account is the real deal. It\u2019s all about earning trust. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "How to get your Twitter account verified:"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "1. Prepare Your Account"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To complete the verification form, you\u2019ll first need to make sure that your Twitter account has been updated with the information listed below:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Verified phone number
  • Confirmed email address\u00a0
  • Biography\u00a0
  • Header photo
  • Website address\u00a0
  • Birthday (only applies to personal accounts, not business accounts)\u00a0
  • Tweets set as public in Tweet privacy settings
  • Profile and account recommendations\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "2. Gather Required Information"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Once all of the above account information has been submitted and confirmed, you then need to compile the information required to complete the form:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • URLs
    You\u2019ll need to supply two to five URLs which showcase your public influence. Including links to news articles and high\u00a0traffic\u00a0content is a good place to start. Don\u2019t worry about including your website's URL - Twitter is already able to access this information via your profile.
  • 500 Character Description
    You\u2019ll be asked to provide a 500 character description on why you or your company should receive Twitter verification. Companies should outline their mission as well as their success at achieving it, whilst individuals should focus on their public reach and the impact they\u2019ve had in a given community.\u00a0
"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "3. Complete form"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Once you\u2019ve gathered all of the required information, you can then fill out the accreditation form:\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Open Twitter and ensure that you are logged into the account that you want to verify. This is important, as when you start filling out the form, Twitter will pull in the information associated with the account you are logged into.
  • Next, visit the\u00a0Twitter verification form page\u00a0and click\u00a0continue.
"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Twitter's Request to Verify an Account page", "image": 1119, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • You\u2019ll then be asked to confirm the Twitter username you want to verify. If you are a company, brand or organisation, make sure to check the relevant tick box. \u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Confirm username", "image": 1120, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • You\u2019ll now be prompted to provide the information you gathered earlier (URLs and blurb). Once you\u2019re happy with all of the information provided, select\u00a0Next.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Provide up to five links to help Twitter identify your account", "image": 1124, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
