  • Your application for Twitter verification has now been made. The Twitter team will let you know via email whether your application has been successful or not. This usually takes around 48 hours.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What Next?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If your application is approved, Twitter\u2019s\u00a0@Verified\u00a0team will get in touch and provide you with instructions on how to verify your account. If your request is denied, fret not. You can re-submit your request after 30 days.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If successful, there are a few final steps you\u2019ll need to take to verify your account:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Learn how to Tweet Effectively
    Twitter will present you with several tweets, asking you which one is better. Don\u2019t worry about getting the answer wrong. The aim of this exercise is to teach users how to increase their following.\u00a0
  • Connect with other interesting Twitter Users\u00a0
    Twitter will provide you with an opportunity to follow other verified accounts.\u00a0
  • Protect your Account\u00a0
    You\u2019ll be required to enter a phone number which Twitter can use to contact you should any problems arise with your account. Once this has step has been completed, your account will be verified.\u00a0
"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Questions?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you would like to find out more information about Twitter verification, please\u00a0get in touch\u00a0and one of our social media experts will answer any questions you may have.\u00a0

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We are thrilled to announce that Torchbox has received a Dadi Awards nomination for the design of Museum of London\u2019s website.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Drum\u2019s Dadi Awards shortlist for 2016 was announced today, revealing the agencies,\u00a0clients\u00a0and projects which impressed the judging panel across a range of categories.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Dadi\u2019s\u00a0(The Drum awards for the digital industries) have been celebrating digital excellence for the past ten years. The awards are open internationally to agencies and brands who are producing great digital work, from websites and apps, through to consumer products, social\u00a0media\u00a0and search.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is the first year we\u2019ve entered the DADI Awards and we are thrilled with our nomination which follows hot on the heels of our\u00a0two Wirehive 100 nominations.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019d like to thank our team for all of their hard work - these achievements wouldn\u2019t be possible without you. If you\u2019d like to find out more about our nominated work, please take a look below or alternatively visit the\u00a0Dadi Awards website\u00a0for the full shortlist.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Museum of London"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shortlisted for: Best Website (Use of Visual Design)\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our brief was to reinterpret the\u00a0Museum of London\u2019s brand for the contemporary digital space: embracing its\u00a0inclusivity\u00a0and appeal to families, while better representing its sophistication, irreverence, and relevance to the city's cultural dialogue.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Museum of London website", "image": 1140, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Working from wireframes supplied by the Museum of London, we created a design which was implemented by the Museum's in-house development team, and the new website launched in mid-April 2016.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We worked hard to strike the right balance between elegance and fun, making the website engaging and easy to explore for users of any age or background.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

View the full Museum of London case study

"}, {"type": "pullquote", "value": {"quote": "\u201cWe wanted our new website to be clearer for users, to showcase our galleries, to create a new virtual space where we can publish our perspectives on London, to optimise e-commerce opportunities and to reflect our brand. We\u2019re delighted that the new site delivers each of these objectives in a way that has dramatically improved our online presence.\"", "attribution": "Nigel Ludlow, Director of Assets, Museum of London"}}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

On Tuesday 26 July Google rolled out a major change to\u00a0AdWords, announcing the release of\u00a0expanded text ads\u00a0to all advertisers, with immediate effect. This is the biggest change I\u2019ve seen in my time working with AdWords. Expanded text ads will eventually replace standard text ads, so if you have a\u00a0Google Ad Grant, or you\u2019re running paid search activity, what are the key changes you need to know about?

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Mencap PPC Ad", "image": 1304, "attribution": "", "alignment": "half"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Firstly, this change had been expected for some time: it was announced in May 2016 at the Google Performance Summit\u00a0along with a recommendation to start preparing for this upgrade ahead of time. We didn\u2019t know when these changes would come into action, and I certainly wasn\u2019t expecting this change to come out of beta for all advertisers quite so soon.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What are the main changes?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The way ads are written has fundamentally changed. The three key changes are as follows:\u00a0

  • Instead of one 25-character headline, ads can now have two 30-character headlines, both of which need to be used. Headline 1 will be separated from headline 2 by a hyphen.\u00a0
  • Instead of two 35-character description lines, ads now have one 80-character description line.
  • Display URLs have been entirely rethought. You now get two paths (subdirectories) of up to 15 characters each, with no control over how the domain is displayed.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As a result, expanded text ads\u00a0offer 50% more ad text\u00a0for you to promote your services, events or products, so this is definitely a good thing. We\u2019ve started writing ads in the new format, and first impressions are good\u2014much more space to play with, but this comes with its own set of challenges. It takes longer to write a well-crafted ad, and the shift in focus on to the headline changes the structure of how an ad should be written. If you\u2019ve picked up habits when writing ads, such as always finishing up with a strong call to action, or including key information in callout extensions rather than in ad copy, you\u2019ll need to rethink some of these approaches.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

AdWords Editor\u00a0has also been updated to accommodate expanded text ads. The update allows you to export your standard ads and reimport them as expanded text ads, which will save you some time upgrading your ads. However, you\u2019re still going to need to write a second headline and a new display URL for your new expanded ads,\u00a0otherwise\u00a0you won\u2019t be able to post your changes to the live account.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "What do you need to do?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The biggest thing advertisers should be aware of is that standard text ads will no longer be accepted as of 26 October 2016. You\u2019ll also no longer be able to edit your existing standard ads\u2014if you want to tweak ad copy, change a final URL, or change the date of an event you\u2019re promoting, you\u2019ll need to create a brand new expanded text ad instead. In other words, this is really happening and you really need to respond.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Whilst standard ads will continue to run after 26 October, Google will discontinue the standard ad format in time, at which point you\u2019ll be forced to make these changes. And it\u2019s not entirely unthinkable that Google will favour these new ad formats when calculating ad rank (in the same way they favour the use of ad extensions in paid search, https sites in organic search, or mobile-friendly sites in mobile search).

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019re going to start the process of upgrading all of our client accounts with immediate effect to stay well ahead of any enforced changes. We also want to make sure that our clients aren\u2019t left behind\u2014if you\u2019re last to make these changes, your standard ads may look less impactful in a sea of expanded text ads, which could cost you clicks.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Google\u00a0have reported\u00a0early signs that expanded text ads have significantly better clickthrough rates, so moving now to make your ads stand out more might put you out in front of the competition. Lastly, don\u2019t underestimate the time this upgrade may take: if you\u2019ve got a large account, you\u2019re no doubt running thousands of ads that will, in time, need to be rewritten. Don\u2019t forget to review your ad extensions too: if you\u2019re going to use the expanded character limits for ads to add in additional messaging, be sure you\u2019re not already mentioning this information in callout extensions,\u00a0sitelinks\u00a0and structured snippets.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s early days but we\u2019re welcoming these changes. There are still some unknowns, particularly around whether these new double headlines might truncate when making full use of the 60 character limit.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Google have attempted to clarify the situation, but it\u2019s still not entirely clear. On the one hand,\u00a0Google\u2019s post on the Google Advertiser Community forum\u00a0recommends advertisers \u201cconsider creating headlines with 33 characters or less to ensure all of their ad text shows,\u201d whilst also stating that \u201cwe recommend utilizing all of the characters allowed by this new format.\u201d 33 characters would make writing in this new format extremely difficult.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These are heady times in the world of Google. In the last few months alone we\u2019ve seen the\u00a0removal of ads on the right-hand side of Google\u2019s results pages, a shift from yellow to green ad labels for text ads (which makes it harder to differentiate paid ads from organic results) and a change to the width of organic results in the SERPs (allowing for longer titles and meta descriptions). Next up: a major overhaul\u00a0to\u00a0the AdWords interface, which is going to be rolled out later this year and into next. We can\u2019t wait to see it.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s early days but we\u2019re welcoming these changes. There are still some unknowns, particularly around whether these new double headlines might truncate when making full use of the 60 character limit.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Google have attempted to clarify the situation, but it\u2019s still not entirely clear. On the one hand,\u00a0Google\u2019s post on the Google Advertiser Community forum\u00a0recommends advertisers \u201cconsider creating headlines with 33 characters or less to ensure all of their ad text shows,\u201d whilst also stating that \u201cwe recommend utilizing all of the characters allowed by this new format.\u201d 33 characters would make writing in this new format extremely difficult.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These are heady times in the world of Google. In the last few months alone we\u2019ve seen the\u00a0removal of ads on the right-hand side of Google\u2019s results pages, a shift from yellow to green ad labels for text ads (which makes it harder to differentiate paid ads from organic results) and a change to the width of organic results in the SERPs (allowing for longer titles and meta descriptions). Next up: a major overhaul\u00a0to\u00a0the AdWords interface, which is going to be rolled out later this year and into next. We can\u2019t wait to see it.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Questions"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you\u2019d like to find out more about expanded text ads and how our team can help you, please\u00a0get in touch\u00a0and one of our experts will get back to you.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We are very excited to announce that Torchbox has been shortlisted for\u00a0five\u00a0Digital Impact Awards.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Digital Impact Awards

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The\u00a0Digital Impact Awards\u00a0are back! Established in 2009 by\u00a0Communicate Magazine, the awards celebrate the very best in digital communications, from websites through to digital marketing and social media management. Previous winners include Rolls Royce, Marie Curie, IKEA and British Heart Foundation.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Digital Impact Awards shortlist badge", "image": 1167, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Nominations"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This is the first year we\u2019ve entered the Digital Impact Awards, and we\u2019re delighted to have started our awards efforts with a bang.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our social video campaign for\u00a0Africa Progress Panel\u00a0has been shortlisted in three categories, whilst our paid search and social media campaign for\u00a0Royal College of Nursing\u00a0has been shortlisted in another two categories:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • Best Use of Digital to Aid a CR Campaign: Africa Progress Panel
  • Best Use of Existing Social Media Platforms:\u00a0Africa Progress Panel
  • Best Use of Online Video:\u00a0Africa Progress Panel
  • Best Digital Charity/ NGO Campaign:\u00a0Royal College of Nursing
  • Best Use of Digital by Sector (Healthcare):\u00a0Royal College of Nursing
"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We are thrilled to be amongst this year\u2019s Digital Impact Awards shortlist which includes\u00a0Transport for London, Expedia, Lynx,\u00a0LinkedIn\u00a0and Unilever.\u00a0We would like to extend our congratulations to all nominees and look forward to meeting everyone at the awards ceremony on 18th October at The Brewery in London.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To view Torchbox's nominations, please take a look below or alternatively visit\u00a0Communicate Magazine's website\u00a0to view the full shortlist.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Shortlisted Work"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "Africa Progress Panel"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shortlisted for:\u00a0Best Use of Digital to Aid a CR Campaign, Best Use of Existing Social Media Platforms & Best Use of Online Video

"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://youtu.be/giRe0EMROVk"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To promote Africa Progress Panel\u2019s report on global warming and its effects on Africa, we launched a social video campaign to raise awareness and drive report downloads. Our campaign not only achieved its objectives, it completely smashed them. Since launch the campaign has amassed more than 242,000 video views, driving 17,951 report downloads.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

View the Africa Progress Panel case study

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "Royal College of Nursing"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Shortlisted for:\u00a0Best Digital Charity/ NGO Campaign & Best Use of Digital by Sector (Healthcare)

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Royal College of Nursing", "image": 1163, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We launched a paid search and social media campaign to promote Royal College of Nursing\u2019s membership benefits to the UK healthcare workforce. Using a mixture of clever targeting techniques, we were able to drive large volumes of membership registrations in a highly cost effective manner. For every \u00a31 spent, our campaign returned 629% ROI.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

View the Royal College of Nursing case study

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in Touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out more about our campaigns for Africa Progress Panel and Royal College of Nursing, please get in touch.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

We are delighted to announce that Torchbox has won two WebAwards. One for the design of Museum of London\u2019s website and another for Shakespeare Birthplace Trust\u2019s website.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "WebAwards"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Established in 1997, the WebAwards recognise the people and organisations responsible for developing the best websites on the internet today. Previous winners include the likes of Virgin Atlantic Airways,\u00a0Walmart and PlayStation.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We are thrilled with our two WebAwards and would like to thank our team for all of their hard work and dedication - this result wouldn't be possible without you.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To find out about our award-winning work and the judges comments, please take a look below.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Museum of London"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Award won: Best Design Website (Best of Industry)

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our brief was to reinterpret the Museum of London\u2019s brand for the contemporary digital space: embracing its inclusivity and appeal to families, while better representing its sophistication irreverence, and relevance to the city's cultural dialogue.

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Museum of London website", "image": 1528, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For maximum visual impact, we made the Museum of London's\u00a0fabulous collections the centerpiece of our design. We worked hard to strike the right balance between elegance and fun, making the website engaging and easy to explore for users of any age or background.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "Judges comments:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • \"This is the second time I have seen the site and love that the information of history is well portrayed.\"
  • \"Excellent structure and perfect amount of content to engage and encourage visits to the Museum.\"
  • \"Very nicely done site. I enjoyed the use of colors and how they divided the information using photos/graphics.\"

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Visit the Museum of London WebAwards page

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Shakespeare Birthplace Trust"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Award won: Oustanding Website

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We worked with\u00a0Shakespeare Birthplace Trust to transform an old, complex to navigate, unresponsive website into a beautiful, visually engaging website, which encourages user exploration and engagement.\u00a0

"}, {"type": "aligned_image", "value": {"caption": "Shakespeare Birthplace Trust's homepage", "image": 1527, "attribution": "", "alignment": "full"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The interactive carousel at the top of the homepage promotes Shakespeare Birthplace Trust's main exhibitions and content placed throughout the rest of the site encourages users to find out more about upcoming events and\u00a0new\u00a0published content.

"}, {"type": "h4", "value": "Judges comments:"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • \"Torchbox really hit the nail and made something beautiful. Visuals and techniques are a 10. An excellent header introduction for every page/section, a great menu navigation.\"

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Visit Shakespeare Birthplace Trust's WebAwards page

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Get in touch"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If you'd like to find out how we can help you to create an award-winning website, please get in touch. We'd love to hear from you.

"}]

[{"type": "intro", "value": "

Undoubtedly the client brief is one of the most critical, yet\u00a0unstandardised\u00a0aspects of our industry.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Throughout my career, I\u2019ve seen both ends of the scale. By both ends, I mean polar opposites - from one liners, to RFPs that make War and Peace look like an afternoon skim read.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Every organisation is different, and each project has different needs so there will never be a one-size-fits-all template for RFPs. But a well written brief leads to well written proposals: it will help agencies understand your story, evaluate your requirements accurately, and also assess their \u2018fit\u2019 to you organisationally. Here are our guidelines for pulling together an effective RFP.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Tell your story"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The starting point should always be \u2018context\u2019. A concise, rounded summary of your organisation is great to lay the foundations. Round this off with the vision - this should be big and broad, encompassing the essence of what your company or organisation wants to be. This is a well known example:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our vision is to be earth\u2019s most customer centric company; to build a place where people can come to find and discover anything they might want to buy online.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Amazon.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

It\u2019s important to keep it concise and focussed. Try to limit your summary to a few paragraphs - it needs to be short, yet accurate.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The second most important context is your audience. Who are they, how do they behave? If you\u2019re not 100% sure, be open and say so. Good agencies will want to help you better understand your audience. It\u2019s often beneficial to recap on previous successes and failures - where you are now, and how you got there.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Describe the problem or challenge (and not the solution)"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Clients should be engaging agencies to solve problems, not execute predefined instructions. If you approach a project with an open mind about solutions, especially from a technical point of view, you\u2019re enabling agencies to think creatively around the problem.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

As a starting point, outline the organisational needs and then separately list audience needs. These distinctly different lists should not be confused with one another. For example:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  • Organisational or business need: This is usually supporting the organisation's strategic objective.
  • Audience need or human truth: Sometimes referred to as the \u2018why\u2019. Understanding the people, culture, context and other human aspects driving a behaviour.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Objectives"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

These range from the sublime to the ridiculous. I\u2019ve witnessed briefs with brash statements of growth, huge aspirations of sales and vast statistics of engagement. It isn\u2019t necessarily wrong to include aspirations, but demonstrating the validity of these targets is critical. If they are just made up numbers, then say so. Most agencies will take this information onboard and help to shape the brief and KPIs to achieve a certain degree of these objectives. The key task here is to summarise what success looks like; it\u2019ll give the respondee a clear methodology to prioritise and optimise the response.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Limitations"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

What limitations do you have to work around? It could be a platform or technology; it could be a legal restriction or a moral grey area. Try to establish the parameters that your prospective suppliers must operate within.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Timings"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We\u2019ve all had the brief that arrives on a Friday asking for responses at 9am on Monday (oh, and the launch needs to be in two weeks). These aren\u2019t timings, these are demands. What the respondent needs to know is the context of any time pressures, not the time you\u2019ve allowed for the task. Be clear about what\u2019s driving your timescale. There may be dependencies (internal/external) driving these target dates. If so, make sure these are clarified. Short timings often reflect the manner in which an organisation operates, timings can be very telling about whether a client and agency are compatible.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Budget"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Ah yes, the golden question. Would you buy a house without a budget in mind? Probably not. I\u2019ve had many discussions about this over the years with both agency and client side colleagues. The usual comment is \u2018well if I give you a budget figure you\u2019ll price the project to meet that\u2019. No: if we understand your budget and your ambitions then we can propose a solution which is realistic and achievable. An unspecified budget is a waste of time for both sides and it certainly won\u2019t result in the best responses.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In an ideal world, a procurement project should have three to five respondents, all within 5-10% variance in costs. This approach will leave the quality and content of the response as the deciding factor. Having widely disparate costings is just distracting.\u00a0Personally,\u00a0I think a budget range is the most appropriate approach\u00a0to\u00a0specifying a brief. It will demonstrate an understanding of what it will likely take to deliver a solution.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Response framework"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Should suppliers submit their proposals in the format they prefer, or will you send out a proforma for them to complete? There\u2019s no single right answer because there\u2019s no such thing as an identikit project. Bearing in mind your goal is to have a shortlist of options from which to evaluate the best respondent, creating a structure that helps you compare responses will save you time and effort later on. This can be as simple as a clear set of headings you expect suppliers to use, or a list of key information you\u2019re expecting them to supply.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Encourage collaboration"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

If the project is still somewhat undefined, try expanding the process to be more collaborative in the early stages. Encourage respondents to question and challenge the brief in their PQQ (pre-qualification questionnaires). Most, if not all agencies will be happy to meet before submitting a proposal. Use this opportunity to challenge the original brief alongside their PQQ responses. They may raise valid points or uncover new thinking. The effect will likely be a sharper brief and it helps you to establish chemistry and get a feel for how the agency works.

"}, {"type": "h2", "value": "Summary"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In summary, a comprehensive brief should include the following:

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

  1. Tell your story
  2. Describe the problem or challenge
  3. Outline the objectives
  4. Identify the limitations
  5. Highlight timing pressures
  6. Outline the budget range
  7. Provide response guidance
  8. Invite collaboration

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The most common issue with briefs is that they cover a couple of the aspects above and leave the rest blank. This is where the problems start, as it often means the brief isn\u2019t clear in the author's mind. The most successful projects start from clear briefs.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This list isn\u2019t exhaustive, there\u2019ll be nuances and specific information needed for any brief, but hopefully this will cover the basics in creating a robust and comprehensible brief as the first stage of a really successful process.

"}]
